TAG_CO8::::1: Circle of Eight Modpack Version 8.1.0 New Content Edition
TAG_CO8::::2: Welcome!Some important notes:1.  Run as administrator if you're using Windows Vista, Windows 7, or Windows 8.2. Set your video card to a "no scaling" setting for video playback. This will make in-game videos play at their original resolution. Some systems experience game crashes when they try to scale ToEE's videos to fit the monitor.3. Do not use quicksaves with ToEE. They corrupt easily. Instead, use an array of at least 5 regular saves while playing ToEE, overwriting each in turn. This practice should ensure that you have a good save to go back to if one becomes corrupt.4. Do not save during combat. This also runs a greater risk of save corruption.5. Do not play in Ironman mode. Save corruption is a fact of life with ToEE, and if your Ironman save becomes corrupt, you're finished. If you want an Ironman-style game, it's best to simply play Ironman-style in a regular game.6. Do not use "autosave on map change" with ToEE. Using this feature will break certain scripts in ToEE. It is set to "off" by default in the Co8 modpack.7. Do not install the moebius2778 temple.dll independently. This file has been heavily modded since moebius2778's day at Co8, and the moebius fixes are included in the current version. If you overwrite the current version with the moebius version, you will be "undoing" a great many fixes. Do not install it separately.8. Do not put an NPC in the left-most position in the party queue along the bottom of the screen. This can cause a variety of problems, such as quests not updating properly or even appearing in your logbook at all.9. Do not use Scather or Fragarach in the Fire Node or the Fire Temple. You will likely experience the endless AoO loop, and you will be very sad.Many other common issues are answered in sticky threads at the Co8 site - www.co8.org.Enjoy the game!
TAG_INTERFACE_HELP::::2: [CMD_CHILDREN]Note that during game play you can access the ~Main Menu~[TAG_MAIN_MENU] at any time by pressing the ESC key, which will allow you to ~Load and Save~[TAG_LOADSAVE] games as well as Quit the game altogether.
TAG_MAIN_MENU:TAG_INTERFACE_HELP:::2: The Main Menu is the first selection screen that appears when you start the game. Additionally, you can back out to this menu by quitting the game, or you can bring it up by pressing the ESC key from within the game.From the main menu, you will be able to start a New Game in either ~Normal~[TAG_NORMAL_GAME] or ~Ironman~[TAG_IRONMAN] mode, ~Load or Save~[TAG_LOADSAVE] a game, play the Tutorial, view the Game Options, or Quit the game altogether.
TAG_LOADSAVE:TAG_INTERFACE_HELP:::2: From within the game, you can bring up the ~Main Menu~[TAG_MAIN_MENU] by pressing the ESC key. From the Main Menu, you can select to Save your game in progress or Load an existing game (and thus leave your current game). In the Save Game menu, you can choose an empty slot or delete a previously saved game by saving over it. You can then name your saved game.From the Load Game menu, simply click on the game you would like to load, highlighting it, and then ACCEPT it to load the game. Remember that this will destroy any game in progress.Finally, you can use the F12 key to do a Quick Save of the game at any time or the F9 key to do a Quick Load of the last Quick Save game.
TAG_NORMAL_GAME:TAG_INTERFACE_HELP:::2: The normal game allows you to reroll your character's ability points and load and save your game whenever you want. This is in contrast to the ~Ironman Mode~[TAG_IRONMAN] which gives you only one roll for your character's abilities and does not allow you to return to past saved games.
TAG_IRONMAN:TAG_INTERFACE_HELP:::2: Ironman Mode is a special mode of the game where you are not allowed to ~Load and Save~[TAG_LOADSAVE] games, although you may Quick Save and Exit and Quick Load to return to the game. You are also not allowed to reroll your characters once you have selected them.
TAG_CHARGEN:TAG_INTERFACE_HELP:::2: Once you have selected a party alignment, you may begin character generation by selecting the blue character boxes at the bottom of the screen.First you roll for your ~ability~[TAG_ABILITIES] scores. If you don't like the outcome, you can reroll your scores. Once you find scores to your liking, you then click and drag them to the ability of your choice. Modifiers are shown as soon as you place the score.When done, you then select your ~Race~[TAG_RACES], ~Gender~[TAG_CHARGEN_GENDER], ~Height~[TAG_CHARGEN_HEIGHT], ~Hairstyle~[TAG_CHARGEN_HAIR], ~Class~[TAG_CLASSES], ~Alignment~[TAG_ALIGNMENT], and ~Deity~[TAG_RELIGION], as well as a ~portrait~[TAG_CHARGEN_PORTRAIT], ~voice~[TAG_CHARGEN_VOICE], and name for your character.You also select your class abilities (where applicable) of ~feats~[TAG_FEATS], ~skills~[TAG_SKILLS], and ~spells~[TAG_SPELLS] (if any) from the lists with available ones highlighted in white and class specific ones displayed in yellow.You must select all your skills, feats, and spells before moving on to the next category.After naming your character (the last step), you can then select FINISH and your character will be ready to begin adventuring.For more detailed information about each interface within Character Generation, please see ~Interface Help (Specific)~[TAG_HMU_ROOT], and scroll down to the PC Creation section.
TAG_INGAME:TAG_INTERFACE_HELP:::2: You can press ESC at any time to bring up the Main Menu from within the game in order to load, save, or exit the game.Additionally, at the bottom right of the game screen, you can select party formations, your logbook, the Townmap (and World Map), rest or pass time, this help text, or the game options.You can select characters by clicking on them. For multiple characters, you can SHIFT-click on them or rope them together by clicking and dragging the mouse around the characters you want to select.You can give your characters commands through the ~radial menu~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU] by right clicking on a character.To move selected characters, left click on the destination where you would like them to move.You can left click on NPCs to interact with them. If they are not hostile, it will open a dialog with them. If they are hostile, combat will begin.
TAG_CHAR_ABILITIES_UI:TAG_DUMMY:::2: The interface specifically for your character or characters can be viewed by right-clicking on the character portrait displayed on the bottom of the game screen. In the middle of the interface, you will see a large box with a series of tabs lining the top. The last tab on the right, the one that features a figure with arms spread open, is the Abilities tab. Hovering over the tab itself with your mouse will produce a description of Abilities and then clicking on the tab will open that part of the interface. Here, you will see the following list:Kill Count: the number of enemies that the character has killedDeath Count: the number of times the character has diedCharacter Generation Method (# of Rolls)Mode (will read either ~Normal~[TAG_NORMAL_GAME] or ~Ironman~[TAG_IRONMAN])
TAG_HMU_CHAR_BARTERING_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT::: The Bartering interface looks very similar to the character ~inventory~[TAG_HMU_CHAR_INVENTORY_UI] with an extra pane on the left side for the NPC's inventory. Hovering over any item in your character's inventory will display the price that the NPC will buy it for, and hovering over any item in the NPC's inventory will tell you what the NPC will sell it for. To buy or sell an item, simply drag it from one inventory to the other. In some cases, the NPC will refuse to buy or sell an item, and he will tell you if that is the case.All shopkeepers can identify magic items, for a price. Simply click the Identify button and you will get a special identify cursor. Click on any unidentified magic item in your inventory and for 100 gp the shopkeeper will identify it.
TAG_HMU_CAMPING_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: The Rest/Pass Time icon lets "fast-forward" time, either a set amount, in days and hours, or until a condition is met. Click on the Rest or Pass Time button after making your selection, or click on Cancel to go back to the game.Note: While you can pass time anywhere, you are only allowed to rest in certain locations (usually at inns, if you pay first, or in the wilderness or in dungeons). If the Rest/Pass Time icon looks like a watch, you can only pass time. If it looks like a tent, you can rest. You must rest to heal and recover spells.Before resting, look carefully at the tent icon. If the background is green, you can rest safely without interruption. However, if it is yellow, you may have a ~random encounter~[TAG_HMU_RANDOM_ENCOUNTER_UI] while you rest. The type of encounter you have will depend on your location, and you cannot avoid it with the ~Survival~[TAG_SURVIVAL] skill.
TAG_HMU_CHAR_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: Here you may view your character's ~inventory~[TAG_HMU_CHAR_INVENTORY_UI], ~portrait~[TAG_CHARGEN_PORTRAIT], ~stats~[TAG_CHARGEN_STATS], ~skills~[TAG_SKILLS], ~feats~[TAG_FEATS], ~spells~[TAG_SPELLS] and ~abilities~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_DESC] of the character. For more information, please see the help text provided specifically for each one of these aspects in the character interface.
TAG_HMU_CHAR_EDITOR_CLERIC_DOMAINS:TAG_H: If you select Cleric as your class, in the class features section you will be asked to select a Cleric ~domain~[TAG_DOMAINS]. On the left side of the interface is a listing of domains that you can choose from. On the right side is two empty slots where the selected domains can be dragged over.If you are a neutral cleric with a neutral deity, there will be an additional part of the interface present. Two buttons representing affiliation will be in the interface; one reads "Positive" and the other, "Negative".If you select the Positive affiliation, your cleric will turn undead and spontaneously cast Cure spells. If you select the Negative affiliation, your cleric will rebuke undead and spontaneously cast Inflict spells.
TAG_HMU_COMBAT_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: When entering ~combat~[TAG_COMBAT], a row of character and monster portraits will appear at the top of the screen, in order of ~initiative~[TAG_INITIATIVE]. On the left side of the screen, a bar will appear. The combat system in the game translates the actions you have available into a numerical score and displays that score as a bar, with three colors. The action bar, path movement, and the entries on the ~radial menu~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU] are all color coded as follows:Green: An action can be performed, and you will still be able to attack afterward (for ~move actions~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION]) or move afterward (for attacks).Yellow: An action can be performed, but you will not be able to attack afterward (for move actions) or move much (for attacks).Red: An action cannot be performed.
TAG_HMU_COMBAT_INITIATIVE_UI:TAG_HMU_ROO: Listed in ~Initiative~[TAG_INITIATIVE] order are the participants of the current combat. The blue border indicates who is currently acting.Hovering over a portrait displays the creature's vital stats.You may click on each portrait to center the game screen on that creature.You may drag portraits around to indicate your desired position in the Initiative order.Initiative Portraits are also selectable targets, e.g., you may target a portrait as the recipient of an action, and it will select the appropriate creature in the combat.Creatures gray out when they are ~unconscious~[TAG_UNCONSCIOUS] or ~dying~[TAG_DYING], and eventually are removed when they die.
TAG_HMU_D20_ROLLS_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: The Rolls History icon brings up a scrollable history of all die rolls in the game. Combat ~attack rolls~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL], damage rolls, ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC], and ~skill~[TAG_USING_SKILLS] and ability checks are all in there. The roll history can be found at the bottom right corner of the game screen, on the Main Icon Bar. Above icons for Help, Townmap, etc., you will see a small crystal-shaped icon, on the extreme right of the bar. Click on that and a window will open, which shows your roll history.
TAG_HMU_DLG_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: The Dialog window opens whenever you talk to an NPC. The top pane of the window shows the conversation thread so far, alternating between lines the NPC has said and lines your character has said. The bottom pane displays all of the current PC responses.Note: An icon appears to the left of any line that uses a dialog skill, such as ~Diplomacy~[TAG_DIPLOMACY].The Dialog History icon in the upper right displays a record of several previous conversations.
TAG_CHAR_FEATS_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: The ~Feats~[TAG_FEATS] interface can be found by either right-clicking on the character portrait in the bottom left-hand side of the game screen, or right-clicking on the character itself, which will bring up the ~radial menu~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU]. With your mouse, hover over the Backpack icon, and you will see "~Inventory~[TAG_HMU_CHAR_INVENTORY_UI]". Selecting this will also open the character interface.Once opened, Feats are located in the row of tabs or icons above the box in the center of the interface, and the tab has a Hand pictured on it. Clicking on this tab will open the Feats section of the interface, where the character's feats will be listed, both those that have already been selected in character creation and those that remain future options. If you slide the cursor/arrow over a feat, a short description and any prerequisites required for that feat will be displayed in a text box at the bottom of the interface.
TAG_HMU_FORMATION_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: This interface allows you to create up to four party formations and select an active formation. The Formation icon is a triangle, found on the Main Icon Bar. Click on this icon to open the Formation interface.Use the numbered tabs along the top to select the active formation, and change a formation by clicking and dragging the character portraits to different locations. The game will initialize your formations to several standard formations, including the two-column formation, the T formation, and the V formation.
TAG_HMU_HELP_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: The ~Help~[TAG_ROOT] icon activates the in-game help system. In this interface, you can access nearly every facet of the game, including the 3.5 D&D rules and definitions. The interface works like a browser, and links show as blue text. Click on any blue text to access more detailed information on that topic.The six blue buttons along the bottom allow you to move through the database. The first two buttons are similar to a browser's back and next buttons. The third button is a home button and takes you to the topmost page of the database. The last three buttons move you to the topic before, above, or after the current topic.
TAG_HMU_CHAR_INVENTORY_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT::: Character inventory may be found either by right-clicking on the character portrait at the bottom left corner of the game screen or by right-clicking on the character itself, which will bring up the ~radial menu~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU]. Selecting the Backpack icon and then the tab that says "Inventory" will open the interface as well.Available items and armor will be displayed on the left side of the interface, with different colored tabs lining the top. The four tabs along the top allow access to different equipped item configurations, which you can set up in advance and then quickly swap configurations using the tabs. To create a configuration, simply drag items into its positions. When you switch away from a configuration, all equipped items return to your inventory. When you switch back to a configuration, all of its previously equipped items are re-equipped.When hovering on any item, a description will pop up in the blank text box on the bottom of the main interface, which states important characteristics like weight, ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] bonuses, damage, etc.Directly to the right is the inventory grid, with the Backpack icon on the left side. Click the Backpack icon to open the usable inventory screen. To use an item, whether that involves putting new armor on a character or changing a weapon, click in the box on the left that holds the item and drag it into the larger box to the right into any open space. Then, at the bottom, you will see an icon/tab with a hand holding an object. Scrolling over this button will indicate that it is the "use an item" button. Next to this button is another with a hand letting go of an object; this is the "drop an item" button. Drag an item to the Use Item icon and the window will close, then the game acts as if you had selected the item to use from the radial menu. If you drag an item to the Drop Item icon, the item is removed from that character's inventory and placed on the ground at the character's location.Next to these two buttons is a blue box that reads "Total Weight" with a text box displaying the amount of weight that the character currently holds. Scrolling over this number will result in a text message that states whether or not you are ~encumbered~[TAG_ADVENTURING_ENCUMBRANCE].The Inventory interface also shows the amount of money that your character has in his or her possession, directly above the listing of character stats.
TAG_HMU_ITEM_CREATION_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::: If your character has an ~item creation~[TAG_FEAT_TYPES] feat, such as ~Craft Wondrous Item~[TAG_CRAFT_WONDROUS] or ~Scribe Scroll~[TAG_SCRIBE_SCROLL] (see also ~Item Creation~[TAG_ITEM_CREATION] feats), they can open the Item Creation interface by right-clicking on their character to display the ~radial menu~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU]. In the radial menu, click on the Hand icon and select the item creation feat you would like your character to use.Once the feat is selected, the item creation interface will open. On the left side, choose the item you would like to create. If an item is dark gray, your character cannot create that item because necessary prerequisites are missing. If an item is red, your character does not have the needed value to create that item. On the top right side, the following aspects are listed:   - the item's name   - the ~XP~[TAG_EXPERIENCE_AND_LEVELS] cost that is required to create this item   - the monetary value of creating this item   - the prerequisite that is needed to create this itemOn the bottom, the name of your character, the remaining XP available for using, and the money that is left to spend is listed. Once your item is selected from the left, click the Create button.
TAG_HMU_CHAR_EDITOR_CLASS_UI:TAG_HMU_ROO: Once a character gains enough ~experience points~[TAG_EXPERIENCE_AND_LEVELS] (XP) to Level Up, a small icon will appear on their character portrait. Click on this icon to open the Level Up interface.The Class portion of the interface is similar to Class in character creation, with two rows of buttons listing each ~class~[TAG_CLASSES]. You will choose which class you would like to level up in and click that button.
TAG_HMU_CHAR_EDITOR_FEATS_UI:TAG_HMU_ROO: Once a character gains enough ~experience points~[TAG_EXPERIENCE_AND_LEVELS] (XP) to level up, a small icon will appear on their character portrait. Click on this icon to open the Level Up interface.If it is time for your character to gain another ~feat~[TAG_FEATS], this option will be available to you in the Feats section of the Level Up interface. For most characters, this occurs at 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th, 15th, and 18th levels. ~Fighters~[TAG_FIGHTERS] gain an additional ~bonus feat~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_FIGHTER_BONUS_FEATS] at 2nd, 4th, 6th, 8th, 10th, 12th, 14th, 16th, 18th, and 20th levels. ~Wizards~[TAG_WIZARDS] gain an additional ~bonus feat~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_WIZARD_BONUS_FEATS] at 5th, 10th, 15th, and 20th levels.In the Level Up interface, the layout and functionality of the feats section is basically the same as it was in the character creation interface for feats. Select a feat from the list on the left and drag it into the empty box or boxes on the right.
TAG_HMU_CHAR_EDITOR_FEATURES_UI:TAG_HMU_: Some ~classes~[TAG_CLASSES] get ~special abilities~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_DESC] (sometimes optional) at certain levels. The interfaces vary according to class, but all are fairly similar to the character creation interfaces. For example, a level 1, 5, 10, 15 or 20 ~ranger~[TAG_RANGERS] must pick a ~favored enemy~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_RANGER_FAVORED_ENEMY] and a level 2 ranger must pick a ~combat style~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_RANGER_COMBAT_STYLE].
TAG_HMU_CHAR_EDITOR_SKILLS_UI:TAG_HMU_RO: Once a character gains enough ~experience points~[TAG_EXPERIENCE_AND_LEVELS] (XP) to level up, a small icon will appear on their character portrait. Click on this icon to open the Level Up interface.The Skills segment of the Level Up interface resembles that of the Skill section in the character interface. On the right side, you will see the number of ~skill points~[TAG_ACQUIRE_SKILLS] that you are able to spend, while on the left is the ~list of skills~[TAG_SKILL_DES] that you can put points into. As before, click the up arrow to the right of the skill name to add points into any skill. Spend your new skill points for your character at a cost of 1 point per class skill and 2 points per cross-class skill.
TAG_HMU_CHAR_EDITOR_STATS_UI:TAG_HMU_ROO: Within the Level Up interface, the section on Stats is a display of the six ~abilities~[TAG_THE_ABILITIES]. Every fourth level, you can raise an ability score by one point. Click on any one of the stats in the row of buttons and one point will be added to that ability.
TAG_HMU_LOADGAME_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: ~Load Game~[TAG_LOADSAVE] is a choice listed on the ~main menu~[TAG_MAIN_MENU] at the beginning of the game. Clicking on Load Game will bring up on interface in which all previously saved games are listed by the names you have given them, the location of your party, and a date. Select a game and then click the Load button in the bottom right corner of the interface.
TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: The Logbook icon will bring up the Logbook interface, which is broken into five sections, accessible by the tab at the top of the Logbook:                    ~Quests~[TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_QUESTS], ~Reputations~[TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_REPUTATIONS], ~Ego~[TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_EGO], ~Keys~[TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_KEYS], and ~Rumors~[TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_RUMORS]
TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_EGO:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: The Ego section of the Logbook keeps track of various party data, including combat stats, damage ranges and similar information. These data are arranged on the left page, with tabs to switch to different ego subsections. The right page shows the actual information. For example, you can select "Creatures Killed" under the Combat tab on the left side of the Ego page. The right side will then list every monster type that you have killed in the game, and tabs on that page will let you sort these monsters by CR, Hit Dice or Name.
TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_EGO_COMBAT:TAG_HMU_RO: In the Ego section of the Logbook, there are three different tabs displayed on the left side, at the top of the book. The first is Combat. Clicking on this tab will reveal various stats that your character has accrued during ~combat~[TAG_COMBAT], including the following:   - Creatures Killed   - Most Experience from 1 Combat Session   - Most ~Critical Hits~[TAG_CRITICAL_HIT]   - Most Consecutive Misses   - Most Kills   - Most DeathsThat information can be sorted on the right side of the logbook, according to CR, Hit Dice, or Name of the creatures. There is a matching tab along the top that lists these three categories. Clicking on any of the tabs will sort the combat statistics in that manner.
TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_EGO_DAMAGE:TAG_HMU_RO: In the Ego section of the Logbook, the second tab listed on the top of the left side of the book is Damage. Here, there are statistics that are calculated based on different aspects of damage that the character could either be responsible for administering or situations in which they were the victim. The stats fall under these categories:   - Most Weapon Damage Taken in a Single Attack   - Most Weapon Damage Dealt in a Single Attack   - Most Spell Damage Taken in a Single Attack   - Most Spell Damage Dealt in a Single AttackClicking on any of these categories will bring up the desired information.
TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_EGO_MISC:TAG_HMU_ROOT: After clicking on the Logbook icon on the Main Icon bar, open the Ego section by selecting the corresponding tab. On the left side, the third tab along the top is the Misc tab. Here, you will find an assortment of statistics based on the ~skills~[TAG_SKILLS] and actions of the characters in your party, including:   - Most Traps Disarmed   - Most Traps Set Off   - Most Uses of ~Diplomacy~[TAG_DIPLOMACY]   - Most Uses of ~Bluff~[TAG_BLUFF]   - Most Uses of ~Intimidate~[TAG_INTIMIDATE]   - Most Uses of ~Gather Information~[TAG_GATHER_INFORMATION]Clicking on any of these headings will result in more specific information appearing about each category.
TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_KEYS:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: The Keys section is similar to the ~Quest~[TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_QUESTS] and ~Reputation~[TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_REPUTATIONS] sections in that it shows all keys you have found on the left, and information on the particular selected key on the right.Note: Unlike all other items in the game, keys do not go into personal character inventories, but instead become group communal property listed here in the Logbook.
TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_QUESTS:TAG_HMU_ROOT::: The Quests section keeps track of all quests you have accepted or even heard mentioned. The quests are arranged by the location where you received them, and these locations appear as tabs on the top of the left page. Each quest is listed on the left page--you may need to scroll if you have a lot of quests in that location.Select a quest to see its status and a description on the right page. The status of a quest is either Mentioned (you heard about the quest), Accepted (you have agreed to undertake the quest), Completed (you have finished the quest), or Botched (the quest is in a state where you can no longer complete it). You receive ~experience points~[TAG_EXPERIENCE_AND_LEVELS] for a Completed quest, and sometimes you can "unbotch" a Botched quest. For example, if you are supposed to rescue someone and they are killed, that quest is Botched. But if you resurrect the person, the quest will be unbotched and you can try to complete it.
TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_REPUTATIONS:TAG_HMU_R: The Reputations section is similar to the ~Quest~[TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_QUESTS] section, in that reputations you have acquired on displayed on the left, and information about the reputation on the right. The Logbook tracks when and where the reputation was received and what effect the reputation has on gameplay.
TAG_HMU_LOGBOOK_UI_RUMORS:TAG_HMU_ROOT::: The Rumors sections of your Logbook records rumors that you pick up through conversations with certain people which may serve as useful hints in the game.
TAG_HMU_CHAR_LOOTING_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: The Looting interface is very similar to the ~Bartering~[TAG_HMU_CHAR_BARTERING_UI] interface, with a few exceptions. Instead of an Identify button, there is a Take All button that enables your character to grab all items off another creature. Also, when scrolling over items that have been looted, there will be no prices listed, as they were not bought.Note: If you press the TAB key after killing a creature, the creature will highlight, if it has any loot in it's inventory.
TAG_HMU_MM_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: When the game begins, you will see the ~Main Menu~[TAG_MAIN_MENU], which contains the following options:New Game: Start a new game. You will choose between ~Normal~[TAG_NORMAL_GAME] and ~Ironman~[TAG_IRONMAN] mode.Load Game: ~Load~[TAG_LOADSAVE] a previously saved game.Options: Adjust graphics, controls, and sound options.Tutorial: Play a short introduction to the game.Quit: Quit to Windows.Left-click on any of the above to select what you would like in the Main Menu.
TAG_HMU_OPTIONS_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: The Options menu allows you to change your video, audio and preferences settings. You can change options either from the ~Main Menu~[TAG_MAIN_MENU], before starting a game, or from within a game using the Options icon on the Main Icon Bar. Note that the Video and Audio settings are configuration settings and therefore are set for every game, while Preferences settings apply just to the game you are playing (or the next game you start, if you are at the Main Menu).
TAG_HMU_PARTY_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: These portraits represent the controllable characters currently in the party. If your character is currently under the effects of a condition, you may see Buff indicators above and Ailment indicators below the portrait. You will also be able to see the character's current ~Hit Point~[TAG_HIT_POINTS] total in the form of the HP bar. If you left-click the HP bar, you will see a numerical representation of the character's current and maximum Hit Points on top of the portrait. Your character's portrait flashes briefly whenever he/she takes damage.Left-clicking a portrait changes the currently selected character (modifiable with the SHIFT key).Left-clicking a portrait will also change the focus of the ~inventory~[TAG_HMU_CHAR_INVENTORY_UI], if the Inventory screen is showing.Left-clicking a Buff or Ailment indicator will open the ~Help UI~[TAG_HMU_HELP_UI] to the appropriate topic.By left-clicking and dragging the portraits, you may change the party marching order.By right-clicking a portrait, you may access/close Inventory for that character.These portraits are selectable in combat as targets, much like the portraits in the ~Combat Initiative UI~[TAG_HMU_COMBAT_INITIATIVE_UI].If a character is able to level up, due to experience, an indicator will appear to bring up the Level Up UI.If a character in the party dies, an indicator will appear to bring up a Party Dismissal UI.
TAG_HMU_PARTY_UI_HP_BAR:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: Left-clicking on the HP bar will cause the character portrait to display the character's current ~HP~[TAG_HIT_POINTS]/maximum HP.
TAG_HMU_PARTY_POOL_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: The character pool interface is used for the creation and organization of your party. Once you create a character, the character may be added and listed on screen, with their portrait, name, and main information.There are four buttons lining the top portion of the interface: create, view, rename, and deleteCreate will bring you to the character creation interface, where you will roll stats and choose your character's ~class~[TAG_CLASSES], ~race~[TAG_RACES], and other attributes.Clicking on View will bring up a small window that holds information about a particular character in your party (the basic defining traits like class and race, as well as their character stats, etc.).Choosing the Rename button will allow you to rename a character.Delete permanently erases the selected character from the party.Toward the bottom of the interface is a button that will either read as Add or Remove, depending on the appropriate action needed. Once a new character is created and listed in the interface, you will need to select Add in order for the character to actually be included in the party. First, click on the desired character's portrait located in the row directly underneath the Add button (the character will be highlighted in blue to indicate the selection), then click Add.If the character's ~alignment~[TAG_ALIGNMENT] or class does not conflict with the party alignment that was chosen, he or she will be added to the party and highlighted in green to indicate the successful addition. If the character's alignment does conflict, then the character will be highlighted in red, indicating that it is not possible to add that character to the party. Likewise, if there is a conflict regarding class and the alignment of the party (specifically, with ~Paladins~[TAG_PALADINS], as they cannot be added to any parties with evil characters) then that character will not be added.If you would like to exclude a character from your party but not permanently delete them, click on their picture in the portrait row and select Remove. The character will no longer be highlighted in green and is removed from the party, but it will still be listed among the other party members, if you wish to add them again at a later time.
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: To create a new character, click on the Create button on the Party Pool screen. Character creation requires a series of steps, which you progress through by clicking on buttons on the right side of the screen. As you complete each creation step, the next button will light up, indicating you can click on it and advance to the next stage.At any time during creation, you may back up to an earlier step by clicking on the appropriate button. You will need to repeat any intermediate stages. For example, if you are picking your ~class~[TAG_CLASSES] and want to change your ~race~[TAG_RACES], click on the Race button. You will then need to reselect your ~gender~[TAG_CHARGEN_GENDER] and ~height~[TAG_CHARGEN_HEIGHT] again before selecting class.
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_ABILITIES_UI:TAG_HMU: You need to select for your character the values of six ~ability scores~[TAG_ABILITY_SCORES]: ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH], ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY], ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION], ~Intelligence~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE], ~Wisdom~[TAG_WISDOM] and ~Charisma~[TAG_CHARISMA]These values are normally generated with four six-sided dice (d6), with the lowest die roll discarded, for a range of 3 to 18.In ~Normal~[TAG_NORMAL_GAME] mode, you can choose to roll (and re-roll) your scores or to buy them directly. Point-buying allows you to customize your character's scores, but random rolling will eventually generate better scores.If you roll, then six values are randomly generated, and you can arrange them any way you like by dragging a number from the right column into an ability score box on the left side. If you don't like the numbers, you can reroll until you're satisfied. However, the game keeps track of the number of rolls you make and displays this number on your character's Info Sheet.You can also buy your ability scores directly in Normal mode. When you use this system, your character begins with all abilities at 8 and you are given 25 points to spend on raising your abilities. Abilities cost 1 point to raise for each score up to 14, 2 points for scores 15 and 16, and 3 points for scores 17 and 18.In ~Ironman~[TAG_IRONMAN] mode, you can only roll your scores (no point buying is available), and you must accept the first roll. You can still choose how to arrange the scores, however.
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_ALIGNMENT_UI:TAG_HMU: The Alignment interface is basically a boxed grouping of buttons that list the nine different ~alignments~[TAG_ALIGNMENT]. When creating a party of player characters, the party alignment will limit which characters may adventure together. In selecting one alignment, others that would potentially work with that party alignment will light up. For example, in selecting ~True Neutral~[TAG_NEUTRAL], all of the following alignments light up: ~Neutral Good~[TAG_NEUTRAL_GOOD], ~Neutral Evil~[TAG_NEUTRAL_EVIL], ~Lawful Neutral~[TAG_LAWFUL_NEUTRAL], ~Chaotic Neutral~[TAG_CHAOTIC_NEUTRAL], and of course True NeutralSo in selecting that party alignment, you may only add characters to your party that fall under one of those alignment categories. Once your decision is made, simply click on the chosen button, and then click on the green Accept button. If you change your mind, click the red Cancel button.
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_CLASS_UI:TAG_HMU_ROO: Clicking on the Class button in the character creation interface will lead to the display of all 11 ~class~[TAG_CLASSES] buttons. Scrolling over any Class button will result in a text description of that corresponding class in the text box directly below. In the event that your party's ~alignment~[TAG_ALIGNMENT] does not match the required alignment for a class (specifically, ~Paladins~[TAG_PALADINS] can only be ~Lawful Good~[TAG_LAWFUL_GOOD], with no evil alignments in their party), that alignment will be grayed out and you will be unable to select it. Once the desired class for your character has been chosen, click the appropriate button and move on to the next stage.
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_DEITY_UI:TAG_HMU_ROO: A list of ~deity~[TAG_RELIGION] buttons will be available in the Deity section of the character creation interface. Only deities appropriate to your character's ~class~[TAG_CLASSES], ~race~[TAG_RACES] and ~alignment~[TAG_ALIGNMENT] are available (the remaining choices are grayed out). As with the rest of the character creation interface, hovering on a selection or button will bring up a Help description in the text box below. Click on one of these buttons to select a deity.
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_FEATS_UI:TAG_HMU_ROO: Select the one or more ~feats~[TAG_FEATS] available to your character. Drag feats from the list is on the left into the slots on the right. Some ~classes~[TAG_CLASSES], such as ~fighters~[TAG_FIGHTERS], have specific bonus feats available. These extra feats are colored gold and you may drag them into the similarly colored slot on the right. You may not choose the regular white-colored as these special feats. Also, some feats have prerequisites and you may only select them when your character has achieved those prerequisites (usually another feat, ~skill~[TAG_SKILLS] or minimum ~ability score~[TAG_ABILITY_SCORES]). These feats are colored gray if they are unavailable.
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_GENDER_UI:TAG_HMU_RO: Left click on either the Male or Female button to select your character's ~gender~[TAG_CHARGEN_GENDER].
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_HAIR_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT: Choose a ~hair~[TAG_CHARGEN_HAIR] style from among those provided and then select a hair color from among the listed choices. Although hair choice will not affect game play, it will affect your character's appearance.
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_HEIGHT_UI:TAG_HMU_RO: Select a ~height~[TAG_CHARGEN_HEIGHT], which will vary depending on your character's ~race~[TAG_RACES] and ~gender~[TAG_CHARGEN_GENDER], by dragging the scroll bar provided until finding what you think is the optimal height for your character. Height will vary depending on your character's race and gender, but has no affect on your character's abilities.
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_NAME_VOICE_UI:TAG_HM: Create a name for your character and type into the blank box provided, in the interface for ~Voice and Name~[TAG_CHARGEN_VOICE]. Next, scroll through the available Voice choices that will list different types of male or female voices, such as "Charismatic" or "Naturalist".
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_PORTRAIT_UI:TAG_HMU_: Left-click and choose from among the character ~portraits~[TAG_CHARGEN_PORTRAIT] provided in the interface. You may scroll down further to in order to view all of them. When selected, a larger version of the portrait that you click on will appear in a window on the left side of the interface, which enables you to view the portrait more closely.
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_RACE_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT: Pick one of the seven ~races~[TAG_RACES] for your character by left-clicking and selecting the desired button. You may choose from ~Humans~[TAG_HUMANS], ~Elves~[TAG_ELVES], ~Half-Elves~[TAG_HALF_ELVES], ~Halflings~[TAG_HALFLINGS], ~Half-Orcs~[TAG_HALF_ORCS], ~Gnomes~[TAG_GNOMES], and ~Dwarves~[TAG_DWARVES]. Race affects some ~ability scores~[TAG_ABILITY_SCORES] and determines a ~favored class~[TAG_FAVORED_CLASS]. It will also change the way your character looks in the game.
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_SKILLS_UI:TAG_HMU_RO: Use your character's ~skill points~[TAG_ACQUIRE_SKILLS] (dependent on the character's ~Intelligence~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] score, ~class~[TAG_CLASSES], and ~race~[TAG_RACES]), to purchase ranks in various ~skills~[TAG_SKILLS], at the rate of one rank per point for class skills (white), and one-half rank per point for cross-class skills (gold).The right side of the interface will show the skill points available. You will start out with a number which will decrease with each additional skill point gained until it reaches 0. In order to obtain skills and add skill points, click on the up arrow directly to the right of a skill. If you want to subtract a skill point, click on the down arrow directly to the right, and the appropriate amount of skill points will be added back on to your total.  Use the scroll bar to the right of all the skills to scan down and view the entire list.
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_SPELLS_UI:TAG_HMU_RO: If applicable to your character's ~class~[TAG_CLASSES], select ~spells~[TAG_SPELLS] from the list on the left, and either drag them into a space on the blank lines on the right or you can right-click on the spell and it will appear in the blank list. If you hover over the spell name with your mouse, a description of each spell will appear in the box on the bottom of the interface. Spells must be selected according to Spell Level; so, for example, a 1st-level spell like ~Burning Hands~[TAG_SPELLS_BURNING_HANDS] cannot be dragged into a 0-level space. Fill in all the spaces available with the spells of your liking.
TAG_HMU_PC_CREATION_STATS_UI:TAG_HMU_ROO: By clicking on the ROLL button in the interface, six numbers will be generated in the boxes on the left by the computer rolling four six-sided dice (d6) and eliminating the lowest single die roll. Additionally, scores with ability bonuses that total less than 0 or scores with no number greater than 13 will automatically be rerolled. If you are still unhappy with the outcome, the option is available to reroll as many times as you would like.You assign the six scores to the ~ability~[TAG_THE_ABILITIES] of your choice by clicking and dragging the number to the box next to the ability name. Once all ability scores have been dragged to their desired places, you can reassign them, reroll them, or move on to the next stage of character creation.
TAG_HMU_CHAR_PORTRAIT_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::: The Portrait interface is one section of the Character Interface and can be found on the top left side. The Portrait interface has three main parts with corresponding buttons. These buttons are directly underneath the blank box in the top left-hand corner; each displays text when the mouse hovers over to give a short description of its function.First, there is the button that shows the character's 3D model, which is shown in the blank box. Second, there is a button that when clicked, will show the character's portrait picture. Lastly, you can click the button that shows the character's item-wield slots.
TAG_HMU_RANDOM_ENCOUNTER_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT: When your party uses the ~World Map~[TAG_HMU_WORLDMAP_UI] interface to travel from one location to another, there is a chance that they may have a random encounter. This is measured against a ~Survival~[TAG_SURVIVAL] check and the computer will then calculate the likelihood. If this does occur, a new interface will pop up in the World Map, that reads "Survival" on the very top. Then, usually, it will have either the type of creature or the type of battle that your party is up against listed directly underneath that. Below this will be a picture icon of the creature and how many creatures are there. (For example, it could have a picture of a Shadow, then say x3 Shadow, which indicates there are three of these creatures.)At the bottom of the interface will be two buttons; the one on the left reads "Engage", the other says "Avoid". You must decide whether to enter your party into combat in this random encounter. If you accept, your party will automatically be transferred to the encounter. If you choose to avoid it, you will continue traveling to your original destination.
TAG_HMU_SAVEGAME_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: To save the game you are currently playing, hit the ESC key and a menu will appear on the game screen. One of the options is ~Save Game~[TAG_LOADSAVE]. Clicking on Save Game will bring up an interface in which there is a blue outlined box that says "Empty". Delete this and type in the name of the game you would like to save. Click on the Save button on the bottom side of the interface and you will then be brought back to the part of the game you were playing previously.
TAG_HMU_SKILL_MASTERY_UI:TAG_DUMMY:::2: Once a ~rogue~[TAG_ROGUES] reaches 10th level and begins going through the leveling up process, he or she has the option of choosing ~Skill Mastery~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_ROGUE_SKILL_MASTERY] as a special ability. If this decision is made, the Skill Mastery interface will appear, in which the rogue needs to choose which skills he or she will "master". On the left side of the interface is a list of skills from which the rogue will select. On the right, is a list of the skills that have already been mastered, followed by a certain number of blank spaces. The number of blank spaces determines how many skills can be mastered at this time. Simply click on a skill on the left side and it will be moved into a blank space. To complete, click on the Accept button at the button; otherwise, you may click Cancel if you would rather not continue.Note: In ToEE, the Skill Mastery ability has not been implemented.
TAG_HMU_CHAR_SKILLS_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: Character ~skills~[TAG_SKILLS] may be found either by right-clicking on the character portrait at the bottom left corner of the game screen or by right-clicking on the actual character, which will bring up the ~radial menu~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU]. Selecting the Backpack icon in the radial menu and then the tab that says "~Inventory~[TAG_HMU_CHAR_INVENTORY_UI]" will open the interface as well.Skills can be found in the character interface, above the large grid in the middle of the interface, by clicking on the tab showing a Hammer & Anvil. There you will see a list of this particular character's skills and the amount of points in each one. To the right, you can view stats for skill rank, the key ability and ability modifier, miscellaneous, and the total. Hovering on a skill will result in these numbers showing up in their corresponding boxes, or in the case of a key ability, the name of the ability will be displayed to the left of the ability modifier. For example, ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] is the key ability for ~Move Silently~[TAG_MOVE_SILENTLY], and this will appear in a gray box to the left of the modifier. For further detail about the skills, scrolling over a skill name with your mouse will provide a short description of the skill in the text box directly below.
TAG_HMU_CHAR_STATS_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: Personal stats in the character interface may be found either by right-clicking on the character portrait at the bottom left corner of the game screen or by right-clicking on the actual character, which will bring up the ~radial menu~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU]. Selecting the Backpack icon in the radial menu and then the tab that says "~Inventory~[TAG_HMU_CHAR_INVENTORY_UI]" will open the interface as well.Character ability stats are listed on the bottom left side of the interface, along with ~experience points~[TAG_EXPERIENCE_AND_LEVELS], level, ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS], ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS], bonuses to saves, bonuses to attacks, ~initiative~[TAG_INITIATIVE], speed, ~height~[TAG_HEIGHT], and ~weight~[TAG_WEIGHT].
TAG_HMU_TOWNMAP_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: The Townmap interface gives you access to an overview of your current location and other locations you have visited, as well as a ~World Map~[TAG_HMU_WORLDMAP_UI]. The location maps, often called Town Maps, show the location you are in--areas you have not seen are blacked-out on the map. Select different locations using the menu on the right side.Use the buttons along the bottom right to manipulate any Town Map. To center the map on your party (drawn as blue circles on the map), press the first button. The second button lets you place note flags on the map. Simply click anywhere on the map and then type in a note to be attached to that flag. Hovering on the flag will display the note. You can delete note flags by clicking the third button and then clicking on any note flag you want to delete. Click on the fourth button to zoom in and out of the Town Map by left-click dragging up an down or by using your mousewheel.The Current Map button below the World Map button will take you back to the Town Map for your current location. The iconic button on the bottom will do that, and center the Town Map on your party's location.In order to exit, click on the red arrow button at the bottom right corner of the interface.
TAG_HMU_TRACK_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: If your character has ~Track~[TAG_TRACK] as a ~feat~[TAG_FEATS], right-click on the character to make the ~radial menu~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU] appear. At this point, click on the Feats icon, which is pictured as a Hand, and choose Track. The Track interface will appear.The left column is for "Enemies Tracked", as is noted by the heading on top. If you are able to track a creature, it is here that the name of the general type of creature will be displayed. This merely presents the creatures that are in the area. On the right side of the interface, a compass is featured, with a heading above that reads "Enemy Direction". The red arrow on the compass will point in the general direction of the creature that has been tracked. At the bottom, there will be the standard red Exit button to return to the game screen.
TAG_HMU_UTILITY_BAR_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: The Main Icon Bar, or Utility Bar, appears in the lower-right corner of the screen. It contains seven icons, all of which bring up a new interface:     Select All, Formations, Logbook, Townmap, Rest/Pass Time, Help, and OptionsThe top right of the icon bar has two tags for the Dialog History and the Rolls History.The bottom of the icon bar contains a clock, which graphically displays the time of day, or the exact time and date, when you hover the mouse cursor over it.
TAG_HMU_CHAR_EDITOR_WIZARD_SPEC:TAG_HMU_: In this interface, a wizard will be asked to choose a specialized ~school~[TAG_MAGIC_SCHOOLS] of magic. A wizard has the option of choosing such a school by selecting from the list entitled "Available Schools". You will drag this school into the box with the heading "Specialized School" and then choose two other schools to be dragged into the "Prohibited Schools" box that is outlined in red.An exception to the rules noted above is the school of Divination. If Divination is chosen as the school that the wizard character will specialize in, then only one school must be selected for the "Prohibited Schools" box.
TAG_HMU_WORLDMAP_UI:TAG_HMU_ROOT:::2: First, to display the interface where the World Map can be found, click on the rolled-up map icon at the bottom right corner of the game screen. This will open the map interface for the ~Townmap~[TAG_HMU_TOWNMAP_UI].Click on the button at the top right of the map interface to display the World Map. Select a location, either by clicking on it in the World Map (such places appear as labeled red circles) or by selecting one of the location names on the list on the right. Your party will then travel to that location, and their path of travel will be drawn as a series of dots. Each dot represents 15 minutes and around a third of a mile of travel. You may have ~random encounters~[TAG_HMU_RANDOM_ENCOUNTER_UI] while traveling, and you may avoid these if one of your character's ~Survival~[TAG_SURVIVAL] skill is high enough. When you arrive safely at your destination, the game will drop back to the main interface, centering on the party at the entrance point of the new location.
TAG_DESCRIPTION::::2: The following are ways that you can customize your characters within the game:~Character Generation~[TAG_CHARGEN][CMD_CHILDREN]
TAG_CHARGEN_PARTY_POOL:TAG_CHARGEN:::2: ~(shortcut to Help)~[TAG_ROOT]The character pool interface is used for the creation and organization of your party.  Once you create a character, the character may be added and listed on screen, with their portrait, name, and main information.There are four buttons lining the top portion of the interface: CREATE, VIEW, RENAME, and DELETE     CREATE will bring you to the character creation interface, where you will roll stats and choose your character's class, race, and other attributes.     VIEW will bring up the Inventory interface that holds information about a particular character (the basic defining traits like class and race, as well as their character stats, skills, feats, but not their spells).     RENAME will allow you to rename a character.     DELETE permanently erases the selected character from the pool.Toward the bottom of the interface is a button that will either read as ADD or REMOVE, depending on the appropriate action needed.  Once a new character is created and listed in the interface, you will need to select ADD in order for the character to actually be included in the party.  First, click on the desired character's portrait located in the row directly underneath the ADD button (the character will be highlighted in blue to indicate the selection), then click ADD.If the character's alignment or class does not conflict with the party alignment that was chosen, he or she will be added to the party and highlighted in green to indicate the successful addition.  If the character's alignment does conflict, then the character will be highlighted in red, indicating that it is not possible to add that character to the party.  Likewise, if there is a conflict regarding class and the alignment of the party (specifically, with Paladins, as they cannot be added to any parties with evil characters) then that character will not be added.If you would like to exclude a character from your party but not permanently delete them, click on their picture in the portrait row and select REMOVE.  The character will no longer be highlighted in green and is removed from the party, but he or she will still be listed among the party pool, if you wish to add him or her again at a later time.
TAG_CHARGEN_STATS:TAG_CHARGEN:TAG_CHARGE: The first part of character generation is assigning ability scores to the character ~abilities~[TAG_THE_ABILITIES]. By clicking on the ROLL button, six numbers will be generated by rolling four six-sided dice and eliminating the lowest single die roll. Additionally, scores with ability bonuses that total less than 0 or scores with no number greater than 13 will automatically be rerolled. If you are still unhappy with the outcome, the option is available to reroll as many times as you would like.You assign the scores to the ability by clicking and dragging the number to the box next to the ability name. Once all are done, you can reassign them, reroll them, or move on to race selection.
TAG_CHARGEN_STATS_POINT_BUY:TAG_CHARGEN:: In ~Normal~[TAG_NORMAL_GAME] mode, you can choose to buy your ability scores directly. Your character begins with all ~abilities~[TAG_THE_ABILITIES] at 8. You are given 25 points to spend on raising your abilities. Abilities cost 1 point to raise for each score up to 14, 2 points for scores 15 and 16, and 3 points for scores 17 and 18. Thus the total point cost for each ability score would be:Ability Score Total Point Cost9 110 211 312 413 514 615 816 1017 1318 16Point buying allows you to customize your character's scores, but random rolling will eventually generate better scores. The choice of methods is yours to make.
TAG_CHARGEN_RACE:TAG_CHARGEN:TAG_CHARGEN: Select a ~race~[TAG_RACES] for your character from among the list above. Selecting a race other than Human or Half-Elf will modify some of the character's abilities.
TAG_CHARGEN_GENDER:TAG_CHARGEN:TAG_CHARG: Your character must be either male or female. You make the choice.
TAG_CHARGEN_HEIGHT:TAG_CHARGEN:TAG_CHARG: Use the sliding bar to assign a height to your character based on his/her race. Although this will not affect the way the game is played, the appearance of your character will be scaled accordingly.
TAG_CHARGEN_HAIR:TAG_CHARGEN:::2: Choose a hair style from among the wigs above and then select a hair color from among the listed choices. Although hair choice will not affect game play, it will affect your character's appearance.
TAG_CHARGEN_CLASS:TAG_CHARGEN:TAG_CHARGE: Select a ~class~[TAG_CLASSES] for your character from among the choices listed. Note that some may not be available based upon your party alignment choice.
TAG_CHARGEN_ALIGNMENT:TAG_CHARGEN:TAG_CH: Choose an ~alignment~[TAG_ALIGNMENT] for your character based on the above choices. Some will not be available based upon your party alignment.
TAG_CHARGEN_DEITY:TAG_CHARGEN:TAG_CHARGE: Choose a ~deity~[TAG_RELIGION] for your character, or choose NONE. Note that if you select NONE, your character will never be able to take a level as a Cleric. Your deity choices are selected from among the racial, class, and alignment preferences of the various deities in the game.
TAG_CHARGEN_ABILITIES:TAG_CHARGEN:TAG_CH: Depending on your class, some feature choices may be available to you. If your character has no feature choices to make, move on to the feat selection screen.
TAG_CHARGEN_FEATS:TAG_CHARGEN:TAG_CHARGE: Scroll through the list of ~feats~[TAG_FEATS_DES] above. Feats that are available to you are highlighted in white. If your class is Fighter, you must also select a bonus feat from among the feats highlighted in gold. Humans also receive a second bonus feat. Note that some feats require other feats as prerequisites, so those must be selected first. Click and drag the feat selection to the appropriate box. If unhappy with the selection, click and drag a different feat over the top of the one you want to remove.
TAG_CHARGEN_SKILLS:TAG_CHARGEN:TAG_CHARG: Based upon your character's class and Intelligence modifier, you have a certain number of skill points to assign to your character. Scroll through the list of ~skills~[TAG_SKILL_DES] above until you find the skill you want to buy ranks in. Class skills are highlighted in white, while cross-class skills are gold. Class skills require one point to purchase one rank, while cross-class skills require two points to buy one rank. You may purchase half-ranks.
TAG_CHARGEN_SPELLS:TAG_CHARGEN:TAG_CHARG: If your character has ~spells~[TAG_SPELLS] as a class feature, you may select from among the list of spells above for your character. Click and drag the spell into the slot to the right. If you are unhappy with a spell selection, click and drag a different spell over the one you want to remove.
TAG_CHARGEN_PORTRAIT:TAG_CHARGEN:TAG_CHA: Select a portrait from the selections above to represent your character. The icon for this portrait will be used for selecting your character and to show initiative in combat.
TAG_CHARGEN_VOICE:TAG_CHARGEN:TAG_CHARGE: Type in a name for your character.Finally, select from a list of voice types for the one you feel will be appropriate for your character. Your character will use this voice to respond to you when given orders, during combats, or randomly throughout your adventure.
TAG_CHARGEN_CLERIC_DOMAIN_SELECTION:TAG_: In the process of creating a character who is a ~cleric~[TAG_CLERICS], you will be asked to select cleric ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] suitable for this character's ~alignment~[TAG_ALIGNMENT] and chosen ~deity~[TAG_RELIGION]. The domains selected will provide your cleric with domain powers and spells. In the cleric domain selection interface, the available domains will be listed on the left, with a space for multiple selections on the right. You will need to select and drag two domains into the space shown, which is a small box with the heading "Domains:".If the character is a neutral cleric who worships a neutral deity, additional information is needed, and a question will appear asking if your cleric character will be more proficient in wielding positive or negative energy. Only a neutral cleric of a neutral deity will be asked to provide this information. Click on the button that reads either "Positive" or "Negative" to make your decision.Once the player makes this choice, it cannot be reversed. This decision will determine whether the cleric will ~spontaneously cast~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_CLERIC_SPONTANEOUS_CASTING] Cure or Inflict spells and will also dictate whether the cleric ~turns or rebukes~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_CLERIC_TURN_REBUKE_UNDEAD] undead. In other words, a cleric who chooses to wield positive energy will spontaneously cast Cure spells and turn undead, while a cleric who decides to wield negative energy will spontaneously cast Inflict spells and rebuke undead.
TAG_CHARGEN_WIZARD_SPECIALIZATION:TAG_CH: A ~school~[TAG_MAGIC_SCHOOLS] is one of eight groupings of spells, each defined by a common theme, such as ~Illusion~[TAG_MAGIC_SCHOOLS_ILLUSION] or ~Necromancy~[TAG_MAGIC_SCHOOLS_NECROMANCY]. If desired, a ~wizard~[TAG_WIZARDS] may specialize in one school of magic. Specialization allows a wizard to cast extra spells from her chosen school, but then she never learns to cast spells from some other schools. Essentially, the wizard gains exceptional mastery over a single school by neglecting the study of other schools.A specialist wizard can prepare one additional spell of her specialty per school per spell level each day. She also gains a +2 bonus on ~Spellcraft~[TAG_SPELLCRAFT] checks to learn the spells of her chosen school.The wizard must choose whether to specialize and, if she does so, choose her specialty. At this time, she must also give up two other schools of magic which become her prohibited schools. In the character creation interface, under features, a wizard has the option of choosing such a school by selecting from the list entitled "Available Schools". You will drag this school into the box with the heading "Specialized School" and then choose two other schools to be dragged into the "Prohibited Schools" box that is outlined in red.An exception to the rules noted above is the school of ~Divination~[TAG_MAGIC_SCHOOLS_DIVINATION]. If Divination is chosen as the school that the wizard character will specialize in, then only one school must be selected for the "Prohibited Schools" box.
TAG_VITALS:TAG_DESCRIPTION:::2: Name: Invent or choose a name that fits your character's race and class.Gender: You character can be either male or female.Looks: You will have the option of selecting a hair style and hair color for your character, as well as a character portrait.~Height~[TAG_HEIGHT]~Weight~[TAG_WEIGHT]~Hit Points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS]
TAG_HIT_POINTS:TAG_VITALS:::2: A measure of a character's health or an object's integrity. Damage decreases current hit points and lost hit points return with healing or natural recovery. A character's hit point total increases permanently with additional ~experience~[TAG_EXPERIENCE_AND_LEVELS] and/or permanent increases in ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION], or temporarily through the use of various special abilities, spells, ~magic items~[TAG_MAGIC_ITEMS], or magical effects (see ~temporary hit points~[TAG_TEMPORARY_HIT_POINTS]). The more hit points a character has, the more difficult he is to kill.At 0 hit points, he is ~disabled~[TAG_DISABLED].At -1 to -9 hit points, he is ~dying~[TAG_DYING].At -10 (or lower), he is ~dead~[TAG_DEAD].
TAG_HEIGHT:TAG_VITALS:::2: The height of your character simply provides a more accurate visual representation within the game. For example, if your character is a ~halfling~[TAG_HALFLINGS], he or she will appear significantly shorter than the rest of the party. Other than this, height has no other affect upon anything in the game.
TAG_WEIGHT:TAG_VITALS:::2: The weight of your character has no affect upon anything in the game. You decide the weight of your character when you choose the height; it is scaled to match height.
TAG_LAWFUL_GOOD:TAG_ALIGNMENT:::2: A Lawful Good character acts as a good person is expected or required to act.  She combines a commitment to oppose evil with the discipline to fight relentlessly.  She tells the truth, keeps her word, helps those in need, and speaks out against injustice.  A Lawful Good character hates to see the guilty go unpunished. Lawful Good can be a positive alignment because it combines honor and compassion.
TAG_NEUTRAL_GOOD:TAG_ALIGNMENT:::2: A Neutral Good character does the best that a good person can do.  He is devoted to helping others.  He works best with kings and magistrates but does not feel beholden to them.  For example, a ~cleric~[TAG_CLERICS] who helps others according to their needs is Neutral Good. Neutral Good is an advantageous alignment because it means doing what is good without bias for or against order.
TAG_CHAOTIC_GOOD:TAG_ALIGNMENT:::2: A Chaotic Good character acts as his conscience directs him with little regard for what others expect of him.  He makes his own way, but he's kind and benevolent.  He believes in goodness and right but has little use for laws and regulations.  He hates it when people try to intimidate others and tell them what to do.  He follows his own moral compass, which although good, may not agree with that of society.  For example, a ~ranger~[TAG_RANGERS] who waylays the evil baron's tax collectors is Chaotic Good. Chaotic Good is favored by some because it combines a good heart with a free spirit.
TAG_LAWFUL_NEUTRAL:TAG_ALIGNMENT:::2: A Lawful Neutral character acts as law, tradition, or a personal code directs her.  Order and organization are paramount to her.  She may believe in personal order and live by a code or standard, or she may believe in order for all and favor a strong, organized government.  For example, a ~monk~[TAG_MONKS] who follows her discipline without being swayed either by the demands of those in need or by the temptations of evil, is Lawful Neutral. Lawful Neutral is considered a good alignment because it means you are reliable and honorable without being a zealot.
TAG_NEUTRAL:TAG_ALIGNMENT:::2: A True Neutral character does what seems to be a good idea.  He doesn't feel strongly one way or the other when it comes to good vs. evil or law vs. chaos.  Most True Neutral characters exhibit a lack of conviction or bias rather than commitment to neutrality.  Such a character thinks of good as better than evil--after all, he would rather have good neighbors and rulers than evil ones.  Still, he's not personally committed to upholding good in any abstract or universal way.  For example, a ~wizard~[TAG_WIZARDS] who devotes himself to his art and is bored by the semantics of moral debate is True Neutral. Some True Neutral characters, on the other hand, commit themselves philosophically to neutrality.  They see good, evil, law, and chaos as prejudices and dangerous extremes.  They advocate the middle way of neutrality as the best, most balanced road in the long run. True Neutral is an alignment favored because it means you can act naturally, without prejudice or compulsion.
TAG_CHAOTIC_NEUTRAL:TAG_ALIGNMENT:::2: A Chaotic Neutral character follows her whims.  She is an individualist first and foremost.  She values her own liberty but doesn't strive to protect others' freedom.  She avoids authority, resents restrictions, and challenges traditions.  A Chaotic Neutral character does not intentionally disrupt organizations as part of a campaign of anarchy.  To do so, she would have to be motivated either by good (and a desire to liberate others) or evil (and a desire to make those different from herself suffer).  A Chaotic Neutral character may be unpredictable, but her behavior is not totally random.  She is not as likely to jump off a bridge as to cross it.  For example, a ~bard~[TAG_BARDS] who wanders the land living by his wits is Chaotic Neutral. Chaotic Neutral is thought of as the best alignment by some because it represents true freedom from both society's restrictions and a do-gooder's zeal.
TAG_LAWFUL_EVIL:TAG_ALIGNMENT:::2: A Lawful Evil character methodically takes what he wants within the limits of his code of conduct without regard for whom it hurts.  He cares about tradition, loyalty, and order, but not about freedom, dignity, or life.  He plays by the rules but without mercy or compassion.  He is comfortable in a hierarchy and would like to rule, but is willing to serve.  He condemns others not according to their actions but according to race, religion, homeland, or social rank.  He is loath to break laws or promises.  This reluctance comes partly from his nature and partly because he depends on order to protect himself from those who oppose him on moral grounds.  Some Lawful Evil villains have particular taboos, such as not killing in cold blood (but having underlings do it) or not letting children come to harm (if it can be helped).  They imagine that these compunctions put them above unprincipled villains.  The scheming baron who expands his power and exploits his people is Lawful Evil. Some Lawful Evil people and creatures commit themselves to evil with a zeal like that of a crusader committed to good.  Beyond being willing to hurt others for their own ends, they take pleasure in spreading evil as an end unto itself.  They may also see doing evil as part of a duty to an evil deity or master. Lawful Evil is sometimes called "diabolical" because devils are the epitome of this alignment. Lawful Evil is a dangerous alignment because is represents methodical, intentional, and frequently successful evil.
TAG_NEUTRAL_EVIL:TAG_ALIGNMENT:::2: A Neutral Evil character does whatever she can get away with.  She is out for herself, pure and simple.  She sheds no tears for those she kills, whether for profit, sport, or convenience.  She has no love of order and holds no illusion that following laws, traditions, or codes would make her any better or more noble.  On the other hand, she doesn't have the reckless nature or love of conflict that a Chaotic Evil villain has.  The criminal who robs and murders to get what she wants is Neutral Evil. Some Neutral Evil villains hold up evil as an ideal, committing evil for its own sake.  Most often, such villains are devoted to evil deities or secret societies. Neutral Evil is considered to be a dangerous alignment because it represents pure evil without honor and without variation.
TAG_CHAOTIC_EVIL:TAG_ALIGNMENT:::2: A Chaotic Evil character does whatever his greed, hatred, and lust for destruction drive him to do.  He is hot-tempered, vicious, arbitrarily violent, and unpredictable.  If he is simply out for whatever he can get, he is ruthless and brutal.  If he is committed to the spread of evil and chaos, he is even worse.  Thankfully, his plans are haphazard, and any groups he joins or forms are poorly organized.  Typically, Chaotic Evil people can be made to work together only by force, and their leader lasts only as long as he can thwart attempts to topple or assassinate him.  The demented ~sorcerer~[TAG_SORCERERS] pursuing mad schemes of vengeance and havoc is Chaotic Evil. Chaotic Evil is sometimes called "demonic" because demons are the epitome of this particular alignment. Chaotic Evil is thought of as dangerous because it represents the destruction not only of beauty and life but also of the order on which beauty and life depend.
TAG_RELIGION:TAG_DESCRIPTION:::2: You may select a patron deity for your character.  Alternatively, you may choose to have your character not have a patron deity.  However, if you choose to select NONE as your character's deity, he/she cannot be a ~cleric~[TAG_CLERICS], nor will he/she ever be able to take a level of cleric as a ~multi-class~[TAG_MULTICLASS]. Deities are restricted by race, class, and alignment.  On the deity selection screen, only those deities appropriate for your character's race, class, and alignment will be available.Available deities are as follows:[CMD_CHILDREN]
TAG_BOCCOB:TAG_RELIGION:::2: The god of magic, Boccob (bock-obb) is ~True Neutral~[TAG_NEUTRAL].  His titles include "the Uncaring", "Lord of All Magics", and "Archmage of the Deities".  Boccob is a distant deity who promotes no special agenda in the world of mortals. As a god of magic and knowledge, he is worshipped by ~wizards~[TAG_WIZARDS], ~sorcerers~[TAG_SORCERERS], and sages. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Knowledge~[TAG_KNOWLEDGE_D], ~Domain: Magic~[TAG_MAGIC_D], and ~Domain: Trickery~[TAG_TRICKERY_D]. The ~quarterstaff~[TAG_WEAPONS_QUARTERSTAFF] is his favored weapon.  It is known as the "Staff of Boccob".
TAG_CORELLON:TAG_RELIGION:::2: The god of the ~elves~[TAG_ELVES], Corellon Larethian (Core-eh-lon Lah-reth-ee-yen), is ~Chaotic Good~[TAG_CHAOTIC_GOOD].  He is known as "the Creator of the Elves", "the Protector", "Protector and Preserver of Life", and "Ruler of All Elves".  Corellon Larethian is the creator and protector of the elf race.  He governs those things held in highest esteem among elves, such as magic, music, arts, crafts, poetry, and warfare.  ~Gruumsh~[TAG_GRUUMSH] is his nemesis, and it is because of Corellon's battle prowess that Gruumsh is called "One-Eye". Elves, ~half-elves~[TAG_HALF_ELVES], and ~bards~[TAG_BARDS] worship him. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] that Corellon Larethian is associated with are ~Domain: Chaos~[TAG_CHAOS_D], ~Domain: Good~[TAG_GOOD_DOMAIN], ~Domain: Protection~[TAG_PROTECTION_D], and ~Domain: War~[TAG_WAR_D]. His favored weapon is the ~longsword~[TAG_WEAPONS_LONGSWORD], which is named "Sahandrian".
TAG_EHLONNA:TAG_RELIGION:::2: Ehlonna (eh-loan-nuh), the goddess of the woodlands, is ~Neutral Good~[TAG_NEUTRAL_GOOD].  Her most commonly encountered title is "Ehlonna of the Forests".  Ehlonna watches over all good people who live in the forest, love the woodlands, or make their livelihood there.  She is pictured sometimes as an ~elf~[TAG_ELVES] and sometimes as a ~human~[TAG_HUMANS]. She is especially close to elves, ~gnomes~[TAG_GNOMES], ~half-elves~[TAG_HALF_ELVES], and ~halflings~[TAG_HALFLINGS].   She is also worshiped by ~rangers~[TAG_RANGERS] and some ~druids~[TAG_DRUIDS]. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] she is associated with are ~Domain: Animal~[TAG_ANIMAL_D], ~Domain: Good~[TAG_GOOD_DOMAIN], ~Domain: Plant~[TAG_PLANT_D], and ~Domain: Sun~[TAG_SUN_D]. Her favored weapon is the ~longbow~[TAG_WEAPONS_LONGBOW], referred to as "Jenevier".
TAG_ERYTHNUL:TAG_RELIGION:::2: The god of slaughter, Erythnul (eh-rith-null), is ~Chaotic Evil~[TAG_CHAOTIC_EVIL].  His title is "the Many".  Erythnul delights in panic and slaughter.  In savage lands, evil ~barbarians~[TAG_BARBARIANS], gnolls, bugbears, ogres, and trolls commonly worship him. In civilized lands, his followers (including evil ~fighters~[TAG_FIGHTERS], barbarians, and ~rogues~[TAG_ROGUES]) form small criminal cults. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Chaos~[TAG_CHAOS_D], ~Domain: Evil~[TAG_EVIL_D], ~Domain: Trickery~[TAG_TRICKERY_D], and ~Domain: War~[TAG_WAR_D]. His favored weapon is a ~morningstar~[TAG_WEAPONS_MORNINGSTAR] with a blunt stone head, appropriately named "Agony".
TAG_FHARLANGHN:TAG_RELIGION:::2: Fharlanghn (far-lahng-un), the god of roads, is ~True Neutral~[TAG_NEUTRAL].  His title is "Dweller on the Horizon".  Fharlanghn's wayside shrines are common on well-used roads, for he is the deity of travel, roads, distance, and horizons. ~Bards~[TAG_BARDS], other wandering adventurers, and merchants favor Fharlanghn. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Luck~[TAG_LUCK_D], ~Domain: Protection~[TAG_PROTECTION_D], and ~Domain: Travel~[TAG_TRAVEL_D]. The ~quarterstaff~[TAG_WEAPONS_QUARTERSTAFF] is his favored weapon, known as "Traveler's Friend".
TAG_GARL:TAG_RELIGION:::2: The god of the ~gnomes~[TAG_GNOMES], Garl Glittergold (garl gliht-er-gold), is ~Neutral Good~[TAG_NEUTRAL_GOOD].  He is known as "the Joker", "the Watchful Protector", "the Priceless Gem", and "the Sparkling Wit".  Garl Glittergold discovered the gnomes and led them into the world.  Since then, he has been their protector.  He governs humor, wit, gemcutting, and jewelrymaking.  Garl is renowned for the jokes and pranks he pulls on other deities, though not all his victims laugh off his jests.  He once collapsed the cavern of Kurtulmak, the god of the kobolds.  Since then, the two deities have been sworn enemies. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Good~[TAG_GOOD_DOMAIN], ~Domain: Protection~[TAG_PROTECTION_D], and ~Domain: Trickery~[TAG_TRICKERY_D]. Garl's favored weapon is the ~battleaxe~[TAG_WEAPONS_BATTLEAXE], which holds the title of "Arumdina".
TAG_GRUUMSH:TAG_RELIGION:::2: Gruumsh (groomsh), the chief god of the orcs, is ~Chaotic Evil~[TAG_CHAOTIC_EVIL].  His titles are "One-Eye" and "He-Who-Never-Sleeps".  Gruumsh calls on his followers to be strong, to cull the weak from their numbers, and to take all the territory that Gruumsh thinks is rightfully theirs (which is almost everything).  He harbors a special hatred for ~Corellon Larethian~[TAG_CORELLON], ~Moradin~[TAG_MORADIN], and their followers.  In ages past, Corellon Larethian put out Gruumsh's left eye in a fight. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Chaos~[TAG_CHAOS_D], ~Domain: Evil~[TAG_EVIL_D], ~Domain: Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH_D], and ~Domain: War~[TAG_WAR_D]. Gruumsh's favored weapon is the ~spear~[TAG_WEAPONS_SPEAR], which has been personally named "Bloodspear".
TAG_HEIRONEOUS:TAG_RELIGION:::2: The god of valor, Heironeous (high-roe-nee-us), is ~Lawful Good~[TAG_LAWFUL_GOOD].  His title is "the Invincible".  Heironeous promotes justice, valor, chivalry, and honor.  His arch-enemy is ~Hextor~[TAG_HEXTOR], his half-brother. He is worshiped by ~paladins~[TAG_PALADINS], good ~fighters~[TAG_FIGHTERS], and good ~monks~[TAG_MONKS]. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Good~[TAG_GOOD_DOMAIN], ~Domain: Law~[TAG_LAW_D], and ~Domain: War~[TAG_WAR_D]. His favored weapon is the ~longsword~[TAG_WEAPONS_LONGSWORD], and is often known as "Justice-bringer".
TAG_HEXTOR:TAG_RELIGION:::2: The god of tyranny, Hextor (heks-tore), is ~Lawful Evil~[TAG_LAWFUL_EVIL].  His titles are "Champion of Evil", "Herald of Hell", and "Scourge of Battle".  Hextor is the six-armed god of war, conflict, and destruction.  He sends his followers to commit evil, and their special purpose is to overthrow the followers of his half-brother ~Heironeous~[TAG_HEIRONEOUS] wherever they are found. Hextor's worshipers include evil ~fighters~[TAG_FIGHTERS] and ~monks~[TAG_MONKS]. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Destruction~[TAG_DESTRUCTION_D], ~Domain: Evil~[TAG_EVIL_D], ~Domain: Law~[TAG_LAW_D], and ~Domain: War~[TAG_WAR_D]. His favored weapon is the ~flail~[TAG_WEAPONS_FLAIL] that has been called "Pain's Memory".
TAG_KORD:TAG_RELIGION:::2: Kord, the god of strength, is ~Chaotic Good~[TAG_CHAOTIC_GOOD].  He is known as "the Brawler".  Kord is the patron of athletes, especially wrestlers. His worshipers include good ~fighters~[TAG_FIGHTERS], ~barbarians~[TAG_BARBARIANS], and ~rogues~[TAG_ROGUES]. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Chaos~[TAG_CHAOS_D], ~Domain: Good~[TAG_GOOD_DOMAIN], ~Domain: Luck~[TAG_LUCK_D], and ~Domain: Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH_D]. Kord's favored weapon is the ~greatsword~[TAG_WEAPONS_GREATSWORD] known as "Kelmar".
TAG_MORADIN:TAG_RELIGION:::2: The god of ~dwarves~[TAG_DWARVES], Moradin (more-uh-din), is ~Lawful Good~[TAG_LAWFUL_GOOD].  His titles include "the Soul Forger", "Dwarffather", "the All-Father", and "the Creator".  Moradin forged the first dwarves out of metal and gems and breathed life into them.
