He governs the arts and sciences of the dwarves: smithing, metalworking, ~engineering~[TAG_STONECUNNING], and war The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Earth~[TAG_EARTH_D], ~Domain: Good~[TAG_GOOD_DOMAIN], ~Domain: Law~[TAG_LAW_D], and ~Domain: Protection~[TAG_PROTECTION_D]. His favored weapon is the ~warhammer~[TAG_WEAPONS_WARHAMMER] known as "~Soulhammer~[TAG_WEAPONS_MORADIN'S_SOUL_HAMMER]".
TAG_NERULL:TAG_RELIGION:::2: The god of death, Nerull (nare-ul), is ~Neutral Evil~[TAG_NEUTRAL_EVIL].  He is known as "the Reaper", "the Foe of All Good", "Hater of Life", "Bringer of Darkness", "King of All Gloom", and "Reaper of Flesh".  Nerull is the patron of those who seek the greatest evil for their own enjoyment or gain. His worshipers, who include evil necromancers and ~rogues~[TAG_ROGUES], depict him as an almost skeletal cloaked figure. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Death~[TAG_DEATH_D], ~Domain: Evil~[TAG_EVIL_D], and ~Domain: Trickery~[TAG_TRICKERY_D]. Nerull bears a ~scythe~[TAG_WEAPONS_SCYTHE], his favored weapon, referred to as "Lifecutter".
TAG_OBAD_HAI:TAG_RELIGION:::2: Obad-Hai (oh-bod-high), the god of nature, is ~True Neutral~[TAG_NEUTRAL].  He is known as "the Shalm".  Obad-Hai rules the wilderness, and he is a friend to all who live in harmony with the natural world.  Because Obad-Hai strictly adheres to neutrality, he is a rival of ~Ehlonna~[TAG_EHLONNA].  Obad-Hai plays a shalm (a double-reed woodwind instrument, also spelled "shawm") and takes his title from this instrument. ~Barbarians~[TAG_BARBARIANS], ~rangers~[TAG_RANGERS], and ~druids~[TAG_DRUIDS] sometimes worship him. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Air~[TAG_AIR_D], ~Domain: Animal~[TAG_ANIMAL_D], ~Domain: Earth~[TAG_EARTH_D], ~Domain: Fire~[TAG_FIRE_D], ~Domain: Plant~[TAG_PLANT_D], and ~Domain: Water~[TAG_WATER_D]. His favored weapon is the ~quarterstaff~[TAG_WEAPONS_QUARTERSTAFF] known as "Stormstouch".
TAG_OLIDAMMARA:TAG_RELIGION:::2: The god of ~rogues~[TAG_ROGUES], Olidammara (oh-lih-duh-mar-uh), is ~Chaotic Neutral~[TAG_CHAOTIC_NEUTRAL].  His title is "the Laughing Rogue".  Olidammara delights in wine, women, and song.  He is a vagabond, a prankster, and a master of disguise.  His temples are few, but many people are willing to raise a glass in his honor. Rogues and ~bards~[TAG_BARDS] are frequently among his worshipers. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Chaos~[TAG_CHAOS_D], ~Domain: Luck~[TAG_LUCK_D], and ~Domain: Trickery~[TAG_TRICKERY_D]. The ~rapier~[TAG_WEAPONS_RAPIER] is his favored weapon and is named "Swiftstrike".
TAG_PELOR:TAG_RELIGION:::2: Pelor (pay-lore), the god of the sun, is ~Neutral Good~[TAG_NEUTRAL_GOOD].  His title is "the Shining One".  Pelor is the creator of many good things, a supporter of those in need, and an adversary of all that is evil.  He is the most commonly worshiped deity among ordinary ~humans~[TAG_HUMANS], and his priests are well received wherever they go. ~Rangers~[TAG_RANGERS] and ~bards~[TAG_BARDS] are found among his worshipers. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Good~[TAG_GOOD_DOMAIN], ~Domain: Healing~[TAG_HEALING_D], ~Domain: Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH_D], and ~Domain: Sun~[TAG_SUN_D]. The ~mace~[TAG_WEAPONS_MACE_HEAVY_LIGHT] is his favored weapon and it is aptly named the "Sunscepter".
TAG_CUTHBERT:TAG_RELIGION:::2: The god of retribution, St. Cuthbert (saint cuhth-burt), is ~Lawful Neutral~[TAG_LAWFUL_NEUTRAL].  He is known as "St. Cuthbert of the Cudgel".  St. Cuthbert exacts revenge and just punishment on those who transgress the law.  Because evil creatures more commonly and flagrantly violate laws than good creatures do, St. Cuthbert favors good over evil, though he is not good himself.  (His ~clerics~[TAG_CLERICS] cannot be evil.) The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Destruction~[TAG_DESTRUCTION_D], ~Domain: Law~[TAG_LAW_D], ~Domain: Protection~[TAG_PROTECTION_D], and ~Domain: Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH_D]. His favored weapon is the ~mace~[TAG_WEAPONS_MACE_HEAVY_LIGHT] known as "The Mace of Cuthbert".
TAG_VECNA:TAG_RELIGION:::2: Vecna (veck-nuh), the god of secrets, is ~Neutral Evil~[TAG_NEUTRAL_EVIL].  He is known as "the Maimed Lord", "the Whispered One", and "the Master of All That is Secret and Hidden".  Vecna rules that which is not meant to be known and that which people wish to keep secret.  He usually appears as a lich who is missing his left hand and left eye.  He lost his hand and eye in a fight with his traitorous lieutenant, Kas. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] he is associated with are ~Domain: Evil~[TAG_EVIL_D], ~Domain: Knowledge~[TAG_KNOWLEDGE_D], and ~Domain: Magic~[TAG_MAGIC_D]. Vecna's favored weapon is the ~dagger~[TAG_WEAPONS_DAGGER] called "Afterthought".
TAG_WEE_JAS:TAG_RELIGION:::2: Wee Jas (wee jass), the goddess of death and magic, is ~Lawful Neutral~[TAG_LAWFUL_NEUTRAL].  Her titles are "Witch Goddess", "Ruby Sorceress", "Stern Lady", and "Death's Guardian".  Wee Jas is a demanding goddess who expects obedience from her followers. Her temples are few and far between, but she counts many powerful ~sorcerers~[TAG_SORCERERS] and ~wizards~[TAG_WIZARDS] (especially necromancers) among her worshipers. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] she is associated with are ~Domain: Death~[TAG_DEATH_D], ~Domain: Law~[TAG_LAW_D], and ~Domain: Magic~[TAG_MAGIC_D]. Her favored weapon is the ~dagger~[TAG_WEAPONS_DAGGER], named by her as "Discretion".
TAG_YONDALLA:TAG_RELIGION:::2: The goddess of the ~halflings~[TAG_HALFLINGS], Yondalla (yon-dah-lah), is ~Lawful Good~[TAG_LAWFUL_GOOD].  Her titles include "the Protector and Provider", "the Nurturing Matriarch", and "the Blessed One".  Yondalla is the creator and protector of the halfling race.  She espouses harmony among halflings and stalwart defense against their enemies.  Her followers hope to lead safe, prosperous lives by following her guidance. The ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] she is associated with are ~Domain: Good~[TAG_GOOD_DOMAIN], ~Domain: Law~[TAG_LAW_D], and ~Domain: Protection~[TAG_PROTECTION_D]. The ~short sword~[TAG_WEAPONS_SWORD_SHORT] is her favored weapon and is named "Hornblade".
TAG_NO_GOD:TAG_RELIGION:::2: Your character has no patron deity and has no particular religion or religious beliefs. Note that this option is not available for ~clerics~[TAG_CLERICS], and a character with no deity will never be able to select a level of cleric as a ~multi-class~[TAG_MULTICLASS].
TAG_ABILITY_SCORES:TAG_ABILITIES:::2: Ability scores are created by rolling four six-sided dice. For each of the six ~abilities~[TAG_THE_ABILITIES] roll the four dice, disregarding the lowest die roll and totaling the three highest ones. The result is a number between 3 (horrible) and 18 (tremendous). The average ability score for a typical commoner is 10 or 11, but your characters are not typical.Your rolls will be displayed on screen. If you are unhappy with them, you have the option of rolling again (not in the ~Ironman Mode~[TAG_IRONMAN] however) until you are satisfied with them. You then will need to assign the six die rolls to that character's abilities.After each assigned die roll, the ~ability modifier~[TAG_ABILITY_MODIFIERS] will be displayed.Finally, it is important for spellcasters to know which ability governs bonus spells for their particular type of magic.     ~Wizards~[TAG_WIZARDS] use ~intelligence~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE].     ~Clerics~[TAG_CLERICS], ~druids~[TAG_DRUIDS], ~paladins~[TAG_PALADINS], and ~rangers~[TAG_RANGERS] use ~wisdom~[TAG_WISDOM].     ~Sorcerers~[TAG_SORCERERS] and ~bards~[TAG_BARDS] use ~charisma~[TAG_CHARISMA].If the spellcaster's abilitiy score is 10 or lower, you will not be able to cast spells tied to that ability.
TAG_CHANGE_ABILITY_SCORES:TAG_ABILITIES:: Over time, the ability scores your character starts with can change. Ability scores can increase with no limit. Points at which ability changes occur include the following:-- Add 1 point to any score at 4th level and at every fourth level your character attains (4th, 8th, 12th, 16th, and 20th levels).-- Many spells and magical effects temporarily increase or decrease ability scores. -- Several magical items improve ability scores as long as the character is using them. -- Some rare magical items can boost an ability score permanently. Such an increase is called an inherent bonus. An ability score cannot have an inherent bonus of more than +5.-- ~Poisons~[TAG_POISON], ~diseases~[TAG_DISEASED], and other effects can temporarily harm an ability. Ability points lost to damage return on their own at a rate of 1 point per day for each damaged ability.-- Some effects drain abilities, resulting in a permanent loss. Points lost this way don't return on their own, but they can be regained with spells.Note that when an ability score changes, all attributes associated with that score change accordingly, including the ~ability modifier~[TAG_ABILITY_MODIFIERS].
TAG_STRENGTH:TAG_THE_ABILITIES:::2: Strength measures your character's muscle and physical power. This ability is especially important for ~fighters~[TAG_FIGHTERS], ~barbarians~[TAG_BARBARIANS], ~paladins~[TAG_PALADINS], ~rangers~[TAG_RANGERS], and ~monks~[TAG_MONKS] because it helps them prevail in combat. Strength also limits the amount of ~equipment~[TAG_EQUIPMENT] your characters can carry.You apply your character's Strength modifier to:-- Melee ~attack rolls~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL]-- Damage rolls when using a melee weapon or a ~thrown weapon~[TAG_THROW_WEAPON]-- Strength checks (for breaking down doors and the like).
TAG_DEXTERITY:TAG_THE_ABILITIES:::2: Dexterity measures hand-eye coordination, agility, reflexes, and balance. This ability is the most important one for ~rogues~[TAG_ROGUES], but it is also high on the list for characters who typically wear light or medium armor (~rangers~[TAG_RANGERS] or ~barbarians~[TAG_BARBARIANS]) or no armor at all (~monks~[TAG_MONKS], ~wizards~[TAG_WIZARDS], or ~sorcerers~[TAG_SORCERERS]), and for anyone who wants to be a skilled archer.You apply your character's Dexterity modifier to:-- Ranged ~attack rolls~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL], including those for attacks made with crossbows (~light~[TAG_WEAPONS_CROSSBOW_LIGHT] or ~heavy~[TAG_WEAPONS_CROSSBOW_HEAVY]) and other ranged weapons-- ~Armor Class~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] (AC), provided that the character can react to the attack.-- ~Reflex~[TAG_REFLEX] ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC] for avoiding ~Fireballs~[TAG_SPELLS_FIREBALL] and other attacks that you can escape by moving quickly-- ~Hide~[TAG_HIDE], ~Move Silently~[TAG_MOVE_SILENTLY], ~Open Lock~[TAG_OPEN_LOCK], and ~Sleight of Hand~[TAG_SLEIGHT]. These are the ~skills~[TAG_SKILLS] that have Dexterity as their key ability.
TAG_CONSTITUTION:TAG_THE_ABILITIES:::2: Constitution represents your character's health and stamina. A Constitution bonus increases a character's ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS], so the ability is important for all classes.You apply your character's Constitution modifier to:-- Each roll of a Hit Die (though a die roll can never drop below 1 due to a penalty)-- ~Fortitude~[TAG_FORTITUDE] ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC] for resisting ~poison~[TAG_POISON] and similar threats-- ~Concentration~[TAG_CONCENTRATION] checks. Concentration is a ~skill~[TAG_SKILLS], important to spellcasters, that has Constitution as its key ability.If a character's Constitution score changes enough to alter his or her Constitution modifier, the character's hit points also increase or decrease accordingly.
TAG_INTELLIGENCE:TAG_THE_ABILITIES:::2: Intelligence determines how well your character learns and reasons. This ability is important for ~wizards~[TAG_WIZARDS] because it affects how many spells they can cast, how hard their spells are to resist, and how powerful their spells can be. It's also important for any character who wants to have a wide assortment of skills.You apply your character's Intelligence modifier to:-- The number of ~skill points~[TAG_ACQUIRE_SKILLS] gained each level. (But your characters always get at least 1 skill point per level.)-- ~Appraise~[TAG_APPRAISE], ~Disable Device~[TAG_DISABLE_DEVICE], ~Search~[TAG_SEARCH], and ~Spellcraft~[TAG_SPELLCRAFT] checks. These are the ~skills~[TAG_SKILLS] that have Intelligence as their key ability.A wizard gains bonus spells based on her Intelligence score. The minimum Intelligence score needed to cast a wizard spell is 10 + the spell's level.An animal has an Intelligence score of 1 or 2. A creature of humanlike intelligence has a score of at least 3.
TAG_WISDOM:TAG_THE_ABILITIES:::2: Wisdom describes a character's willpower, common sense, perception, and intuition. While ~Intelligence~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] represents one's ability to analyze information, Wisdom represents being in tune with and aware of one's surroundings. An "absentminded professor" has low Wisdom and high Intelligence. A simpleton (low Intelligence) might still have great insight (high Wisdom). Wisdom is the most important ability for ~clerics~[TAG_CLERICS] and ~druids~[TAG_DRUIDS], and it is also important for ~paladins~[TAG_PALADINS] and ~rangers~[TAG_RANGERS]. If you want your character to have acute senses, put a high score in Wisdom. Every creature has a Wisdom score.You apply your character's Wisdom modifier to:-- ~Will~[TAG_WILL] ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC] for negating the effects of ~Charm Person~[TAG_SPELLS_CHARM_PERSON] and other spells-- ~Heal~[TAG_HEAL], ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN], ~Sense Motive~[TAG_SENSE_MOTIVE], ~Spot~[TAG_SPOT], and ~Survival~[TAG_SURVIVAL] checks. These are the ~skills~[TAG_SKILLS] that have Wisdom as their key ability.Clerics, druids, paladins, and rangers get bonus spells based on their Wisdom scores. The minimum Wisdom score needed to cast a cleric, druid, paladin, or ranger spell is 10 + the spell's level.
TAG_CHARISMA:TAG_THE_ABILITIES:::2: Charisma measures a character's force of personality, persuasiveness, personal magnetism, ability to lead, and physical attractiveness. This ability represents actual strength of personality, not merely how one is perceived by others in a social setting. Charisma is most important for ~paladins~[TAG_PALADINS], ~sorcerers~[TAG_SORCERERS], and ~bards~[TAG_BARDS]. It is also important for ~clerics~[TAG_CLERICS], since it affects their ability to ~turn or rebuke~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_CLERIC_TURN_REBUKE_UNDEAD] undead. Every creature has a Charisma score.You apply your character's Charisma modifier to:-- ~Bluff~[TAG_BLUFF], ~Diplomacy~[TAG_DIPLOMACY], ~Gather Information~[TAG_GATHER_INFORMATION], ~Intimidate~[TAG_INTIMIDATE], ~Perform~[TAG_PERFORM], and ~Use Magic Device~[TAG_UMD] checks. These are the ~skills~[TAG_SKILLS] that have Charisma as their key ability.-- Checks that represent attempts to influence others.-- Turning checks for clerics and paladins attempting to turn zombies, skeletons, and other undead.Sorcerers and bards get bonus spells based on their Charisma scores. The minimum Charisma score needed to cast a sorcerer or bard spell is 10 + the spell's level.
TAG_ABILITY_MODIFIERS :TAG_ABILITY_SCOR: Each ability, after changes made because of ~race~[TAG_RACES], has a modifier ranging from -5 to +5. The modifier is the number you apply to the die rolls when your character tries to do something related to that ability.Ability Score        Modifier---------------       ----------    1                           @t-5    2-3                       @t-4    4-5                       @t-3     6-7                       @t-2    8-9                       @t-1    10-11                   @t 0    12-13                  @t+1    14-15                  @t+2    16-17                  @t+3    18-19                  @t+4    20-21                  @t+5
TAG_RACIAL_CHARACTERISTICS:TAG_RACES:::2: Your character's race determines some of his or her qualities.Depending on what race you choose, your character's abilities may be modified by ability adjustments. Each race has a favored class, which comes into play for characters choosing to ~multiclass~[TAG_MULTICLASS].
TAG_HUMANS:TAG_RACES:::2: Most humans are the descendants of pioneers, conquerors, traders, travelers, refugees, and other people on the move. As a result, human lands are home to a mix of people--physically, culturally, religiously, and politically different. Hardy or fine, light-skinned or dark, showy or austere, primitive or civilized, devout or impious, humans run the gamut.Physical Description: Humans typically stand from 5 feet to a little over 6 feet tall and weigh from 125 to 250 pounds, with men noticeably taller and heavier than women. Humans have short life spans, reaching adulthood at about age 15 and rarely living even a single century.Alignment: Humans tend toward no particular alignment, not even neutrality. The best and the worst are found among them.Religion: Unlike members of the other common races, humans do not have a chief racial deity. ~Pelor~[TAG_PELOR], the sun god, is the most commonly worshiped deity in human lands, but he can claim nothing like the central place that the ~dwarves~[TAG_DWARVES] give ~Moradin~[TAG_MORADIN] or the ~elves~[TAG_ELVES] give ~Corellon Larethian~[TAG_CORELLON] in their respective pantheons. Racial Traits:-- Medium: As Medium creatures, humans have no special bonuses or penalties due to their size.-- Human base land speed is 30 feet.-- 1 extra ~feat~[TAG_FEATS] at 1st level.-- 4 extra ~skill points~[TAG_ACQUIRE_SKILLS] at 1st level and 1 extra skill point at each additional level.-- Favored Class: Any. When determining whether a multiclass human takes an experience point penalty, her highest-level class does not count.
TAG_DWARVES:TAG_RACES:::2: Dwarves are known for their skill in warfare, their ability to withstand physical and magical punishments, their knowledge of the earth's secrets, their hard work, and their capacity for drinking ale. Their mysterious kingdoms, carved from the insides of mountains, are renowned for the marvelous treasures that they produce as gifts for trade.Physical Description: Dwarves stand only 4 to 4 1/2 feet tall, but they are so broad and compact that they are, on average, almost as heavy as ~humans~[TAG_HUMANS]. Dwarf men are slightly taller and noticeably heavier than dwarf women. Dwarf men value their beards and groom them very carefully. Dwarves are considered adults at about age 40, and they can live to be more than 400 years old.Alignment: Dwarves are usually lawful, and they tend toward good. Adventuring dwarves are less likely to fit the common mold, however, since they're more likely to be those who didn't fit perfectly into dwarven society.Religion: The chief deity of the dwarves is ~Moradin~[TAG_MORADIN], "the Soul Forger". He is the creator of the dwarves, and he expects his followers to work for the betterment of the dwarf race.Racial Traits:-- +2 ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION], -2 ~Charisma~[TAG_CHARISMA]-- Medium: As Medium creatures, dwarves have no special bonuses or penalties due to their size.-- Dwarf base land speed is 20 feet. However, dwarves can move at this speed even when wearing medium or heavy armor or when carrying a medium or heavy load.-- Weapon Familiarity: Dwarves may treat ~dwarven waraxes~[TAG_WEAPONS_WARAXE_DWARVEN] as martial weapons rather than exotic weapons. In ToEE, a dwarf has the ~Exotic Weapon Proficiency~[TAG_EXOTIC_PROF] feat for the Dwarven Waraxe.-- Stability: +4 bonus on ability checks made to resist being ~tripped~[TAG_TRIP] when standing on the ground.-- +2 racial bonus on ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC] against ~poison~[TAG_POISON].-- +2 racial bonus on saving throws against spells and spell-like effects.-- +1 racial bonus on ~attack rolls~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL] against orcs and goblinoids (such as goblins, hobgoblins, and bugbears).-- +4 dodge bonus to ~Armor Class~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] against creatures of the giant type (such as ogres, trolls, and hill giants).-- +2 racial bonus on ~Appraise~[TAG_APPRAISE] checks that are related to stone or metal items.-- Favored Class: ~Fighter~[TAG_FIGHTERS]. A multiclass dwarf's fighter class does not count when determining whether he takes an experience point penalty for multiclassing.
TAG_ELVES:TAG_RACES:::2: Elves mingle freely in ~human~[TAG_HUMANS] lands, always welcome yet never at home there. They are well known for their poetry, dance, song, lore, and magical arts. Elves favor things of natural and simple beauty. When danger threatens their woodland homes, however, elves reveal a more martial side, demonstrating skill with sword, bow, and battle strategy.Physical Description: Elves are short and slim, standing about 4 1/2 to 5 1/2 feet tall and typically weighing 85 to 135 pounds, with elf men the same height as and only marginally heavier than elf women. They are graceful but frail. An elf reaches adulthood at about 110 years of age and can live to be more than 700 years old. Elves do not sleep, as members of other common races do. Instead, an elf meditates in a deep trance for 4 hours a day.Alignment: Since elves love freedom, variety, and self-expression, they lean strongly toward the gentler aspects of chaos. Generally, they value and protect others' freedom as well as their own, and they are more often good than not. Religion: Above all others, elves worship ~Corellon Larethian~[TAG_CORELLON], "the Protector and Preserver of life". Elven myth holds that it was from his blood, shed in battle with ~Gruumsh~[TAG_GRUUMSH], the chief god of the orcs, that the elves first arose.Racial Traits:-- +2 ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY], -2 ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION]-- Medium: As Medium creatures, elves have no special bonuses or penalties due to their size.-- Elf base land speed is 30 feet.-- Immunity to magic ~sleep~[TAG_SPELLS_SLEEP] spells and effects, and a +2 racial ~saving throw~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC] bonus against ~enchantment~[TAG_MAGIC_SCHOOLS_ENCHANTMENT] spells or effects.-- Weapon Proficiency: Elves receive the ~Martial Weapon Proficiency~[TAG_MARTIAL_PROF] feats for the ~longsword~[TAG_WEAPONS_LONGSWORD], ~rapier~[TAG_WEAPONS_RAPIER], ~longbow~[TAG_WEAPONS_LONGBOW], and ~shortbow~[TAG_WEAPONS_SHORTBOW] as bonus feats. -- +2 racial bonuses on ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN], ~Search~[TAG_SEARCH], and ~Spot~[TAG_SPOT] checks. An elf who merely passes within 5 feet of a secret or concealed door is entitled to a Search check to notice it as if she were actively looking for it.-- Favored Class: ~Wizard~[TAG_WIZARDS]. A multiclass elf's wizard class does not count when determining whether she takes an experience point penalty for multiclassing.
TAG_GNOMES:TAG_RACES:::2: Gnomes are welcome everywhere as technicians, alchemists, and inventors. Despite the demand for their skills, most gnomes prefer to remain among their own kind, living in comfortable burrows beneath the rolling, wooded hills where animals abound.Physical Description: Gnomes stand about 3 to 3 1/2 feet tall and weigh 40 to 45 pounds. Gnomes reach adulthood at about age 40, and they typically live about 350 years, though some can live almost 500 years.Alignment: Gnomes are most often good. Those who tend toward law are sages, engineers, researchers, scholars, or investigators. Those who tend toward chaos are minstrels or wanderers. Gnomes are good-hearted, and even the tricksters among them are more playful than vicious. Evil gnomes are as rare as they are frightening. Religion: The chief gnome god is ~Garl Glittergold~[TAG_GARL], "the Watchful Protector". Racial Traits:-- +2 ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION], -2 ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH]-- Small: As a Small creature, a gnome gains a +1 ~size~[TAG_SIZE_MODIFIER] bonus to ~Armor Class~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS], a +1 size bonus on ~attack rolls~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL], and a +4 bonus on ~Hide~[TAG_HIDE] checks, but he must use smaller weapons than ~humans~[TAG_HUMANS] use, and his lifting and carrying limits are three-quarters of those of a Medium character.-- Gnome base land speed is 20 feet.-- Weapon Familiarity: Gnomes may treat ~gnome hooked hammers~[TAG_WEAPONS_HAMMER_GNOME_HOOKED] as martial weapons rather than exotic weapons. In ToEE, a gnome has the ~Exotic Weapon Proficiency~[TAG_EXOTIC_PROF] feat for the Gnome Hooked Hammer.-- +2 racial bonus on ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC] against illusions.-- Add +1 to the Difficulty Class for all saving throws against ~illusion~[TAG_MAGIC_SCHOOLS_ILLUSION] spells cast by gnomes.-- +1 racial bonus on attack rolls against kobolds and goblinoids (such as goblins, hobgoblins, and bugbears).-- +4 dodge bonus to Armor Class against creatures of the giant type (such as ogres, trolls, and hill giants).-- +2 racial bonus on ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN] checks.-- Favored Class: ~Bard~[TAG_BARDS]. A multiclass gnome's bard class does not count when determining whether he takes an experience point penalty.
TAG_HALF_ELVES:TAG_RACES:::2: ~Humans~[TAG_HUMANS] and ~elves~[TAG_ELVES] sometimes wed, the elf attracted to the human's energy and the human to the elf's grace. These marriages end quickly because a human's life is so brief (compared to an elf's life span of hundreds of years), but they leave an enduring legacy--half-elf children. The life of a half-elf can be hard. Most find places for themselves eventually in human lands, but some feel like outsiders all their lives.Physical Description: Half-elf height ranges from under 5 feet to about 6 feet tall, and weight usually ranges from 90 to 180 pounds. Half-elf men are taller and heavier than half-elf women, but the difference is less pronounced than that found among humans. A half-elf reaches adulthood at age 20 and can live to be more than 180 years old.Alignment: Half-elves share the chaotic bent of their elven heritage, but, like humans, they tend toward good and evil in equal proportion. Like elves, they value personal freedom and creative expression, demonstrating neither love of leaders nor desire for followers. They chafe at rules, resent others' demands, and sometimes prove unreliable, or at least unpredictable. Religion: Half-elves raised among elves follow elven deities, principally ~Correlon Larethian~[TAG_CORELLON]. Those raised among humans follow ~Ehlonna~[TAG_EHLONNA].Racial Traits:-- Medium: As Medium creatures, half-elves have no special bonuses or penalties due to their size.-- Half-elf base land speed is 30 feet.-- Immunity to ~sleep~[TAG_SPELLS_SLEEP] spells and similar magical effects, and a +2 racial bonus on ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC] against ~enchantment~[TAG_MAGIC_SCHOOLS_ENCHANTMENT] spells or effects.-- +1 racial bonus on ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN], ~Search~[TAG_SEARCH], and ~Spot~[TAG_SPOT] checks. A half-elf does not have the elf's ability to notice secret doors simply by passing near them.-- +2 racial bonus on ~Diplomacy~[TAG_DIPLOMACY] and ~Gather Information~[TAG_GATHER_INFORMATION] checks.-- Elven Blood: For all effects related to race, a half-elf is considered an elf.-- Favored Class: Any. When determining whether a multiclass half-elf takes an experience point penalty, her highest-level class does not count.
TAG_HALF_ORCS:TAG_RACES:::2: In the wild frontiers, tribes of ~humans~[TAG_HUMANS] and orc barbarians live in uneasy balance, fighting in times of war and trading in times of peace. Half-orcs who are born in the frontier may live with either human or orc parents, but they are nevertheless exposed to both cultures. Some, for whatever reasons, leave their homeland and travel to civilized lands, bringing with them the tenacity, courage, and combat prowess that they developed in the wilds.Physical Description: Half-orcs stand between 6 and 7 feet tall and usually weigh between 200 and 250 pounds. Many half-orcs have scars, whether as symbols of pride or shame. Half-orcs mature a little faster than humans and age noticeably faster. They reach adulthood at age 14, and few live longer than 75 years.Alignment: Half-orcs inherit a tendency toward chaos from their orc parents, but, like their human parents, they favor good and evil in equal proportions. Half-orcs raised among orcs and willing to live out their lives with them are usually the evil ones.Religion: Like orcs, many half-orcs worship ~Gruumsh~[TAG_GRUUMSH], the chief orc god and arch-enemy of ~Corellon Larethian~[TAG_CORELLON], the god of the elves. Half-orcs who want to solidify their connection to their human heritage, on the other hand, follow human gods, and they may be outspoken in their shows of piety.Racial Traits:-- +2 ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH], -2 ~Intelligence~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE], -2 ~Charisma~[TAG_CHARISMA]-- Medium: As Medium creatures, half-orcs have no special bonuses or penalties due to their size.-- Half-orc base land speed is 30 feet.-- Orc Blood: For all effects related to race, a half-orc is considered an orc.-- Favored Class: ~Barbarian~[TAG_BARBARIANS]. A multiclass half-orc's barbarian class does not count when determining whether he takes an experience point penalty.
TAG_HALFLINGS:TAG_RACES:::2: Halflings are clever, capable opportunists. Halfling individuals and clans find room for themselves wherever they can. Often they are strangers and wanderers, and others react to them with suspicion or curiosity. Depending on the clan, halflings might be reliable, hardworking citizens, or they might be thieves just waiting for the opportunity to make a big score and disappear in the dead of night. Regardless, halflings are cunning and resourceful survivors.Physical Description: Halflings stand about 3 feet tall and usually weigh between 30 and 35 pounds. A halfling reaches adulthood at the age of 20 and usually lives into the middle of her second century.Alignment: Halflings tend to be neutral. While they are comfortable with change (a chaotic trait), they also tend to rely on intangible constants, such as clan ties and personal honor (a lawful trait).Religion: The chief halfling deity is ~Yondalla~[TAG_YONDALLA], "the Blessed One", protector of the halflings. Halflings also recognize countless lesser gods, who rule over individual villages, forests, rivers, lakes, and so on. The halflings pay homage to these deities to ensure safe journey as they travel from place to place.Racial Traits:-- +2 ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY], -2 ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH]-- Small: As a Small creature, a halfling gains a +1 ~size~[TAG_SIZE_MODIFIER] bonus to ~Armor Class~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS], a +1 size bonus on ~attack rolls~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL], and a +4 bonus on ~Hide~[TAG_HIDE] checks, but she must use smaller weapons than ~humans~[TAG_HUMANS] use, and her lifting and carrying limits are three quarters of those of a Medium character.-- Halfling base land speed is 20 feet.-- +2 racial bonus on ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN] and ~Move Silently~[TAG_MOVE_SILENTLY] checks.-- +1 racial bonus on all ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC].-- +2 morale bonus on saving throws against ~fear~[TAG_FEAR]. This bonus stacks with the halfling's +1 bonus on saving throws in general.-- +1 racial attack bonus with ~thrown weapons~[TAG_THROW_WEAPON] and ~slings~[TAG_WEAPONS_SLING].-- Favored Class: ~Rogue~[TAG_ROGUES]. A multiclass halfling's rogue class does not count when determining whether she takes an experience point penalty for multiclassing.
TAG_CLASSES::::2: ~Barbarians~[TAG_BARBARIANS]~Bards~[TAG_BARDS]~Clerics~[TAG_CLERICS]~Druids~[TAG_DRUIDS]~Fighters~[TAG_FIGHTERS]~Monks~[TAG_MONKS]~Paladins~[TAG_PALADINS]~Rangers~[TAG_RANGERS]~Rogues~[TAG_ROGUES]~Sorcerers~[TAG_SORCERERS]~Wizards~[TAG_WIZARDS]Other Information about Classes:~Class and Level Bonuses~[TAG_LEVEL_BONUSES]~Saving Throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC]~Level-Dependent Benefits~[TAG_CLASS_BENEFITS]~Experience and Levels~[TAG_EXPERIENCE_AND_LEVELS]~Multiclass Characters~[TAG_MULTICLASS]~Favored Class~[TAG_FAVORED_CLASS]
TAG_LEVEL_BONUSES:TAG_CLASSES:::2: An ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL], ~saving throw~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC], or ~skill check~[TAG_USING_SKILLS] is a combination of three numbers, each representing a different factor: a random factor (the number you roll on a d20), a number representing the character's innate abilities (the ability modifier), and a bonus representing the character's experience and training. This third factor depends, either directly or indirectly, on the character's class and level.Base Save Bonus (BSB): As the character gains levels, this bonus increases for ~Fortitude~[TAG_FORTITUDE], ~Will~[TAG_WILL], and ~Reflex~[TAG_REFLEX] saving throws. Depending on the character's class, this increase can be either Good or Poor.Base Attack Bonus (BAB): As the character gains levels, this bonus adds to the attack roll. Depending on the character's class, this increase can be Good, Average, or Poor.  Additional attacks receive a reduced bonus.Class BAB and BSB~Barbarian~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARBARIAN]~Bard~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD]~Cleric~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_CLERIC]~Druid~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_DRUID]~Fighter~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_FIGHTER]~Monk~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_MONK]~Paladin~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_PALADIN]~Ranger~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_RANGER]~Rogue~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_ROGUE]~Sorcerer~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_SORCERER]~Wizard~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_WIZARD]
TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC:TAG_LEVEL_BONUSES:: Generally, when you are subject to an unusual or magical attack, you get a saving throw to avoid or reduce the effect.  Like an ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL], a saving throw is a d20 roll plus a bonus based on your ~class~[TAG_CLASSES], level and ~ability score~[TAG_ABILITY_SCORES].  Your saving throw modifier is:                          ~base save bonus~[TAG_LEVEL_BONUSES] + ~ability modifier~[TAG_ABILITY_MODIFIERS]There are three different kinds of saving throws:                                ~Fortitude~[TAG_FORTITUDE], ~Reflex~[TAG_REFLEX], and ~Will~[TAG_WILL]Saving Throw Difficulty Class: The DC for a save is determined by the attack itself.  For example, a Small Centipede's ~poison~[TAG_POISON] allows a DC 11 Fortitude save against it.Automatic Failures and Successes: A natural 1 on a saving throw is always a failure.  A natural 20 is always a success.
TAG_FORTITUDE:TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC:::2: These saves measure your ability to stand up to massive physical punishment or attacks against your vitality and health.  Apply your ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION] modifier to your Fortitude saving throws:                  1d20 + ~base save bonus~[TAG_LEVEL_BONUSES] + Constitution modifierFortitude saves can be made against attacks or effects such as ~poison~[TAG_POISON], ~disease~[TAG_DISEASED], ~paralysis~[TAG_PARALYZED], petrification, ~energy drain~[TAG_ENERGY_DRAINED], ~Destruction~[TAG_SPELLS_DESTRUCTION], and ~Disintegrate~[TAG_SPELLS_DISINTEGRATE].
TAG_REFLEX:TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC:::2: These saves test your ability to dodge area attacks.  Apply your ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] modifier to your Reflex saving throws:                   1d20 + ~base save bonus~[TAG_LEVEL_BONUSES] + Dexterity modifierReflex saves can be made against attacks or effects such as pit traps, catching on fire, ~Fireball~[TAG_SPELLS_FIREBALL], ~Lightning Bolt~[TAG_SPELLS_LIGHTNING_BOLT], and Red Dragon breath.
TAG_WILL:TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC:::2: These saves reflect your resistance to mental influence and domination as well as many magical effects.  Apply your ~Wisdom~[TAG_WISDOM] modifier to your Will saving throws:                   1d20 + ~base save bonus~[TAG_LEVEL_BONUSES] + Wisdom modifierWill saves can be made against attacks or effects such as ~Charm Person~[TAG_SPELLS_CHARM_PERSON], ~Hold Person~[TAG_SPELLS_HOLD_PERSON], and most ~illusion~[TAG_MAGIC_SCHOOLS_ILLUSION] spells.
TAG_CLASS_BENEFITS:TAG_CLASSES:::2: Characters gain benefits from advancing in levels, in addition to those gained from their ~class and level bonuses~[TAG_LEVEL_BONUSES]. Maximum Skill Ranks: A character's level determines the maximum allowable ranks he or she may have in Class ~Skills~[TAG_SKILLS] and Cross-Class Skills. The maximum ranks in Class Skills is the level plus 3, while the maximum level for Cross-Class Skills is half of that.Feats: A character receives one ~feat~[TAG_FEATS] at 1st level and another at every level divisible by three after that (3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th, 15th, and 18th). These feats are in addition to any bonus feats granted as ~class features~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_DESC].Ability Score Increase: Upon attaining any level divisible by four (4th, 8th, 12th, 16th, and 20th), a character increases one of his or her ~ability scores~[TAG_ABILITY_SCORES] by 1 point. The player chooses which ability score to improve.
TAG_EXPERIENCE_AND_LEVELS:TAG_CLASSES:::: Experience points (XP) measure how much your character has learned and how much he or she has grown in personal power. Your character earns XP by defeating monsters and completing quests. When your character's XP total reaches at least the minimum XP needed for a new character level (see ~Class Benefits~[TAG_CLASS_BENEFITS]), he or she "goes up a level". Characters can only go up one level at a time.Below are the point totals needed to attain a given character level--that is, the total of all the character's levels in classes:Level     @tXP1st       @t02nd     @t1,0003rd      @t3,0004th      @t6,0005th     @t10,0006th     @t15,0007th     @t21,0008th     @t28,0009th     @t36,00010th     @t45,00011th       @t55,00012th     @t66,00013th      @t78,00014th      @t91,00015th     @t105,00016th     @t120,00017th     @t136,00018th     @t153,00019th     @t171,00020th    @t190,000
TAG_MULTICLASS:TAG_CLASSES:::2: When a character advances a level, he or she may choose to advance in a different ~class~[TAG_CLASSES] than the original class selected. Once a character has two or more different classes, that character is said to be a multiclass character.Characters gain ~abilities~[TAG_ABILITIES] and ~features~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_DESC] according to their new class, but their overall level remains the combined total of all their levels. Thus, a 7th level ~cleric~[TAG_CLERICS]/1st level ~barbarian~[TAG_BARBARIANS] is said to be an 8th level character.A multiclass character receives a 20% experience point reduction penalty for each class that is not within 2 levels of his highest class. Note that a character's ~favored class~[TAG_FAVORED_CLASS] (dependent upon ~race~[TAG_RACES]) does not count as the highest level.
TAG_FAVORED_CLASS:TAG_CLASSES:::2: A character's favored ~class~[TAG_CLASSES] does not count against him or her when determining experience point penalties for ~multiclassing~[TAG_MULTICLASS]. For example, as a ~halfling~[TAG_HALFLINGS] ~rogue~[TAG_ROGUES], Lidda can add a second class later on (becoming a multiclass character) without worrying about an XP penalty, because rogue is the favored class for halflings. Note that ~humans~[TAG_HUMANS] and ~half-elves~[TAG_HALF_ELVES] do not have a favored class. Instead their highest-level class, whatever it may be, is not counted when determining if there is an experience point penalty for that character.
TAG_BARBARIANS:TAG_CLASSES:::2: From the frozen wastes of the north and the hellish jungles of the south come brave, even reckless warriors. Civilized people call them barbarians or berserkers and suspect them of mayhem, impiety, and atrocities. These "barbarians" have proven their mettle and their value to those who would be their allies.Characteristics: The barbarian is an excellent warrior. Where the ~fighter's~[TAG_FIGHTERS] skill in combat comes from training and discipline, however, the barbarian has a powerful rage. Barbarians are at home in the wild and they run at great speed.Alignment: Barbarians are never lawful. They may be honorable, but at heart they are wild. This wildness is their strength, and it could not live in a lawful soul. At best, barbarians of chaotic alignment are free and expressive. At worst, they are thoughtlessly destructive.Religion: Some barbarians distrust established religions and prefer an intuitive, natural relationship to the cosmos over formal worship. Others devote themselves to powerful deities, such as ~Kord~[TAG_KORD] (the god of strength), ~Obad-Hai~[TAG_OBAD_HAI] (the god of nature), or ~Erythnul~[TAG_ERYTHNUL] (the god of slaughter).Other Classes: As people of the wild, barbarians are most comfortable in the company of ~rangers~[TAG_RANGERS], ~druids~[TAG_DRUIDS], and ~clerics~[TAG_CLERICS] of nature deities. Many barbarians admire the talents of ~bards~[TAG_BARDS] and are enthusiastic about music. However, barbarians don't trust what they don't understand, which includes the practices of ~wizards~[TAG_WIZARDS]. They are more tolerant toward ~sorcerers~[TAG_SORCERERS], perhaps because sorcerers are so charismatic. Barbarians have little in common with the practical, deliberate approach to combat that ~monks~[TAG_MONKS] take, but these two classes are not necessarily hostile to one another. Barbarians have no special attitude toward fighters, ~paladins~[TAG_PALADINS], clerics, or ~rogues~[TAG_ROGUES].Role: A barbarian's typical primary role in a group of adventurers is as a front-line combat specialist. No other character can match a barbarian's sheer toughness. He can also serve as a good scout, thanks to his speed, skill selection, and trap sense.Abilities: ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] is important for barbarians because of its role in combat. ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] is also useful to barbarians, especially those who wear light armor. ~Wisdom~[TAG_WISDOM] is important for several of the barbarian's class skills. A high ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION] score lets a barbarian rage longer.Class Alignment: Any nonlawfulHit Die: d12Base Attack and Base Save Bonuses: see ~table~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARBARIAN]Class Skills: ~Intimidate~[TAG_INTIMIDATE], ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN], and ~Survival~[TAG_SURVIVAL]Skill points at 1st Level: (4 + ~Int~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] modifier) x 4Skill points at Each Additional Level: 4 + Int modifierClass Features:[CMD_CHILDREN]
TAG_BARDS:TAG_CLASSES:::2: It is said that music has a special magic, and the bard proves that saying true. Wandering across the land, gathering lore, telling stories, working magic with his music, and living on the gratitude of his audience--such is the life of a bard. When change or opportunity draws them into a conflict, bards serve as diplomats, negotiators, scouts, and spies.Characteristics: A bard brings forth magic from his soul, not from a book. He can cast only a small number of spells, but he can do so without selecting or preparing them in advance. His magic emphasizes charms and illusions over the more dramatic evocation spells that ~wizards~[TAG_WIZARDS] and ~sorcerers~[TAG_SORCERERS] often use. In addition to spells, a bard works magic with his music and poetry. He can encourage allies, hold his audiences rapt, and counter magical effects that rely on speech or sound. Bards have some of the same skills as ~rogues~[TAG_ROGUES]. A bard listens to stories as well as telling them, of course, so he has a vast knowledge of local events and noteworthy items.Alignment: Bards are wanderers, guided by whim and intuition rather than by tradition or law. The spontaneous talent, magic, and lifestyle of the bard are incompatible with a lawful alignment.Other Classes: A bard works well with companions of other classes. He often serves as the spokesperson of the party, using his social skills for the party's benefit. In a party without a wizard or sorcerer, the bard contributes magic. In a party without a rogue, bards use their skills.Role: The bard is perhaps the ultimate generalist. In most adventuring groups, he works best in a supporting role. The bard makes all the other characters better at what they do, and can often fill in for another character when needed.Abilities: ~Charisma~[TAG_CHARISMA] determines how powerful a spell a bard can cast, how many spells he can cast per day, and how hard those spells are to resist. Charisma, ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY], and ~Intelligence~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] are important for many of the bard's class skills.Class Alignment: Any nonlawfulHit Die: d6Base Attack and Base Save Bonuses: see ~table~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD]Class Skills: ~Appraise~[TAG_APPRAISE], ~Bluff~[TAG_BLUFF], ~Concentration~[TAG_CONCENTRATION], ~Diplomacy~[TAG_DIPLOMACY], ~Gather Information~[TAG_GATHER_INFORMATION], ~Hide~[TAG_HIDE], ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN], ~Move Silently~[TAG_MOVE_SILENTLY], ~Perform~[TAG_PERFORM], ~Sense Motive~[TAG_SENSE_MOTIVE], ~Sleight of Hand~[TAG_SLEIGHT], ~Spellcraft~[TAG_SPELLCRAFT], and ~Use Magic Device~[TAG_UMD]Skill Points at 1st Level: (6 + Int modifier) x 4Skill Points at Each Additional Level: 6 + Int modifierClass Features:[CMD_CHILDREN]
TAG_CLERICS:TAG_CLASSES:::2: The handiwork of the gods is everywhere--in places of natural beauty, in mighty crusades, in soaring temples, and in the hearts of worshipers. Like people, gods can run the gamut from benevolent to malicious, reserved to intrusive, simple to inscrutable. The gods, however, work mostly through intermediaries--their clerics. Good clerics heal, protect, and avenge. Evil clerics pillage, destroy, and sabotage.Characteristics: Clerics are masters of ~divine magic~[TAG_DIVINE_SPELLS], a form of magic that is especially good with healing.Alignment: Like the gods they serve, clerics can be of any alignment. Because people more readily worship good deities than neutral or evil ones, there are more good than evil clerics. Clerics also tend toward law instead of chaos, since lawful religions tend to be more structured and better able to recruit and train clerics than chaotic ones. Typically, a cleric is the same alignment as his or her deity, though some clerics are one step away from their respective deities in alignment.Other Classes: In an adventuring party, the cleric is everybody's friend and often the glue that holds the party together, as well as the healer who channels divine energy to keep others alive. Clerics sometimes clash with ~druids~[TAG_DRUIDS], since druids represent an older, more primal relationship between the mortal and the divine. Mostly, though, the religion of a cleric and the god that he worships determines how he gets along with others.Role: The cleric serves as a typical group's primary healer, diviner, and defensive specialist. Clerics can hold their own in a fight, but are not usually well served by charging to the front of combat.Abilities: ~Wisdom~[TAG_WISDOM] determines how powerful a spell a cleric can cast, how many spells he can cast per day, and how hard those spells are to resist. A high ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION] score improves a cleric's ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS], and a high ~Charisma~[TAG_CHARISMA] score improves his ability to turn or rebuke undead.Class Alignment: A cleric's ~alignment~[TAG_ALIGNMENT] must be within one step of his ~deity's~[TAG_RELIGION].Hit Die: d8Base Attack and Base Save Bonuses: see ~table~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_CLERIC]Class Skills: ~Concentration~[TAG_CONCENTRATION], ~Diplomacy~[TAG_DIPLOMACY], ~Heal~[TAG_HEAL], and ~Spellcraft~[TAG_SPELLCRAFT]Domains: Clerics must select two ~domains~[TAG_DOMAINS] from their deity's list. A cleric who chooses the ~Travel domain~[TAG_TRAVEL_D] adds ~Survival~[TAG_SURVIVAL] to his class skill list. A cleric who chooses the ~Trickery domain~[TAG_TRICKERY_D] adds ~Bluff~[TAG_BLUFF] and ~Hide~[TAG_HIDE] to his class skill list.Skill Points at 1st Level: (2 + ~Int~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] modifier) x 4Skill Points at Each Additional Level: 2 + Int modifierClass Features:[CMD_CHILDREN]
TAG_DRUIDS:TAG_CLASSES:::2: The fury of a storm, the gentle strength of the morning sun, the cunning of the fox, the power of the bear--all these and more are at the druid's command. The druid, however, claims no mastery over nature. That claim, she says, is the empty boast of a city dweller. The druid gains her power not by ruling nature but by being at one with it. To a trespasser in a druid's sacred grove, and to those who feel her wrath, the distinction is overly fine.Characteristics: Druids cast ~divine spells~[TAG_DIVINE_SPELLS] much the same way ~clerics~[TAG_CLERICS] do, though most get their spells from the power of nature rather than from deities. In addition to spells, druids gain an increasing array of magical powers, including the ability to take the shapes of animals, as they advance in level.Alignment: Druids, in keeping with nature's ultimate indifference, must maintain at least some measure of dispassion. As such, they must be neutral on at least one alignment axis (chaotic-lawful or good-evil), if not both.Other Classes: The druid shares with ~rangers~[TAG_RANGERS] and many ~barbarians~[TAG_BARBARIANS] a reverence for nature and a familiarity with natural lands. She doesn't really understand the urban mannerisms of a ~rogue~[TAG_ROGUES] and finds ~arcane magic~[TAG_ARCANE_SPELLS] disruptive. The typical druid also dislikes the ~paladin's~[TAG_PALADINS] devotion to abstract ideals instead of "the real world". However, most druids accept diversity and, as such, take little offense to other characters.Role: The druid enjoys extraordinary versatility, using her offensive spells and wild shape ability to a party's advantage.Abilities: ~Wisdom~[TAG_WISDOM] determines how powerful a spell a druid can cast, how many spells she can cast per day, and how hard those spells are to resist. To cast a spell, a druid must have a Wisdom score of: 11 + the spell's level     A druid gets bonus spells based on Wisdom. The Difficulty Class of a ~saving throw~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC] against a druid's spell is: 11 + the druid's Wisdom modifier     Since a druid wears only light or medium armor, a high ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] score greatly improves her defensive ability.Class Alignment: ~Neutral Good~[TAG_NEUTRAL_GOOD], ~Lawful Neutral~[TAG_LAWFUL_NEUTRAL], ~True Neutral~[TAG_NEUTRAL], ~Chaotic Neutral~[TAG_CHAOTIC_NEUTRAL], or ~Neutral Evil~[TAG_NEUTRAL_EVIL]Hit Die: d8Base Attack and Base Save Bonuses: see ~table~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_DRUID]Class Skills: ~Concentration~[TAG_CONCENTRATION], ~Diplomacy~[TAG_DIPLOMACY], ~Heal~[TAG_HEAL], ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN], ~Spellcraft~[TAG_SPELLCRAFT], ~Spot~[TAG_SPOT], and ~Survival~[TAG_SURVIVAL]Skill Points at 1st Level: (4 + ~Int~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] modifier) x 4Skill Points at Each Additional Level: 4 + Int modifierClass Features:[CMD_CHILDREN]
TAG_FIGHTERS:TAG_CLASSES:::2: The questing knight, the conquering overlord, the king's champion, the elite foot soldier, the hardened mercenary, and the bandit king--all are fighters. Fighters can be stalwart defenders of those in need, cruel marauders, or gutsy adventurers. Some are among the land's best souls, willing to face death for the greater good. Others are among the worst, with no qualms about killing for private gain, or even for sport. Fighters who are not actively adventuring may be soldiers, guards, bodyguards, champions, or criminal enforcers.Characteristics: Fighters are familiar with all the standard weapons and armors and also develop particular weapon and fighting specialties of their own.Other Classes: The fighter excels in a straight fight, but he or she relies on others for magical support, healing and scouting. On a team, it is a fighter's job to man the front lines, protect the other party members and bring the tough opponents down.Role: In most adventuring parties, the fighter serves as a melee combatant, charging into the fray while his comrades support him with spells, ranged attacks and other effects. Fighters who favor ranged combat can prove very deadly, although without other melee support they can find themselves in front-line combat more often than they might prefer.Abilities: ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] is especially important for fighters because it improves their melee ~attack~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL] and damage rolls. ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION] is important for giving fighters many ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS], which they need in their frequent battles. ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] is important for fighters who want to be good archers or who want access to certain Dexterity-oriented feats, but the heavy armor that fighters usually wear reduces the benefits of a very high Dexterity score.Class Alignment: AnyHit Die: d10Base Attack and Base Save Bonuses: see ~table~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_FIGHTER]Class Skills: ~Intimidate~[TAG_INTIMIDATE]Skill Points at 1st Level: (2 + ~Int~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] modifier) x 4Skill Points at Each Additional Level: 2 + Int modifierClass Features:[CMD_CHILDREN]
TAG_MONKS:TAG_CLASSES:::2: Dotted across the landscape are monasteries--small, walled cloisters inhabited by monks who pursue personal perfection through action as well as contemplation. They train themselves to be versatile warriors skilled at fighting without weapons or armor. The inhabitants of monasteries headed by good masters serve as protectors of the people. In contrast, the residents of monasteries headed by evil masters rule the surrounding lands through fear, as an evil warlord and his entourage might.Characteristics: The key feature of the monk is her ability to fight unarmed and unarmored. Though a monk casts no spells, she has a magic of her own, called ki, which allows her to perform amazing feats. The monk's best known ~feat~[TAG_STUNNING_FIST] is her ability to stun an opponent with an unarmed blow.Alignment: Any lawful. A monk's training requires strict discipline. Only those who are lawful at heart are capable of undertaking it.Other Classes: Monks do not have much in common with others, as their skills and motivation differ from those of most adventurers. However, monks realize that they work well with the support of others and they usually prove themselves reliable companions.Role: The monk functions best as an opportunistic combatant, using her speed to get into and out of combat quickly, rather than engaging in prolonged melees.Abilities: ~Wisdom~[TAG_WISDOM] powers the monk's special offensive and defensive capabilities. ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] provides an unarmored monk with a better defense and with bonuses to some class skills. ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] helps a monk's unarmed combat ability.Class Alignment: ~Lawful Good~[TAG_LAWFUL_GOOD], ~Lawful Neutral~[TAG_LAWFUL_NEUTRAL], or ~Lawful Evil~[TAG_LAWFUL_EVIL]Hit Die: d8Base Attack and Base Save Bonuses: see ~table~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_MONK]Class Skills: ~Concentration~[TAG_CONCENTRATION],~Diplomacy~[TAG_DIPLOMACY], ~Hide~[TAG_HIDE], ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN], ~Move Silently~[TAG_MOVE_SILENTLY], ~Perform~[TAG_PERFORM], ~Sense Motive~[TAG_SENSE_MOTIVE], ~Spot~[TAG_SPOT], and ~Tumble~[TAG_TUMBLE]Skill Points at 1st Level: (4 + ~Int~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] modifier) x 4Skill Points at Each Additional Level: 4 + Int modifierClass Features:[CMD_CHILDREN]Like a member of any other class, a monk may be a ~multiclass~[TAG_MULTICLASS] character, but multiclass monks face a special restriction. A monk who gains a new class or (if already multiclass) raises another class by a level may never again raise her monk level, though she retains all her monk abilities.
TAG_PALADINS:TAG_CLASSES:::2: The compassion to pursue good, the will to uphold law, and the power to defeat evil--these are the three weapons of the paladin. Few have the purity and devotion that it takes to walk the paladin's path, but those few are rewarded with the power to protect, to heal, and to smite. In a land of scheming ~wizards~[TAG_WIZARDS], unholy priests, bloodthirsty dragons, and infernal fiends, the paladin is the final hope that cannot be extinguished.Characteristics: Divine power protects the paladin and gives her special powers. It wards off harm, protects her from disease, lets her heal herself and heal others, as well. A paladin can use this power to destroy evil.Alignment: Paladins must be lawful good. They lose their divine powers if they deviate from that alignment.Other Classes: Paladins work well with other classes, particularly when members of the group are committed to good. Their only conflicts arise in regards to evil characters or evil acts.Role: The paladin's chief role is as a melee combatant, but they also work well as a secondary healer within a group, or as a charismatic party leader.Abilities: ~Charisma~[TAG_CHARISMA] enhances a paladin's healing power, self-protective capabilities, and turn undead ability. ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] is important for the paladin because of its role in combat. A ~Wisdom~[TAG_WISDOM] score of 14 or higher is required to get access to the most powerful paladin spells, and a score of 11 or higher is required to cast any paladin spells at all.Class Alignment: ~Lawful Good~[TAG_LAWFUL_GOOD]Hit Die: d10Base Attack and Base Save Bonuses: see ~table~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_PALADIN]Class Skills: ~Concentration~[TAG_CONCENTRATION], ~Diplomacy~[TAG_DIPLOMACY], ~Heal~[TAG_HEAL], and ~Sense Motive~[TAG_SENSE_MOTIVE]Skill Points at 1st Level: (2 + ~Int~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] modifier) x 4Skill Points at Each Additional Level: 2 + Int modifierClass Features:[CMD_CHILDREN]Like a member of any other class, a paladin may be a ~multiclass~[TAG_MULTICLASS] character, but multiclass paladins face a special restriction. A paladin who gains a level in any class other than paladin may never again raise her paladin level, though she retains all her paladin abilities.
TAG_RANGERS:TAG_CLASSES:::2: The forests are home to fierce and cunning creatures, such as bloodthirsty owlbears and malicious displacer beasts. But more cunning and powerful than these monsters is the ranger, a skilled hunter and stalker. He knows the woods as if they were his home (as indeed they are), and he knows his prey in deadly detail.Characteristics: A ranger can use a variety of weapons and is quite capable in combat. A ranger's skills allow him to survive in the wilderness, and he possesses special knowledge about certain creatures. Finally, an experienced ranger has such a tie to nature that he can actually draw upon natural power to cast ~divine spells~[TAG_DIVINE_SPELLS], as a ~druid~[TAG_DRUIDS] does.Alignment: Most rangers are good, and they usually function as protectors of natural areas. They are also typically chaotic, preferring to follow the ebb and flow of nature or of their own hearts instead of rigid rules. Evil rangers are much to be feared as they gain spells to use nature for destructive purposes.Other Classes: Rangers get along well with druids and to some extent with ~barbarians~[TAG_BARBARIANS]. They bicker most often with ~paladins~[TAG_PALADINS], who have a different style and approach to life that is much more bound by a code of morals and laws. Typically, though, rangers easily tolerate others, mostly because they don't feel the need to get upset over differences.Role: The ranger's best role is that of a scout and secondary combatant, often focusing on opportunistic and ranged attacks.Abilities: ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] is important for a ranger both because he tends to wear light armor and because several ranger skills are based on that ability. ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] is important because rangers frequently get involved in combat. Several ranger skills are based on ~Wisdom~[TAG_WISDOM], and a Wisdom score of 14 or higher is required to get access to the most powerful ranger spells. A Wisdom score of 11 or higher is required to cast any ranger spells at all. One of the ranger's trademark skills, his ability to ~track~[TAG_TRACK] foes, is based on Wisdom.Class Alignment: AnyHit Die: d8Base Attack and Base Save Bonuses: see ~table~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_RANGER]Class Skills: ~Concentration~[TAG_CONCENTRATION], ~Heal~[TAG_HEAL], ~Hide~[TAG_HIDE], ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN], ~Move Silently~[TAG_MOVE_SILENTLY], ~Search~[TAG_SEARCH], ~Spot~[TAG_SPOT], and ~Survival~[TAG_SURVIVAL]Skill Points at 1st Level: (6 + ~Int~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] modifier) x 4Skill Points at Each Additional Level: 6 + Int modifierClass Features:[CMD_CHILDREN]
TAG_ROGUES:TAG_CLASSES:::2: Rogues have little in common with one another. Some are stealthy thieves. Others are silver-tongued tricksters. Still others are scouts, infiltrators, spies, diplomats, or thugs. What they do share is versatility, adaptability, and resourcefulness. In general, rogues are skilled at getting what others don't want them to get: entrance into a locked treasure vault, safe passage past a deadly trap, secret battle plans, a guard's trust, or some random person's pocket moneyCharacteristics: Rogues are highly skilled and they can concentrate on developing any of several categories of skills. A rogue knows how to hit where it hurts and she can dish out a lot of damage with a sneak attack.Alignment: Rogues follow opportunities, not ideals. Though they are more likely to be chaotic than lawful, they are a diverse bunch, so they can be of any alignment.Other Classes: Rogues excel when protected by warriors and spellcasters, but they are wary of the sometimes overbearing disposition of ~paladins~[TAG_PALADINS].Role: The rogue's role in a group can vary dramatically based on her skill selection, but most rogues share certain aspects. They aren't capable of prolonged melee combat, so they focus on opportunistic sneak attacks or ranged attacks. The rogue's stealth and trapfinding ability make her one of the best scouts in the game.Abilities: ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] provides extra protection for the lightly armored rogue. ~Intelligence~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] and ~Wisdom~[TAG_WISDOM] are important for many of the rogue's skills. A high Intelligence score also gives the rogue extra skill points, which can be used to expand her repertoire.Class Alignment: AnyHit Die: d6Base Attack and Base Save Bonuses: see ~table~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_ROGUE]Class Skills: ~Appraise~[TAG_APPRAISE], ~Bluff~[TAG_BLUFF], ~Diplomacy~[TAG_DIPLOMACY], ~Disable Device~[TAG_DISABLE_DEVICE], ~Gather Information~[TAG_GATHER_INFORMATION], ~Hide~[TAG_HIDE], ~Intimidate~[TAG_INTIMIDATE], ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN], ~Move Silently~[TAG_MOVE_SILENTLY], ~Open Lock~[TAG_OPEN_LOCK], ~Perform~[TAG_PERFORM], ~Search~[TAG_SEARCH], ~Sense Motive~[TAG_SENSE_MOTIVE], ~Sleight of Hand~[TAG_SLEIGHT], ~Spot~[TAG_SPOT], ~Tumble~[TAG_TUMBLE], and ~Use Magic Device~[TAG_UMD]Skill Points at 1st Level: (8 + Int modifier) x 4Skill Points at Each Additional Level: 8 + Int modifierClass Features:[CMD_CHILDREN]
TAG_SORCERERS:TAG_CLASSES:::2: Sorcerers create magic the way a poet creates poems, with inborn talent honed by practice. They have no books, no theories, no mentors--just raw power that they direct at will. Some sorcerers claim that the blood of dragons courses through their veins. This claim may be true in some cases, although many hold that the claim is either an unsubstantiated boast or envious gossip.Characteristics: Sorcerers cast spells through innate power rather than through careful training and study. Their magic is intuitive rather than logical. They can cast spells more often than ~wizards~[TAG_WIZARDS] and have no need to select and prepare their spells ahead of time.Alignment: Sorcery favors the free, chaotic, creative spirit over the disciplined mind, so sorcerers tend slightly towards chaos over law. Otherwise, sorcerer alignment varies considerably.Other Classes: Sorcerers find that they have the most in common with members of other largely self-taught classes, such as ~druids~[TAG_DRUIDS] and ~rogues~[TAG_ROGUES]. They sometimes find themselves at odds with members of the more disciplined classes, such as ~paladins~[TAG_PALADINS] and ~monks~[TAG_MONKS]. Since they cast the same spells as wizards do but do so in a different way, they sometimes find themselves in competition with wizards.Role: A sorcerer tends to define his role based on spell selection. A sorcerer who focuses on damage-dealing spells becomes the center of the party's offensive power, while another sorcerer that relies on charms or illusions will take a quieter role. A party with a sorcerer should strongly consider a second spellcaster to make up for the sorcerer's lack of versatility. Since sorcerers rely on their charismatic presence when interacting with others, they often serve as the "face" for an adventuring party.Abilities: ~Charisma~[TAG_CHARISMA] determines how powerful a spell a sorcerer can cast, how many spells he can cast per day, and how hard those spells are to resist. Like a wizard, a sorcerer benefits from high ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] and ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION] scores.Class Alignment: AnyHit Die: d4Base Attack and Base Save Bonuses: see ~table~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_SORCERER]Class Skills: ~Bluff~[TAG_BLUFF], ~Concentration~[TAG_CONCENTRATION], and ~Spellcraft~[TAG_SPELLCRAFT]Skill Points at 1st Level: (2 + ~Int~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] modifier) x 4Skill Points at Each Additional Level: 2 + Int modifierClass Features:[CMD_CHILDREN]
TAG_WIZARDS:TAG_CLASSES:::2: A few unintelligible words and fleeting gestures carry more power than a battleaxe, when they are the words and gestures of a wizard. These simple acts make magic seem easy, but they only hint at the time the wizard must spend poring over his spellbook preparing each spell for casting, and the years before that spent in apprenticeship to learn the arts of magic. For wizards, magic is not a talent but a difficult, rewarding art.Characteristics: The wizard's strength is his spells. Everything else is secondary. He learns new spells as he explores and grows in experience.     Some wizards prefer to specialize in a certain type of magic. ~Specialization~[TAG_CHARGEN_WIZARD_SPECIALIZATION] makes a wizard more powerful in his chosen field, but it denies him access to some of the spells that lie outside that field.     Like a ~sorcerer~[TAG_SORCERERS], a wizard can call a familiar--a small, magical animal companion that serves him.Alignment: Overall, wizards show a slight tendency toward law over chaos because the study of magic rewards those who are disciplined. Illusionists and transmuters, however, are masters of deception and change, respectively. They favor chaos over law.Other Classes: Wizards prefer to work with members of other classes. They love to cast their spells from behind strong ~fighters~[TAG_FIGHTERS], to "magic up" ~rogues~[TAG_ROGUES] and send them out to scout, and to rely on the divine healing of ~clerics~[TAG_CLERICS]. They may find members of certain classes (such as sorcerers, rogues, and ~bards~[TAG_BARDS]) to be not quite serious enough, but they're not judgmental.Role: The wizard's role depends somewhat on his spell selection, but most wizards share certain similarities in function. They are among the most offensively minded of the spellcasting classes, with a broad range of options available for neutralizing enemies.Abilities: ~Intelligence~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] determines how powerful a spell a wizard can cast, how many spells he can cast per day, and how hard those spells are to resist. A high ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] score is helpful for a wizard, who typically wears little or no armor, because it provides him with a bonus to ~Armor Class~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS]. A good ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION] score gives a wizard extra ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS], a resource he is otherwise very low on.Class Alignment: AnyHit Die: d4Base Attack and Base Save Bonuses: see ~table~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_WIZARD]Class Skills: ~Concentration~[TAG_CONCENTRATION] and ~Spellcraft~[TAG_SPELLCRAFT]Skill Points at 1st Level: (2 + Int modifier) x 4Skill Points at Each Additional Level: 2 + Int modifierClass Features:[CMD_CHILDREN]
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_DESC:TAG_LEVEL_BONUSE: Class features are special characteristics that belong exclusively to that class.  When applicable, restrictions and disadvantages will also be described.  Class features include aspects such as Weapon and Armor Proficiency, special skills, or spells.
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARBARIAN_DAMAGE_REDU: At 7th level, a barbarian gains the ability to shrug off some amount of injury from each blow or attack.  1 point of damage is subtracted each time a barbarian is dealt damage from a weapon or natural attack.  At 10th level, the damage reduction rises by 1 point, so 2 points of damage total is subtracted at that level.  Damage reduction can reduce damage to 0 but not below 0.
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARBARIAN_FAST_MOVEME: A barbarian's land speed is faster than the norm for his race by +10 feet.  This benefit applies only when he is wearing no armor, light armor, or medium armor, and not carrying a heavy load.  Apply this bonus before modifying the barbarian's speed because of any load carried or armor worn.     For example, a ~human~[TAG_HUMANS] barbarian has a speed of 40 feet, rather than 30 feet, when wearing light or no armor.  When wearing medium armor or carrying a medium load, his speed drops to 30 feet.     A ~halfling~[TAG_HALFLINGS] barbarian has a speed of 30 feet, rather than 20 feet, in light or no armor.  When wearing medium armor or carrying a medium load, his speed drops to 20 feet.
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARBARIAN_IMPROVED_UN: At 5th level and higher, a barbarian can no longer be ~flanked~[TAG_FLANKING]; he can react to opponents on opposite sides of him as easily as he can react to a single attacker.  This defense denies a ~rogue~[TAG_ROGUES] the ability to ~sneak attack~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_ROGUE_SNEAK_ATTACK] the barbarian by flanking him, unless the attacker has at least four more rogue levels than the target has barbarian levels.     If a character already has ~uncanny dodge~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_ROGUE_UNCANNY_DODGE] from a second class, the character automatically gains improved uncanny dodge instead, and the levels from the classes that grant uncanny dodge stack to determine the minimum rogue level required to flank the character.
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARBARIAN_RAGE:TAG_BA: A barbarian can fly into a screaming blood frenzy a certain number of times per day.  In rage, a barbarian gains phenomenal strength and durability but becomes reckless and less able to defend himself.  He temporarily gains a +4 bonus to ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH], a +4 bonus to ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION], and a +2 morale bonus on ~Will~[TAG_WILL] saves, but he takes a -2 to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS].     The Constitution bonus increases the barbarian's ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS] by 2 points per level, but these hit points disappear once the rage ends, at which point his Constitution score drops back to normal.     While raging, a barbarian cannot use skills or abilities that require patience or concentration (such as casting a spell or moving silently).  He can use any feat he may have except for ~Combat Expertise~[TAG_COMBAT_EXPERTISE], ~item creation feats~[TAG_ITEM_CREATION], ~metamagic feats~[TAG_METAMAGIC], and ~Skill Focus~[TAG_SKILL_FOCUS].     A fit of rage lasts for the number of rounds equal to 3 + the character's newly improved Constitution modifier.  At the end of the rage, the barbarian loses the rage modifiers and becomes ~fatigued~[TAG_FATIGUED] (-2 penalty to Strength, -2 penalty to ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY], cannot ~charge~[TAG_CHARGE] or ~run~[TAG_RUN]) for the same number of rounds as the rage lasted.     A barbarian can fly into a fit of rage only once per encounter.  At 1st level, he can use his rage ability once per day.  At 4th level and every 4 levels thereafter, he can use it one additional time per day.  Entering a rage can only be done during the barbarian's action, not in response to someone else's action.  For example, a barbarian can't fly into a rage when struck by an arrow just to get the extra hit points from the Constitution bonus.  Those extra hit points would only be helpful if the barbarian initiated a rage before being struck.
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARBARIAN_TRAP_SENSE:: Starting at 3rd level, a barbarian has an intuitive sense that alerts him to danger from traps, giving him a +1 bonus on ~Reflex~[TAG_REFLEX] saves made to avoid traps and a +1 dodge bonus to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] against attacks made by traps.  These bonuses rise by +1 every three barbarian levels thereafter.  Trap sense bonuses gained from multiple classes stack.
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARBARIAN_UNCANNY_DOD: At 2nd level, a barbarian gains the ability to react to danger before his senses would normally allow him to do so.  He retains his ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] bonus to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] (if any) even if he is caught ~flat-footed~[TAG_FLAT_FOOTED] or struck by an ~invisible~[TAG_INVISIBLE] attacker.  However, he still loses his Dexterity bonus to AC if immobilized.
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARBARIAN_WEAPON_ARMO: A barbarian is proficient with all ~simple~[TAG_SIMPLE_WEAPONS] and ~martial~[TAG_MARTIAL_WEAPONS] weapons, ~light~[TAG_ARMOR_LIGHT] armor, ~medium~[TAG_ARMOR_MEDIUM] armor, and ~shields~[TAG_ARMOR_SHIELD].
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARBARIAN:TAG_DUMMY::: Barbarian Base Attack & Base Save Bonuses
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD_BARDIC_KNOWLEDGE: A bard picks up a lot of stray knowledge while wandering the land and learning stories from other bards.  He may make a special bardic knowledge check with a bonus equal to his bard level + his ~Intelligence~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] modifier to see whether he knows some relevant information about local notable people, legendary items, or noteworthy places.     A successful bardic knowledge check will not reveal the powers of a ~magic item~[TAG_MAGIC_ITEMS] but may give a hint as to its general function.
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD_BARDIC_MUSIC:TAG: Once per day per bard level, a bard can use her song or poetics to produce magical effects on those around her (including herself, if desired).  While these abilities fall under the category of bardic music and include descriptions of singing or playing instruments, they can all also be activated by reciting poetry, chanting, singing lyrics or melodies, etc.  Each ability requires both a minimum bard level and a minimum number of ranks in the ~Perform~[TAG_PERFORM] skill to qualify.     Starting a bardic music effect is a ~standard action~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION].  Some bardic music abilities require concentration, which means the bard must take a standard action each round to maintain the ability.  While using bardic music, a bard can fight but cannot cast spells, activate ~magic items~[TAG_MAGIC_ITEMS] by spell completion (such as scrolls), or activate magic items by magic word (such as wands).  All are mind-affecting abilities.     See ~Countersong~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD_COUNTERSONG], ~Fascinate~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD_FASCINATE], ~Inspire Courage~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD_INSPIRE_COURAGE], ~Inspire Competence~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD_INSPIRE_COMPETENCE], and ~Inspire Greatness~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD_INSPIRE_GREATNESS] for descriptions of the different types of bardic musical abilities.
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD_COUNTERSONG:TAG_: A bard with 3 or more ranks in a ~Perform~[TAG_PERFORM] skill can use her music or poetics to counter magical effects that depend on sound (but not spells that simply have verbal components).  The bard may keep up the countersong for 10 rounds.  Each round of the countersong, she makes a Perform check.  Any creature within 30 feet of the bard (including the bard herself) that is affected by a sonic or language-dependent magical attack (such as a ~Sound Burst~[TAG_SPELLS_SOUND_BURST] or ~Command~[TAG_SPELLS_COMMAND] spell) may use the bard's Perform check result in place of its ~saving throw~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC] if, after the saving throw is rolled, the Perform check result proves to be higher.     If a creature within range of the countersong is already under the effect of a noninstantaneous sonic or language-dependent magical attack, it gains another saving throw against the effect each round it hears the countersong, but it must use the bard's Perform check result for the save.  Countersong will not influence effects that don't allow saves.
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD_FASCINATE:TAG_BA: A bard with 3 or more ranks in a ~Perform~[TAG_PERFORM] skill can use his music or poetics to cause one creature to become ~fascinated~[TAG_FASCINATED].  No other action besides ~movement~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION] can be executed by the bard during the round that the creature is fascinated.  The creature must be within 90 feet and able to see, hear, and pay attention to the bard.  Likewise, the bard must be able to see the creature.     To fascinate, a bard makes a Perform check.  His check result is the DC for the affected creature's ~Will~[TAG_WILL] save against the effect.  If the creature's ~saving throw~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC] is successful, a bard can still attempt to fascinate the same creature as many times as the bard's daily performance limit allows.  If the creature's saving throw fails, it sits and listens to the song for as long as the bard continues to play and concentrate (up to a max of 1 round per bard level).  While fascinated, a target takes a -4 penalty on ~skill checks~[TAG_USING_SKILLS] made as reactions (e.g. ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN] or ~Spot~[TAG_SPOT] checks).     Any potential threat to the target, such as an ally of the bard approaching the creature, requires the bard to make another Perform check and allows the creature a new saving throw against a DC equal to the new Perform check result.  Any obvious threat to the target,  such as someone drawing a weapon or the creature taking damage, automatically breaks the effect and the creature will no longer be fascinated.
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD_INSPIRE_COMPETEN: A bard of 4th level or higher with 7 or more ranks in a ~Perform~[TAG_PERFORM] skill can use his music or poetics to help an ally succeed at a task.  A bard cannot inspire competence in himself.  The ally must be within 30 feet and be able to see and hear the bard; likewise, the bard must be able to see the ally.  Bardic music may be used to lift the ally's spirits, to help them mentally focus, or in some other manner.  The ally gets a +2 competence bonus on ~skill checks~[TAG_USING_SKILLS] with a particular skill as long as they continue to hear the bard's music.  The effect lasts as long as the bard concentrates, up to a maximum of 2 minutes.
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD_INSPIRE_COURAGE:: A bard with 3 or more ranks in a ~Perform~[TAG_PERFORM] skill can use song or poetics to inspire courage in her allies (including herself), bolstering them against fear and improving their combat abilities.  To be affected, an ally must be able to hear the bard sing, and the effect lasts as long as the bard can be heard and for 5 rounds thereafter.  The ally will receive a +1 morale bonus on ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC] against ~charm~[TAG_CHARMED] and ~fear~[TAG_FEAR] effects and a +1 morale bonus on ~attack~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL] and weapon damage rolls.  At 8th level, and every six bard levels thereafter, this bonus increases by 1 (+2 at 8th, +3 at 14th, and +4 at 20th).
TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD_INSPIRE_GREATNES: A bard of 10th level or higher with 13 or more ranks in a ~Perform~[TAG_PERFORM] skill can use music or poetics to inspire greatness in himself or a single willing ally within 30 feet, granting him or her an extra fighting capability.  To inspire greatness, a bard must sing and be heard by an ally.  The effect lasts for as long as the ally hears the bard sing and for 5 rounds thereafter.
