TAG_COMBAT::::2: Combat takes place in rounds. If some of the combatants are unaware that hostilities have begun, those who are aware act in a ~surprise round~[TAG_SURPRISE] before the others. Combatants who have not had an action yet in combat are ~flat-footed~[TAG_FLAT_FOOTED].     Participants in combat first roll for ~initiative~[TAG_INITIATIVE]. The highest result will have the first action, and the other participants will follow in order, from highest to lowest. Ties are broken by comparing ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] scores. The higher Dexterity will go before the lower one in a tie.     The computer will handle all these rolls for you before combat begins by placing the combatants in order of initiative across the top of your screen.In a normal round, your character can perform a ~standard action~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION] and a ~move action~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION], or a ~full-round action~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION]. He or she can always substitute a move action for a standard action. ~Free actions~[TAG_FREE_ACTION] do not count toward either limitation.     In ToEE, actions are categorized as Standard, Move, Full, and Free. You can perform as many Free actions in a round as you wish.     In a single round, you can perform:     - a Full action     - a Standard action and a Move action     - two Move actions     Likewise, if you haven't physically moved in a round, you can perform a ~5-foot step~[TAG_5_FOOT_STEP]. This is an example of an action that does not fit neatly into any category; the 5-foot step and other such examples that are more difficult to classify are known as ~miscellaneous actions~[TAG_MISC_ACTION].In addition to the standard ~combat actions~[TAG_COMBAT_ACTIONS], there are ~special attacks~[TAG_SPECIAL_ATTACKS] and ~special initiative actions~[TAG_SPECIAL_INIT] that can be done.     Specifically, in ToEE, there are several combat options that are available through the use of the ~radial menu~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU], including the following:     ~Cast Defensively~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_CAST_DEFENSIVELY]     ~Deal Nonlethal Damage~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_NONLETHAL_DAMAGE]     ~Fight Defensively~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_FIGHT_DEFENSIVELY]For further descriptions of actual combat within ToEE, please see ~Combat and Game Play~[TAG_COMBAT_AND_GAME_PLAY] and ~Combat Actions~[TAG_COMBAT_ACTIONS].
TAG_STANDARD_ACTION:TAG_ACTION_COST:::2: All of the following are considered standard actions:1.  Attack. An attack can be a standard ~melee attack~[TAG_MELEE_ATTACKS], an ~unarmed attack~[TAG_WEAPONS_STRIKE_UNARMED], which provokes an ~attack of opportunity~[TAG_AOO], or a ~ranged attack~[TAG_RANGED_ATTACKS]. Melee attacks can be done for ~nonlethal damage~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_NONLETHAL_DAMAGE] at a penalty on the ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL] and unarmed attacks can be done for lethal damage at a similar penalty. Some attacks might do extra damage as a result of a ~critical hit~[TAG_CRITICAL_HIT].2. Cast a spell. Most ~spells~[TAG_SPELLS] require a standard action as noted in their description. Casting a spell in an enemy's threat range provokes an attack of opportunity. Depending on distractions, a ~Concentration~[TAG_CONCENTRATION] check may also be required.3. Activate a ~magic item~[TAG_MAGIC_ITEMS].4. Use a special ability.5. ~Total Defense~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_TOTAL_DEFENSE]. This action gives your character a +4 dodge bonus to his ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] for one full turn.6. Start/Complete a ~full-round action~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION]. A character restricted to standard actions only can spend his standard action to start a full-round action and complete it the next round during his standard action.
TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION:TAG_ACTION_COST:::2: The following are considered to be move actions during combat:1.  Move. You may move your character up to his standard ~movement rate~[TAG_MOVEMENT_RATE]. Note that moving through or out of a threatened square provokes an ~attack of opportunity~[TAG_AOO].2. Draw or sheathe a weapon.3. Ready or loose a shield.4. Manipulate an item.5. Direct or redirect a spell. Some ~spells~[TAG_SPELLS] allow you to redirect the effect to new targets or areas after you cast the spell. Although this requires a move action, it does not provoke an attack of opportunity or require concentration.6. Stand up.
TAG_MOVEMENT_RATE:TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION:::: Movement rate is the speed at which your character moves, which may vary according to ~race~[TAG_RACES] and/or level of ~encumbrance~[TAG_ADVENTURING_ENCUMBRANCE]. ~Dwarves~[TAG_DWARVES], ~gnomes~[TAG_GNOMES], and ~halflings~[TAG_HALFLINGS] all move at a base land speed of 20 feet, while ~humans~[TAG_HUMANS], ~elves~[TAG_ELVES], ~half-elves~[TAG_HALF_ELVES], and ~half-orcs~[TAG_HALF_ORCS] all move at a base land speed of 30 feet.
TAG_FREE_ACTION:TAG_ACTION_COST:::2: Free actions don't take any time at all and can be performed without limit. These are as follows:1.  Drop an item.2. Drop ~prone~[TAG_PRONE]. (Note: In ToEE, this action has not been implemented.)3. Speak. However, in ToEE, using the "~Talk~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_TALK]" command is a ~full-round action~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION] that usually can only be done ~Out of Combat~[TAG_OUT_OF_COMBAT].4. Cease ~concentration~[TAG_STOP_CONCENTRATION] on a spell.5. Cast a ~Quickened~[TAG_QUICKEN_SPELL] spell.
TAG_COMBAT_ACTIONS:TAG_COMBAT:::2: There are many actions a character can take during combat.  All actions have an ~action cost~[TAG_ACTION_COST].  Some actions provoke ~attacks of opportunity~[TAG_AOO].~Standard Actions~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION]~Movement Actions~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION]~Free Actions~[TAG_FREE_ACTION]~Full-Round Actions~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION]~Miscellaneous Actions~[TAG_MISC_ACTION][CMD_CHILDREN_SORTED]See also:~Special Attacks~[TAG_SPECIAL_ATTACKS]~Special Initiative Actions~[TAG_SPECIAL_INIT]
TAG_COMBAT_AND_GAME_PLAY:TAG_COMBAT:::2: When entering combat, a row of character and monster portraits will appear at the top of the screen, in order of ~initiative~[TAG_INITIATIVE], which is determined by the computer.  On the left side of the screen, a bar will appear.  The combat system in the game translates the actions you have available into a numerical score and displays that score as a bar, with three colors.  The action bar, path movement, and the entries on the ~radial menu~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU] are all color coded as follows:Green:  An action can be performed, and you will still be able to attack afterward (for ~move actions~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION]) or move afterward (for attacks).Yellow: An action can be performed, but you will not be able to attack afterward (for move actions) or move much (for attacks).Red: An action cannot be performed.Combat options that fall into the categories of ~full-round~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION], ~standard~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION], ~movement~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION], and ~free~[TAG_FREE_ACTION] actions can be selected in the radial menu, provided you are still able to perform these actions (otherwise, they will be "greyed out" and you cannot select them).If you choose not to select anything from the radial menu, the only remaining option is simply to move the distance that the characters are allowed (for example, ~humans~[TAG_HUMANS] can move a maximum of 30 feet in a single move).
TAG_MODIFIER:TAG_COMBAT:::2: A modifier is any bonus or penalty applying to a die roll.  A positive modifier is a bonus, and a negative modifier is a penalty.Modifier Types~Ability Modifiers~[TAG_ABILITY_MODIFIERS][CMD_CHILDREN_SORTED]
TAG_ARMOR_BONUS:TAG_MODIFIER:::2: A bonus to ~Armor Class~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] granted by ~armor~[TAG_ARMOR] or by a ~spell~[TAG_SPELLS] or magical effect that mimics armor.  Armor bonuses stack with all other bonuses to Armor Class (even with natural armor bonuses) except other armor bonuses.  Magic armor typically grants an ~enhancement~[TAG_ENHANCEMENT] bonus to the armor's armor bonus, which has the effect of increasing the armor's overall bonus.  An armor bonus granted by a spell or ~magic item~[TAG_MAGIC_ITEMS] typically takes the form of an invisible, tangible field of force around the recipient.  An armor bonus doesn't apply against touch attacks, except for armor bonuses granted by force effects (such as the ~Mage Armor~[TAG_SPELLS_MAGE_ARMOR] spell) which apply against incorporeal touch attacks, such as that of a ~shadow~[TAG_MONSTER_SHADOW].
TAG_DEFLECTION_BONUS:TAG_MODIFIER:::2: A bonus to ~Armor Class~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] granted by a ~spell~[TAG_SPELLS] or magic effect that makes attacks veer off harmlessly.  Deflection bonuses stack with all other bonuses to AC except other deflection bonuses.  A deflection bonus applies against touch attacks.
TAG_ENHANCEMENT_BONUS:TAG_MODIFIER:::2: A bonus that represents an increase in the sturdiness and/or effectiveness of ~armor~[TAG_ARMOR] or natural armor, the effectiveness of a ~weapon~[TAG_WEAPONS], or a general bonus to an ~ability~[TAG_THE_ABILITIES] score.  Multiple enhancement bonuses on the same object (in the case of armor and weapons), creature (in the case of natural armor), or ability score do not stack.  Only the highest enhancement bonus applies.  Since enhancement bonuses to armor or natural armor effectively increase the armor or natural armor's bonus to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS], they don't apply against touch attacks.The following is a list of available enhancements (and special abilities) to weapons and armor through the ~Craft Magic Arms and Armor~[TAG_CRAFT_MAA] feat:Weapon Enhancement+1+2+3Weapon Special Ability~Defending~[TAG_DEFENDING]~Flaming~[TAG_FLAMING]~Frost~[TAG_FROST]~Shock~[TAG_SHOCK]~Keen~[TAG_KEEN]~Mighty Cleaving~[TAG_MIGHTY_CLEAVING]~Flaming Burst~[TAG_FLAMING_BURST]~Icy Burst~[TAG_ICY_BURST]~Shocking Burst~[TAG_SHOCKING_BURST]~Holy~[TAG_HOLY]~Unholy~[TAG_UNHOLY]~Axiomatic~[TAG_AXIOMATIC]~Anarchic~[TAG_ANARCHIC]Armor Enhancement+1+2+3Armor Special Ability~Silent Moves~[TAG_SILENT_MOVES]~Spell Resistance (13)~[TAG_MAGIC_ARMOR_SPELL_RESISTANCE]
TAG_SHIELD_BONUS:TAG_MODIFIER:::2: A bonus to ~Armor Class~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] granted by a ~shield~[TAG_ARMOR_SHIELD] or by a ~spell~[TAG_SPELLS] or magic effect that mimics a shield.  Shield bonuses stack with all other bonuses to AC except other shield bonuses.  A magic shield typically grants an ~enhancement~[TAG_ENHANCEMENT] bonus to the shield's shield bonus, which has the effect of increasing the shield's overall bonus to AC.  A shield bonus granted by a spell or magic item typically takes the form of an invisible, tangible field of force that protects the recipient.  A shield bonus doesn't apply against touch attacks.
TAG_5_FOOT_STEP:TAG_COMBAT:::2: A small position adjustment that does not count as an action.  Usually, a 5-foot step is permitted at any point in the round (such as before or after a ~full-round action~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION], between attacks in a full attack, between a ~standard action~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION] and a ~move action~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION], or between two move actions).You can't take a 5-foot step:   - in the same round that you move any distance   - if your movement is hampered, such as into a square of difficult terrain, in darkness, or when ~blinded~[TAG_BLINDED]Taking a 5-foot step does not provoke an ~attack of opportunity~[TAG_AOO].
TAG_AOO:TAG_COMBAT:::2: A single extra ~melee attack~[TAG_MELEE_ATTACKS] per round that a combatant can make when an opponent within reach takes an action which provokes an attack of opportunity.  Actions which provoke attacks of opportunity include casting a spell, using a ranged weapon, and moving through a threatened area.In ToEE, all characters automatically make the first attack of opportunity which presents itself.
TAG_ARMOR_CLASS:TAG_COMBAT:::2: Armor Class (AC) is a number representing a character's ability to avoid being hit in combat.  Higher numbers are better.An opponent's ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL] must equal or exceed the target's Armor Class to hit it.A character's Armor Class is 10 + all applicable modifiers (typically ~armor~[TAG_ARMOR_BONUS] bonus, ~shield~[TAG_SHIELD_BONUS] bonus, ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] modifier, and ~size~[TAG_SIZE_MODIFIER] modifier).
TAG_ATTACK_ROLL:TAG_COMBAT:::2: When making attack, a twenty-sided die (1d20) is rolled to determine if you hit.  Your attack bonus is added to the roll.  If your roll equals or exceeds your opponents ~Armor Class~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS], you score a hit and roll damage.  If you roll a natural twenty, you may score a ~critical hit~[TAG_CRITICAL_HIT] and may inflict double damage or more.
TAG_CONCEALMENT:TAG_COMBAT:::2: Concealment encompasses all circumstances where nothing physically blocks a blow or shot but where something interferes with an attacker's accuracy.  If a defender has concealment, the attacker must pass a concealment check before an attacker is even allowed to make an ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL].  Some magical effects (such as ~Blur~[TAG_SPELLS_BLUR] and ~Displacement~[TAG_SPELLS_DISPLACEMENT]) provide concealment.Partial concealment gives the subject of an attack a 20% chance that the attack is an automatic miss.  If the attacker rolls higher than 20 percent, he has passed the concealment check but still has to hit with a standard attack roll.Total concealment occurs when the attacker can't see the target, for example when the attacker is ~blinded~[TAG_BLINDED] or the defender is ~invisible~[TAG_INVISIBLE].  An attacker attacking someone with total concealment has a 50% miss chance.If the attacker has the ~Blind-Fight~[TAG_BLIND_FIGHT] feat, he gets two chances to pass any concealment checks.
TAG_COVER:TAG_COMBAT:::2: Targets which take cover behind a low obstacle or another creature get a +4 bonus to their ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS].You can view which creatures or objects are providing cover by holding down the left mouse button when attacking.  Cover is indicated by a red circle.
TAG_CRITICAL_HIT:TAG_COMBAT:::2: When you make an ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL] and get a natural 20, you hit regardless of your target's ~Armor Class~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS], and you have scored a threat.  The hit might be a critical hit.  To find out if it's a critical hit, you immediately make a critical roll--another attack roll with all the same modifiers as the attack roll you just made.  If the critical roll also results in a hit against the target's AC, you original hit is a critical hit.  If the critical roll is a miss, then your hit is just a regular hit.A critical hit means that you roll your damage twice, with all your usual bonuses, and add the rolls together.Some weapons have a threat range is greater than 20.  That is, you can score a threat on a lower number.  ~Longswords~[TAG_WEAPONS_LONGSWORD], for example, give you a threat on a natural attack roll of 19 or 20.  In such cases, a roll of lower than 20 is not an automatic hit.  Any attack roll that doesn't result in a hit is not a threat.Some weapons, such as ~battle axes~[TAG_WEAPONS_BATTLEAXE] and ~arrows~[TAG_WEAPONS_ARROWS], deal better than double damage on a critical hit.Bonus damage represented as extra dice, such as from a ~sneak attack ~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_ROGUE_SNEAK_ATTACK] or a ~flaming~[TAG_FLAMING] sword, is not multiplied when you score a critical hit.Some creatures, such as undead, are immune to critical hits.
TAG_DISMISS_SPELL:TAG_COMBAT::TAG_COMBAT: Dismissing an active spell is a ~standard action~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION] that does not provoke ~attacks of opportunity~[TAG_AOO].
TAG_FLANKING:TAG_COMBAT:::2: When making a ~melee attack~[TAG_MELEE_ATTACKS], you get a +2 flanking bonus if your opponent is threatened by a character or creature friendly to you on the opponent's opposite side or opposite corner.When in doubt about whether two friendly characters flank an opponent in the middle, trace an imaginary line between the two friendly characters' centers.  If the line passes through opposite sides of the opponent's space (including corners of those sides), then the opponent is flanked.Exception: If a flanker takes up more than 1 square, it gets the flanking bonus if any square it occupies counts for flanking.Only a creature or character that threatens the defender can help an attacker get a flanking bonus.Creatures with a reach of 0 feet can't flank an opponent.
TAG_HELPLESS:TAG_COMBAT:::2: An opponent who is bound, ~sleeping~[TAG_SLEEPING], ~paralyzed~[TAG_PARALYZED], ~unconscious~[TAG_UNCONSCIOUS], or otherwise at your mercy is considered helpless.A helpless character takes a -4 penalty to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] against ~melee attacks~[TAG_MELEE_ATTACKS], but no penalty to AC against ~ranged attacks~[TAG_RANGED_ATTACKS].  A helpless defender can't use any ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] bonus to AC.  In fact, his Dexterity score is treated as if it were 0 and his Dexterity modifier to AC as if it were -5 (and a ~rogue~[TAG_ROGUES] can ~sneak attack~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_ROGUE_SNEAK_ATTACK] him).As a ~full-round action~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION], you can use a melee weapon to deliver a ~coup de grace~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_COUP_DE_GRACE] to a helpless opponent.
TAG_INITIATIVE:TAG_COMBAT:::2: Your character's initiative is a number assigned by the computer that determines when you will take your turn in combat (as well as determining the order that everyone else will take their turns).
TAG_MELEE_ATTACKS:TAG_COMBAT::TAG_COMBAT: With a normal melee weapon, you can strike any opponent within 5 feet.  (Opponents within 5 feet are considered adjacent to you.)  Some melee weapons have reach.  With a typical reach weapon, you can strike opponents 10 feet away and in ToEE, you can strike adjacent foes (those within 5 feet).  A melee attack is a ~standard action~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION].In order to damage your opponent you must succeed at an ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL].
TAG_MULTIPLE_ATTACKS:TAG_COMBAT::TAG_COM: If you get more than one attack per round because your ~base attack bonus~[TAG_LEVEL_BONUSES] is high enough, because you fight with ~two weapons~[TAG_TWO_WEAPONS], or for some special reason (such as a ~feat~[TAG_FEATS] or a ~magic item~[TAG_MAGIC_ITEMS]), you must use a ~full-round action~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION] to get your additional attacks.  You do not need to specify the targets of your attacks ahead of time.  You can see how the earlier attacks turn out before assigning the later ones.Each attack gets it's own ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL].
TAG_NORMAL_DAMAGE:TAG_COMBAT:::2: When your attack succeeds, whether it be with a weapon, a spell, or another form of combat, you deal damage.  Damage reduces a target's current ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS].
TAG_OUT_OF_COMBAT:TAG_COMBAT:::2: Out of Combat describes a spell casting time (or any action) that is anything longer than a round during combat.
TAG_RANGE_PENALTY:TAG_COMBAT:::2: The range penalty for a ranged weapon depends on the weapon and the distance to the target.  All ranged weapons have a range increment, such as 10 feet for a thrown ~dagger~[TAG_WEAPONS_DAGGER] or 120 feet for a ~heavy crossbow~[TAG_WEAPONS_CROSSBOW_HEAVY].  Any attack from a distance of less than one range increment is not penalized for range, so an ~arrow~[TAG_WEAPONS_ARROWS] from a ~shortbow~[TAG_WEAPONS_SHORTBOW] (range increment 60 feet) can strike at enemies up to 59 feet away with no penalty.  However, each full range increment cases a cumulative -2 penalty on the ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL].  A shortbow archer firing at a target 200 feet away takes a -6 penalty on his attack roll (because 200 feet is at least three range increments, but not four increments).
TAG_RANGED_ATTACKS:TAG_COMBAT::TAG_COMBA: With a ranged weapon, you can shoot or throw at any target that is within the weapon's maximum range (see ~Range Penalty~[TAG_RANGE_PENALTY]) and in line of sight.  The maximum range for a ~thrown weapon~[TAG_THROW_WEAPON] is five range increments.In order to damage your opponent you must succeed at an ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL].
TAG_MELEE_SHOOTING:TAG_COMBAT::TAG_COMBA: Shooting or Throwing into a Melee

If you shoot or throw a ranged weapon at a target engaged in melee with a friendly character, you take a -4 penalty on your ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL] because you have to aim carefully to avoid hitting your friend.  Two characters are engaged in melee if they are enemies of each other and either threatens the other.  (An ~unconscious~[TAG_UNCONSCIOUS] or otherwise immobilized character is not considered engaged unless he is actually being attacked.)If your target (or the part of your target you're aiming at, if it's a big target) is at least 10 feet away from the nearest friendly character, you can avoid the -4 penalty, even if the creature you're aiming at is engaged in melee with a friendly character.If you have the ~Precise Shot~[TAG_PRECISE_SHOT] feat, you don't take this penalty.
TAG_SIZE_MODIFIER:TAG_COMBAT::TAG_MODIFI: The smaller you are, the bigger other creatures are relative to you. A ~human~[TAG_HUMANS] is a big target to a ~halfling~[TAG_HALFLINGS], just as an ogre is a big target to a human.  Since this same size modifier applies to ~Armor Class~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS], two creatures of the same size strike each other normally, regardless of what size they actually are.Size / Size Modifier:Fine  (+8)Diminutive (+4)Tiny  (+2)Small  (+1)Medium (+0)Large  (-1)Huge (-2)Gargantuan (-4)Colossal (-8)
TAG_SPECIAL_INIT:TAG_COMBAT:::2: Delay: If you would prefer for your character to move after someone else within the combat round, you can elect to Delay your action.  To do this, simply click and drag the character portrait at the top of the screen to the location in the order of when you would like that character to act.  However, if the character has already taken his turn, moving him to a lower ~initiative~[TAG_INITIATIVE] will not allow him to act again, and if he has not yet taken his actions for his turn, then moving him to an initiative higher than the current combatant will forfeit his turn for this round.Ready: You may also choose to Ready an action, dependent on something that the enemy does, such as prepare to cast a spell or shoot a bow.  In this case, as soon as the condition is achieved, the character will immediately enact his readied action.  If the condition is not achieved, then that character fails to act in that round.     For more information on Ready actions, see the ~Ready~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_READY] action list in the ~radial menu~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU].
TAG_STOP_CONCENTRATION:TAG_COMBAT::TAG_C: You must concentrate to cast (or maintain) a spell.  If you are unable to concentrate, the spell can't be cast (or maintained).  If you start casting (or are maintaining) a spell but something interferes with your concentration, such as a creature taking an ~attack of opportunity~[TAG_AOO] to hit you with its club, you must make a ~Concentration~[TAG_CONCENTRATION] check or lose the spell.
TAG_SURPRISE:TAG_COMBAT:::2: In combat, if one or more characters gain surprise, they are allowed to act in the surprise round, before anyone else gets a chance to react.  Characters not acting in the surprise round are ~flat-footed~[TAG_FLAT_FOOTED].Characters are allowed to make one ~standard action~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION] in the surprise round and as many ~free actions~[TAG_FREE_ACTION] as they want.
TAG_THROW_WEAPON:TAG_STANDARD_ACTION::TA: Some weapons can be thrown as an attack.  If you hit, your ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] bonus is applied to the damage.  All bonuses and penalties applicable to ranged weapons apply to the thrown weapon.  Throwing a weapon, like any other ~ranged attack~[TAG_RANGED_ATTACKS], incurs an ~attack of opportunity~[TAG_AOO].
TAG_TOUCH_ATTACK:TAG_COMBAT:::2: Touch attacks are used with spells that have a range of touch.  To use these spells, you cast the spell and then touch the subject.Since you need only touch your enemy, you make a touch attack instead of a regular attack.  Touching an opponent with a touch spell is considered to be an armed attack and therefore does not provoke ~attacks of opportunity~[TAG_AOO] when it is discharged on an armed opponent.  However, the act of casting a spell does provoke an attack of opportunity, so you may want to cast the spell and then move to the target instead of vice versa.Touch attacks come in two types:   -Melee touch attacks: for touches made with your hand   -Ranged touch attacks: for touches made with magic rays, for exampleSome touch attacks allow the caster to ~hold a charge~[TAG_HOLDING_A_CHARGE] of the spell.
TAG_FULL_ATTACK:TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION:::: A full attack allows you to use all of your attacks in a given round, if you have multiple attacks.  If you do not have multiple attacks, you do not need to use this attack.You may have multiple attacks because your ~Base Attack Bonus~[TAG_LEVEL_BONUSES] is high enough to allow it or you use ~two weapons~[TAG_TWO_WEAPONS] to fight.To make a full attack, select full attack from the ~radial menu~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU].  The number of attacks you have will be indicated by a number next to the cursor.  Click on an opponent to use an attack.  You may also use ~Trip~[TAG_TRIP], ~Stunning Fist~[TAG_STUNNING_FIST], ~Throw~[TAG_THROW_WEAPON], make a touch attack, or other actions from the radial menu which are equivalent to an attack.
TAG_CAST_FULL:TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION:::2: Some spells require a full round to cast. Others may be cast in a full round, such as a ~bard~[TAG_BARDS] or ~sorcerer~[TAG_SORCERERS] choosing to make a ~standard action~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION] spell a ~metamagic~[TAG_METAMAGIC] one.
TAG_USE_FULL:TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION:::2: Depending on the special ability, some require a full-round action to execute.
TAG_WITHDRAW:TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION:::2: You can move away from an opponent at double your ~movement rate~[TAG_MOVEMENT_RATE], without provoking an ~attack of opportunity~[TAG_AOO], using this a ~full-round action~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION].
TAG_RUN:TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION:::2: A character can run as a ~full-round action~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION] up to 4 times his or her normal ~movement rate~[TAG_MOVEMENT_RATE] in a straight line.  A character will run at 3 times his or her normal speed if they are wearing heavy armor.  Running provokes an ~attack of opportunity~[TAG_AOO].
TAG_AID_ANOTHER:TAG_DUMMY:::2: In combat, you can help a friend attack or defend by distracting or interfering with opponents.  Select a friendly target.  That target gains a +2 bonus to his ~attack rolls~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL] until your next turn.You can also use this action to wake a friend under the influence of a ~Sleep~[TAG_SPELLS_SLEEP] spell.Aiding another is a ~standard action~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION] which does not provoke an ~attack of opportunity~[TAG_AOO].
TAG_BULLRUSH:TAG_DUMMY:::2: To make a bull rush, you attempt to push an enemy back.You initiate this by moving into your opponent's square, which provokes an ~attack of opportunity~[TAG_AOO].Then you make opposed ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] checks.  If you succeed, you can push your opponent back 5 feet.Note: In ToEE, the Bull Rush attack has not been implemented.
TAG_CHARGE:TAG_SPECIAL_ATTACKS:::2: You move at least 5 feet or up to as much as double your normal speed directly toward your opponent.  You must have a clear straight-line path with nothing that can hinder your movement (such as difficult terrain or obstacles) toward the opponent.  After moving, you make a single attack, which results in a +2 bonus on the ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL].  You also take a -2 penalty to your ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] until the start of your next turn.  A charge attack is a ~full-round action~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION].
TAG_FEINT:TAG_SPECIAL_ATTACKS:::2: To feint, make a ~Bluff~[TAG_BLUFF] check opposed by a ~Sense Motive~[TAG_SENSE_MOTIVE] check by your target.  If your Bluff check result exceeds your target's Sense Motive check result, the next ~melee attack~[TAG_MELEE_ATTACKS] you make against the target does not allow him to use his ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] bonus to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS].  A feint is a ~full-round action~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION].If you have the ~Improved Feint~[TAG_IMPROVED_FEINT] feat, a feint is a ~move action~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION].
TAG_GRAPPLE:TAG_DUMMY:::2: Grappling means wrestling and struggling hand-to-hand.  It's tricky to perform, but sometimes you want to pin foes instead of killing them, and sometimes you have no choice in the matter.A grapple check is like a melee ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL].  Your attack bonus on a grapple check is:    ~base attack bonus~[TAG_LEVEL_BONUSES] + ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] modifier + special size modifierThe special size modifier for a grapple check is as follows: Colossal (+16), Gargantuan (+12), Huge (+8), Large (+4), Medium (+0), Small (-4), Tiny (-8), Diminutive (-12), Fine (-16)     Use this number in place of the normal ~size~[TAG_SIZE_MODIFIER] modifier you use when making an attack roll.The steps to attempt a grapple are:1.  Provoke an ~attack of opportunity~[TAG_AOO].2. Perform a melee touch attack to grab the opponent.3. Make an opposed grapple check as a ~free action~[TAG_FREE_ACTION].If you succeed, your opponent is ~grappled~[TAG_GRAPPLING].Note: In ToEE, this attack has only been implemented for enemy creatures, such as a ~Giant Frog~[TAG_MONSTER_GIANT_FROG].
TAG_TRIP:TAG_SPECIAL_ATTACKS:::2: To make a trip attack, make a melee touch attack against your target.  This provokes an ~attack of opportunity~[TAG_AOO] from your target.  If your attack succeeds, make a ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] check opposed by the defender's ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] or Strength check (whichever has the higher modifier).  If you win, you trip the defender and he falls ~prone~[TAG_PRONE].  If you lose, the defender will immediately react and make a Strength check opposed by your Dexterity or Strength check to try to trip you.A combatant gets a +4 bonus for every ~size~[TAG_SIZE_MODIFIER] category he is larger than medium.  He gets a -4 penalty for every size category he is smaller than medium.  A defender gets a +4 bonus if he has more than two legs or is otherwise more stable than a normal humanoid (such as a ~dwarf~[TAG_DWARVES]).If you have the ~Improved Trip~[TAG_IMPROVED_TRIP] feat, you don't provoke an attack of opportunity for making a trip attack.Some creatures, such as those which fly or slither like a snake, cannot be tripped.
TAG_TURN:TAG_SPECIAL_ATTACKS:::2: Good ~clerics~[TAG_CLERICS], ~paladins~[TAG_PALADINS], and some neutral clerics can channel positive energy to halt, drive off (rout), or destroy undead.Evil clerics and some neutral clerics can channel negative energy to hold, awe (rebuke), control (command), or bolster undead.Regardless of the effect, the general term for the activity is called "~turning~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_CLERIC_TURN_REBUKE_UNDEAD]".
TAG_TWO_WEAPONS:TAG_SPECIAL_ATTACKS:::2: If you wield a second weapon in your off hand, you can get one extra attack per round with that weapon.  Fighting in this way is very hard, however, and you suffer a -6 penalty to your regular attack or attacks with your primary hand and a -10 penalty to the attack with your off hand.  You can reduce these penalties in the following ways:  - If your off-hand weapon is light, the penalties are reduced by 2 each.  - The ~Two-Weapon Fighting~[TAG_TWO_FIGHTING] feat lessens the primary hand penalty by 2, and the off-hand penalty by 6.
TAG_MISC_ACTION:TAG_COMBAT:::2: These actions do not fit neatly into any category. They are as follows:1. Take a ~5-foot step~[TAG_5_FOOT_STEP]. A character may make one 5-foot step per round, and you can't take a 5-foot step in a round when your character moves any distance. Taking a 5-foot step does not provoke an ~attack of opportunity~[TAG_AOO], but it is the only movement that character can do that round.1. Use a ~feat~[TAG_FEATS]. Each feat has its own dependencies for combat, and some are not allowed in combat at all. Refer to the feats list for detailed descriptions.2. Use a ~skill~[TAG_SKILLS]. Most skills require a standard action, but some may be different. Refer to the skills list for detailed descriptions.
TAG_RADIAL_MENU:TAG_INGAME::TAG_COMBAT T: You can control your character's actions by use of the radial menu in the game.You can bring up the radial menu by right-clicking on the character of your choice. Spokes off the menu will guide you to your desired action. Simply move the cursor over the type of action you wish to perform and further spokes will extend out of the menu as necessary until your desired choice of action appears.     All actions are color coded during ~combat~[TAG_COMBAT], so that any that will complete actions for your turn (except ~free actions~[TAG_FREE_ACTION]) are yellow, any that will allow for further actions to take place are green, and any that are not allowed this turn are red.The radial menu features four icons (Sword, Person, Hammer & Anvil, and Backpack) from which the spokes emanate. The Hand icon will appear if your character has the feats that can be set or require activation. The Star icon will appear if your character is a spellcaster.1) Sword Icon:          Movement:                       ~5-foot Step~[TAG_5_FOOT_STEP]                       ~Break Free~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_BREAK_FREE]                       Flee Combat                       ~Move~[TAG_ADVENTURING_MOVE]                       ~Run~[TAG_RUN]                       ~Withdraw~[TAG_WITHDRAW]          Offense:                        ~Charge Attack~[TAG_CHARGE]                        ~Coup de Grace~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_COUP_DE_GRACE]                        ~Full Attack~[TAG_FULL_ATTACK]                        ~Reload~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_RELOAD]                        ~Single Attack~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION]                        ~Throw Weapon~[TAG_THROW_WEAPON]                        ~Trip Attack~[TAG_TRIP]                        ~Whirlwind Attack~[TAG_WHIRLWIND_ATTACK]          Options:                       ~Cast Defensively~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_CAST_DEFENSIVELY]                       ~Deal Nonlethal Damage~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_NONLETHAL_DAMAGE] or ~Deal Normal Damage~[TAG_NORMAL_DAMAGE]                       ~Fight Defensively~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_FIGHT_DEFENSIVELY]          Tactical:                        ~Feint~[TAG_FEINT]                        ~Ready~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_READY] (ready an action vs. an enemy action)                             ~Ready vs. Approach~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_READY_APPROACH]                             ~Ready vs. Spell~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_READY_SPELL]                             ~Ready vs. Withdrawl~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_READY_WITHDRAWL]                             ~Ready: Counterspell~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_READY_COUNTERSPELL]                        ~Total Defense~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_TOTAL_DEFENSE]2) Person Icon:     Clicking on this icon will make the "~Talk~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_TALK]" option appear. This is used as the primary way to talk to NPCs that join your party.     A ~barbarian~[TAG_BARBARIANS] can activate his ~Barbarian Rage~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARBARIAN_RAGE] ability.     A ~bard~[TAG_BARDS] can play any ~Bardic Music~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARD_BARDIC_MUSIC].     A ~cleric~[TAG_CLERICS] or ~paladin~[TAG_PALADINS] can ~Turn or Rebuke Undead~[TAG_TURN].     A cleric can also use a granted ~Domain~[TAG_DOMAINS] power.     A paladin can also use his ~Detect Evil~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_PALADIN_DETECT_EVIL], ~Lay on Hands~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_PALADIN_LAY_ON_HANDS], ~Remove Disease~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_PALADIN_REMOVE_DISEASE], or ~Smite Evil~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_PALADIN_SMITE_EVIL] abilities.     A ~druid~[TAG_DRUIDS] or ~ranger~[TAG_RANGERS] can bring forth an ~Animal Companion~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_ANIMAL_COMPANION].     A druid can also use her ~Wild Shape~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_DRUID_WILD_SHAPE] ability.     A ~monk~[TAG_MONKS] can set her ~Flurry of Blows~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_MONK_FLURRY_OF_BLOWS] or use her ~Wholeness of Body~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_MONK_WHOLENESS_OF_BODY] abilities.     A ~wizard~[TAG_WIZARDS] can copy scrolls into his ~spellbook~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_WIZARD_SPELLBOOK].     A ~sorcerer~[TAG_SORCERERS] or wizard can call or dismiss a ~familiar~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_CALL_FAMILIAR].3) Hand Icon:     Your character may use or set several feats: ~Combat Expertise~[TAG_COMBAT_EXPERTISE], ~Manyshot~[TAG_MANYSHOT], ~Power Attack~[TAG_POWER_ATTACK], ~Rapid Shot~[TAG_RAPID_SHOT], ~Stunning Fist~[TAG_STUNNING_FIST], ~Track~[TAG_TRACK], or any ~Item Creation~[TAG_ITEM_CREATION] feat4) Hammer & Anvil Icon:                       ~Heal~[TAG_HEAL]                       ~Sneak~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_SNEAK]                       ~Search~[TAG_SEARCH] (concentrated)     You can also use skills that require training, such as ~Disable Device~[TAG_DISABLE_DEVICE], ~Open Lock~[TAG_OPEN_LOCK], ~Sleight of Hand~[TAG_SLEIGHT] and ~Use Magic Device~[TAG_UMD].5) Star Icon:     Your character can cast Bard, Cleric, Druid, Paladin, Ranger, Sorcerer, or Wizard ~spells~[TAG_SPELLS] for the corresponding class.     Your spellcaster might be able to use ~Dismiss Spell~[TAG_DISMISS_SPELL] or ~Stop Concentration~[TAG_STOP_CONCENTRATION] on an active spell.6) Backpack Icon:     Inventory: You will be able to select your character's ~inventory~[TAG_HMU_CHAR_INVENTORY_UI] and view your character's ~skills~[TAG_SKILLS], ~feats~[TAG_FEATS], spells, ~abilities~[TAG_THE_ABILITIES]; as well as view the character's items and basic stats.     You can also ~activate defending weapons~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_ACTIVATE_DEFENDING_WEAPON], ~set charges~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_STAFF_OF_STRIKING] on a magic weapon, activate magic weapons (such as a ~Dagger of Venom~[TAG_WEAPONS_DAGGER_OF_VENOM]), use ~magic items~[TAG_MAGIC_ITEMS], use potions, use scrolls, use wands, or summon a called familiar as a party member.
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_ACTIVATE_DEFENDING_WEAPO: A defending weapon allows the wielder to transfer some or all of the weapon's ~enhancement~[TAG_ENHANCEMENT_BONUS] bonus to his ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] as a bonus that stacks with all others.  As a ~free action~[TAG_FREE_ACTION], the wielder chooses how to allocate the weapon's enhancement bonus at the start of his turn before using the weapon, and the effect to AC lasts until his next turn.
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_AUTOEND_TURN:TAG_DUMMY::: AutoEnd Turn will conclude your turn if a ~5-foot step~[TAG_5_FOOT_STEP] is your only remaining option.  If you would like to take a 5-foot step as your last action in combat, be sure not to enable this option.
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_BREAK_FREE:TAG_INGAME::T: You can break free from a ~grapple~[TAG_GRAPPLING] by winning an opposed grapple check (see ~Grapple~[TAG_GRAPPLE]) in place of making an attack.  If more than one opponent is grappling you, your grapple check result has to beat all of their individual check results to escape.  If you escape, you finish the action by moving into any space adjacent to your opponent or opponents.You can also break free from being ~entangled~[TAG_ENTANGLED].  If you become entangled from a spell, such as ~Entangle~[TAG_SPELLS_ENTANGLE] or ~Web~[TAG_SPELLS_WEB], you can break free (see spell description).
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_CAST_DEFENSIVELY:TAG_ING: You may attempt to cast a spell while paying attention to threats and avoiding blows.  In this case, you are no more vulnerable to attack than you would be if you were just standing there, so casting a spell while on the defensive does not provoke an ~attack of opportunity~[TAG_AOO].  It does, however, require a ~Concentration~[TAG_CONCENTRATION] check to pull off.  Failure means that you lose the spell.
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_COUP_DE_GRACE:TAG_INGAME: As a ~full-round action~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION], you can use a melee weapon to deliver a coup de grace to a ~helpless~[TAG_HELPLESS] opponent.  You automatically hit and score a ~critical hit~[TAG_CRITICAL_HIT].  If the defender survives the damage, he must make a ~Fortitude~[TAG_FORTITUDE] save (DC 10 + the damage dealt) or die.~Asleep~[TAG_SLEEPING], ~paralyzed~[TAG_PARALYZED] or ~unconscious~[TAG_UNCONSCIOUS] opponents are all considered helpless.Delivering a coup de grace provokes ~attacks of opportunity~[TAG_AOO] from threatening opponents.A coup de grace is the best way to kill ~regenerating~[TAG_REGENERATION] monsters once they have become unconscious.
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_FIGHT_DEFENSIVELY:TAG_IN: As a ~standard action~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION]:     You can choose to fight defensively when attacking.  If you do so, you take a -4 penalty on all attacks in a round to gain a +2 dodge bonus to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] for the same round.  This bonus stacks with the AC bonus granted by the ~Combat Expertise~[TAG_COMBAT_EXPERTISE] feat.As a ~full round action~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION]:     You can choose to fight defensively when taking a ~full attack~[TAG_FULL_ATTACK] action.  If you do so, you take a -4 penalty on all attacks in a round to gain a +2 dodge bonus to AC for the same round.
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_NONLETHAL_DAMAGE:TAG_ING: Sometimes you get roughened up or weakened, such as by getting clocked in a fistfight or tired out by a forced march.  This sort of trauma won't kill you, but it can knock you out or make you ~fatigued~[TAG_FATIGUED].If you take sufficient nonlethal damage, you fall ~unconscious~[TAG_UNCONSCIOUS] but you don't die.  Nonlethal damage goes away much faster than lethal damage does.Dealing Nonlethal Damage:     Certain attacks deal nonlethal damage, such as a ~human's~[TAG_HUMANS] ~unarmed strike~[TAG_WEAPONS_STRIKE_UNARMED].  Other effects, such as heat or being ~exhausted~[TAG_EXHAUSTED], also deal nonlethal damage.  Technically, nonlethal damage is not "real" damage (meaning it's not deducted from your current ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS]).  Instead, when your nonlethal damage equals your current hit points, you're ~staggered~[TAG_STAGGERED], and when it exceeds your current hit points, you fall unconscious.Nonlethal Damage with a Weapon that Deal Lethal Damage:     You can use a melee weapon that deals lethal damage to deal nonlethal damage instead, but you take a -4 penalty on your ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL] because you have to use the flat of the blade, strike at nonvital areas, or check your swing.Lethal Damage with a Weapon that Deals Nonlethal Damage:     You can use a weapon that deals nonlethal damage, including an unarmed strike, to deal lethal damage instead, but you take a -4 penalty on your attack roll because you have to strike only in the most vulnerable areas to inflict lethal damage.
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_READY:TAG_INGAME:::2: You may also choose to ready an action, dependent on something that the enemy does, such as prepare to cast a spell or shoot a bow.  In this case, as soon as the condition is achieved, the character will immediately enact his readied action.  If the condition is not achieved, then that character fails to act in that round.List of Ready Actions[CMD_CHILDREN_SORTED]
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_READY_APPROACH:TAG_INGAM: You may choose to ready versus an approach.  You can take a single ~standard~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION] or ~move~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION] action (or any number of ~free actions~[TAG_FREE_ACTION]) when the next enemy creature enters your threat range.
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_READY_SPELL:TAG_INGAME::: You may choose to ready versus a spell.  You can take a single ~standard~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION] or ~move~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION] action (or any number of ~free actions~[TAG_FREE_ACTION]) when the next enemy spellcaster attempts to cast a spell.
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_READY_WITHDRAWL:TAG_INGA: You may choose to ready versus a withdrawl.  You can take a single ~standard~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION] or ~move~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION] action (or any number of ~free actions~[TAG_FREE_ACTION]) when the next enemy creature attempts to exit your threat range.
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_READY_COUNTERSPELL:TAG_I: You may ready a counterspell against a spellcaster.  In this case, when the spellcaster starts a spell, you get a chance to identify it with a ~Spellcraft~[TAG_SPELLCRAFT] check (DC 15 + spell level).  If you do, and if you can cast that same spell (are able to cast it and have it prepared, if you prepare spells), you can cast the spell as counterspell and automatically ruin the other spellcaster's spell.If you have the ~Improved Counterspell~[TAG_IMPROVED_COUNTERSPELL] feat, to counter a spell, you may use a spell of the same school that is one or more spell levels higher than the other spellcaster's spell.A spellcaster can use ~Dispel Magic~[TAG_SPELLS_DISPEL_MAGIC] to counterspell, but it doesn't always work.
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_RELOAD:TAG_INGAME:::2: You can reload ~bolts~[TAG_WEAPONS_BOLTS] into a ~light~[TAG_WEAPONS_CROSSBOW_LIGHT] or ~heavy~[TAG_WEAPONS_CROSSBOW_HEAVY] crossbow.  Loading a light crossbow is a ~move action~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION] and loading a heavy crossbow is a ~full-round action~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION].  Both provoke an ~attack of opportunity~[TAG_AOO].
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_SNEAK:TAG_INGAME:::2: Sneak is an action that allows you to actively ~Move Silently~[TAG_MOVE_SILENTLY] and ~Hide~[TAG_HIDE] at the same time.  In order for someone to see you while you are sneaking, a ~Spot~[TAG_SPOT] check is needed.  The higher that your Hide skill is, the less likely they will be able to spot you.  Likewise, the lower your Hide skill, the more likely they will be able to spot you.  The same is true of moving silently while you're sneaking; a ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN] check is needed to hear any of your movement and the skill level is measured accordingly.While in Sneak mode in the game, you visually appear to move slower, as if you are prowling.
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_TALK:TAG_INGAME:::2: Using "Talk" in the ~radial menu~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU] will allow you to speak to NPCs.
TAG_RADIAL_MENU_TOTAL_DEFENSE:TAG_INGAME: You can defend yourself as a ~standard action~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION].  You get a +4 dodge bonus to your ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] for 1 round.  Your AC improves at the start of this action, so it helps you against any ~attacks of opportunity~[TAG_AOO] you incur during the round.  You can't combine total defense with ~fighting defensively~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_FIGHT_DEFENSIVELY] or with the benefit of the ~Combat Expertise~[TAG_COMBAT_EXPERTISE] feat (since both of those require you to declare an attack or ~full attack~[TAG_FULL_ATTACK]).  You can't make attacks of opportunity while using total defense.
TAG_ABILITY_DAMAGED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDIT: The character has temporarily lost 1 or more ~ability~[TAG_THE_ABILITIES] score points.  Lost points return at a rate of 1 per day unless noted otherwise by the condition dealing the damage.  A character with ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] 0, ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] 0, ~Intelligence~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] 0, ~Wisdom~[TAG_WISDOM] 0, or ~Charisma~[TAG_CHARISMA] 0 is ~paralyzed~[TAG_PARALYZED].  A character with ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION] 0 is ~dead~[TAG_DEAD].     Ability damage is different from penalties to ~ability scores~[TAG_ABILITY_SCORES], which go away when the conditions causing them (~fatigue~[TAG_FATIGUED], ~entanglement~[TAG_ENTANGLED], etc.) go away.
TAG_ABILITY_DRAINED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDIT: The character has permanently lost 1 or more ~ability~[TAG_THE_ABILITIES] score points.  The character can only regain these points through magical means.  A character with ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] 0, ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] 0, ~Intelligence~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE] 0, ~Wisdom~[TAG_WISDOM] 0, or ~Charisma~[TAG_CHARISMA] 0 is ~paralyzed~[TAG_PARALYZED].  A character with ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION] 0 is ~dead~[TAG_DEAD].
TAG_BLINDED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::2: The character cannot see.  He takes a -2 penalty to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS], loses his ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] bonus to AC (if any), moves at half speed, and takes a -4 penalty on ~Search~[TAG_SEARCH] checks and on most ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] and Dexterity-based ~skill checks~[TAG_USING_SKILLS].  All checks and activities that rely on vision (such as reading and ~Spot~[TAG_SPOT] checks) automatically fail.  All opponents are considered to have total ~concealment~[TAG_CONCEALMENT] (50% miss chance) to the blinded character.     Characters who remain blinded for a long time grow accustomed to these drawbacks and can overcome some of them.
TAG_CHARMED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::2: As the subject of a charm spell (such as ~Charm Animal~[TAG_SPELLS_CHARM_ANIMAL], ~Charm Person~[TAG_SPELLS_CHARM_PERSON], or ~Charm Monster~[TAG_SPELLS_CHARM_MONSTER]), you essentially retain some form of free will, but make choices according to the suggestive powers of the spell.  Your mind may be clouded and you may suddenly be unable to tell friend from foe.  However, the spells do not render you ~helpless~[TAG_HELPLESS] and there are restrictions to what can be done, including the following:  - A charmed character retains his original ~alignment~[TAG_ALIGNMENT] and allegiances, generally with the exception that he now regards the creature who charmed him as a dear friend.  - A charmed character fights his former allies only if they threaten his new friend, and even then he uses the least lethal means at his disposal.  - A charmed character is entitled to an opposing ~Charisma~[TAG_CHARISMA] check against his master in order to resist instructions or commands that would make him do something he wouldn't do even for a close friend. If he succeeds, he decides not to follow that order but remains charmed.  - A charmed character never obeys a command that is obviously suicidal or grievously harmful to him.  - A charmed character who is openly attacked by the creature who charmed him or by that creature's apparent allies is automatically freed of the spell or effect.
TAG_CONFUSED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::: A confused character's actions are determined by rolling d% at the beginning of his turn.  A confused character who can't carry out the indicated action does nothing but babble incoherently.  Attackers are not at any special advantage when attacking a confused character.  Any confused character who is attacked automatically attacks her attackers on her next turn, as long as she is still confused when her turn comes.  A confused character does not make ~attacks of opportunity~[TAG_AOO] against any creature that she is not already devoted to attacking (either because of her most recent action or because she has just been attacked).
TAG_COWERING:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::: The character is frozen in ~fear~[TAG_FEAR] and can take no actions.  A cowering character takes a -2 penalty to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] and loses his ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] bonus (if any).
TAG_DAZED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::2: The creature is unable to act normally.  A dazed creature can take no actions, but has no penalty to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS].
TAG_DAZZLED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::2: The creature is unable to see well because of overstimulation of the eyes.  A dazzled creature takes a -1 penalty on ~attack rolls~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL].
TAG_DEAD:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::2: The creature's ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS] are reduced to -10, his ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION] drops to 0, or he is killed outright by a spell or effect.  The creature's soul leaves his body.  Dead creatures cannot benefit from normal or magical healing, but they can be restored to life via magic.  A dead body decays normally unless magically preserved (such as with the ~Gentle Repose~[TAG_SPELLS_GENTLE_REPOSE] spell), but magic that restores a dead creature to life also restores the body either to full health or to its condition at the time of death (depending on the spell or device).  Either way, resurrected creatures need not worry about rigor mortis, decomposition, and other conditions that affect dead bodies.     An undead creature or a construct is not at risk of death from massive damage, but when reduced to 0 hit points or less, it is immediately destroyed.  Undead, along with ~elementals~[TAG_MONSTER_ELEMENTAL] and non-native outsiders, are not affected by ~Raise Dead~[TAG_SPELLS_RAISE_DEAD] and ~Reincarnation~[TAG_SPELLS_REINCARNATION] spells or abilities.  Since it was never alive, a construct cannot be raised or resurrected.
TAG_DEAFENED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::: A deafened character cannot hear.  She takes a -4 penalty on ~initiative~[TAG_INITIATIVE] checks, automatically fails ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN] checks, and has a 20% chance of spell failure when casting spells with verbal components.     Characters who remain deafened grow accustomed to these drawbacks and can overcome some of them.
TAG_DISABLED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::: A character with 0 ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS], or one who has negative hit points but has become stable and conscious, is disabled.  A disabled character may take a single ~move~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION] or ~standard~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION] action each round (but not both, nor can she take ~full-round actions~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION]).  She moves at half speed.  Taking move actions doesn't risk further injury, but performing any standard action deals 1 point of damage after the completion of the act.  Unless the action increased the disabled character's hit points, she is now in negative hit points and ~dying~[TAG_DYING].     A disabled character recovers hit points from resting normally.
TAG_DISEASED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::: When a character is injured by a contaminated attack, touches an item smeared with disease matter, or consumes disease-tainted food or drink, he or she must make an immediate ~Fortitude~[TAG_FORTITUDE] ~saving throw~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC].  If the person succeeds, the disease has no effect--their immune system fought off the infection.  If the saving throw is failed, they take damage after an incubation period.  Once per day afterward, the character must make a successful Fortitude saving throw to avoid repeated damage.  Two successful saving throws in a row indicate that he has fought off the disease and recovers, taking no more damage.Typical diseases include the following:Blinding Sickness: Spread in tainted water.Cackle Fever: Symptoms include high fever, disorientation, and frequent bouts of hideous laughter. Also known as the "shrieks".Demon Fever: ~Night Hags~[TAG_MONSTER_NIGHT_HAG] spread it. Can cause permanent ~ability drain~[TAG_ABILITY_DRAINED].Devil Chills: ~Barbazu~[TAG_MONSTER_BEARDED_DEVIL] and ~Pit Fiends~[TAG_MONSTER_PIT_FIEND] spread it. It takes three, not two, successful saves in a row to recover from Devil Chills.Filth Fever: ~Dire Rats~[TAG_MONSTER_DIRE_RAT] and ~Otyughs~[TAG_MONSTER_OTYUGH] spread it. Those injured while in filthy surroundings might also catch it.Mindfire: Feels like your brain is burning. Causes stupor.Mummy Rot: Spread by mummies. Successful saving throws do not allow the character to recover (though they do prevent damage normally).Red Ache: Skin turns red, bloated, and warm to the touch.The Shakes: Causes involuntary twitches, tremors, and fits.Slimy Doom: Victim turns into infectious goo from the inside out. Can cause permanent ability drain.Disease                    DC          DamageBlinding Sickness @t16        @t1d4 ~Str~[TAG_STRENGTH]Cackle fever          @t16        @t1d6 ~Wis~[TAG_WISDOM]Filth fever           @t12        @t1d3 ~Dex~[TAG_DEXTERITY] and 1d3 ~Con~[TAG_CONSTITUTION]Mindfire              @t12        @t1d4 ~Int~[TAG_INTELLIGENCE]Red ache              @t15        @t1d6 StrShakes                  @t13        @t1d8 DexSlimy doom            @t14        @t1d4 Con
TAG_DYING:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::2: A dying character is unconscious and near death.  She has -1 to -9 current ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS].  A dying character can take no actions and is ~unconscious~[TAG_UNCONSCIOUS].  At the end of each round (starting with the round in which the character dropped below 0 hit points), the character rolls d% to see whether she becomes stable.  She has a 10% chance of becoming stable.  If she does not, she loses 1 hit point.  If a dying character reaches -10 hit points, she is ~dead~[TAG_DEAD].
TAG_ENERGY_DRAINED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITI: The character gains one or more negative levels, which might permanently drain the character's levels.     If the subject has at least as many negative levels as Hit Dice, he dies.  Each negative level gives a creature the following penalties:     -1 penalty on ~attack rolls~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL], ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC], ~skill checks~[TAG_USING_SKILLS], and ability checks     loss of 5 ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS]     -1 to effective level (for determining the power, duration, DC, and other details of spells or special abilities)     In addition, a spellcaster loses one spell or spell slot from the highest spell level castable.
TAG_ENTANGLED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS::: The character is ensnared.  Being entangled impedes movement, but does not entirely prevent it unless the bonds are anchored to an immobile object or tethered by an opposing force.  An entangled creature moves at half speed, cannot ~run~[TAG_RUN] or ~charge~[TAG_CHARGE], and takes a -2 penalty on all ~attack rolls~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL] and a -4 penalty to ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY].  An entangled character who attempts to cast a spell must make a ~Concentration~[TAG_CONCENTRATION] check (DC 15 + the spell's level) or lose the spell.
TAG_EXHAUSTED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS::: An exhausted character moves at half speed and take a -6 penalty to ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] and ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY].  After 1 hour of complete rest, an exhausted character becomes ~fatigued~[TAG_FATIGUED].  A fatigued character becomes exhausted by doing something else that would normally cause fatigue.
TAG_FASCINATED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:: A fascinated creature is entranced by a supernatural or spell effect.  The creature stands or sits quietly, taking no actions other than to pay attention to the fascinating effects, for as long as the effect lasts.  It takes a -4 penalty on ~skill checks~[TAG_USING_SKILLS] made as reactions, such as ~Listen~[TAG_LISTEN] and ~Spot~[TAG_SPOT] checks.  Any potential threat, such as a hostile creature approaching, allows the fascinated creature a new ~saving throw~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC] against the fascinating effect.  Any obvious threat, such as someone drawing a weapon, casting a spell, or aiming a ranged weapon at the fascinated creature, automatically breaks the effect.  A fascinated creature's ally may shake it free of the spell as a ~standard action~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION].
TAG_FATIGUED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::: A fatigued character can neither ~run~[TAG_RUN] nor ~charge~[TAG_CHARGE] and takes a -2 penalty to ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] and ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY].  Doing anything that would normally cause fatigue causes the fatigued character to become ~exhausted~[TAG_EXHAUSTED].  After 8 hours of complete rest, fatigued characters are no longer fatigued.
TAG_FEAR:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::2: Any spell or magical effect that causes the victim to become ~shaken~[TAG_SHAKEN], ~frightened~[TAG_FRIGHTENED], ~panicked~[TAG_PANICKED], or to suffer from some other fear-based effect defined in the description of the specific spell, item, or creature in question.     If a fear effect allows a ~saving throw~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC], it is a ~Will~[TAG_WILL] save.  All fear attacks are mind-affecting effects.
TAG_FLAT_FOOTED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS: A character who has not yet acted during combat is flat-footed and is especially vulnerable to attacks.  Characters remain flat-footed until their first turn in the ~initiative~[TAG_INITIATIVE] cycle.   A flat-footed character loses his ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] bonus to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] (if any) and cannot make ~attacks of opportunity~[TAG_AOO].     ~Barbarians~[TAG_BARBARIANS] and ~rogues~[TAG_ROGUES] have the ~Uncanny Dodge~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_UNCANNY_DODGE] extraordinary ability, which allows them to avoid losing their AC due to being flat-footed.
TAG_FRIGHTENED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:: Fearful of a creature, situation, or object.  A frightened creature flees from the source of its fear as best it can.  If unable to flee, it may fight.  A frightened creature takes a -2 penalty on all ~attack rolls~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL], ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC], ~skill checks~[TAG_USING_SKILLS], and ability checks.  A frightened creature can use special abilities, including spells, to flee; indeed, the creature must use such means if they are the only way to escape.     Frightened is like ~shaken~[TAG_SHAKEN], except that the creature must flee if possible.  ~Panicked~[TAG_PANICKED] is a more extreme state of ~fear~[TAG_FEAR].
TAG_GRAPPLING:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS::: Engaged in wrestling or some other form of hand-to-hand struggle with one or more attackers.  A grappling character can undertake only a limited number of actions.  He does not threaten any squares, and loses his ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] bonus to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] (if any) against opponents he isn't grappling.  See ~Grapple~[TAG_GRAPPLE].
TAG_HELD:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::2: Held characters are subjected to enchantments that make them unable to move.  They are ~helpless~[TAG_HELPLESS].  They can perform no physical actions (but they continue to breathe and can take purely mental actions).
TAG_HOLDING_A_CHARGE:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDI: As a spellcaster, if you don't discharge a touch spell on the round that you cast it, you can hold the charge (postpone the discharge of the spell) indefinitely.  You can make ~touch attacks~[TAG_TOUCH_ATTACK] round after round.  You can touch a creature (or yourself) as a ~standard action~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION].  If you touch anything with your hand while holding a charge, the spell discharges.  If you cast another spell, the touch spell dissipates.
TAG_INVISIBLE:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS::: Visually undetectable.  An invisible creature gains a +2 bonus on ~attack rolls~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL] against sighted opponents, and ignores its opponents' ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] bonuses to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] (if any).     Invisible creatures also gain the 50% automatic miss chance afforded by total ~concealment~[TAG_CONCEALMENT].
TAG_LEVEL_LOSS:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:: In ToEE, level loss is experienced by the character as a draining of ~experience points~[TAG_EXPERIENCE_AND_LEVELS], instead of simply losing a level.  For example, if a 6th-level ~fighter~[TAG_FIGHTERS] dies during combat, she will not automatically be dropped to 5th-level, but rather will lose an appropriate amount of XP.     This character condition can be countered with ~Restoration~[TAG_SPELLS_RESTORATION], which will restore the character with enough XP to put them at the minimum amount of their previous level.
TAG_NAUSEATED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS::: Experiencing stomach distress.  Nauseated creatures are unable to attack, cast spells, concentrate on spells, or do anything else requiring attention.  The only action such a character can take is a single ~move action~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION] per turn.
TAG_PANICKED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::: A panicked creature must drop everything and flee at top speed from the source of its fear, as well as any other dangers it encounters, along a random path.  It can't take any other actions.  In addition, the creature takes a -2 penalty on ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC], ~skill checks~[TAG_USING_SKILLS], and ability checks.  If cornered, a panicked creature ~cowers~[TAG_COWERING].  A panicked creature can use special abilities, including spells, to flee; indeed, the creature must use such means if they are the only way to escape.     Panicked is a more extreme state of ~fear~[TAG_FEAR] than ~shaken~[TAG_SHAKEN] or ~frightened~[TAG_FRIGHTENED].
TAG_PARALYZED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS::: A paralyzed character stands rigid, unable to move or act physically.  He has effective ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] and ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] scores of 0 and is ~helpless~[TAG_HELPLESS], but can take purely mental actions.
TAG_PRONE:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::2: The character is on the ground.  A character who is prone cannot attack, but he gains a +4 bonus to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS] against ~ranged attacks~[TAG_RANGED_ATTACKS].  However, he also takes a -4 penalty to AC against ~melee attacks~[TAG_MELEE_ATTACKS].
TAG_SHAKEN:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::2: Mildly fearful.  A shaken character takes a -2 penalty on ~attack rolls~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL], ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC], ~skill checks~[TAG_USING_SKILLS], and ability checks.     Shaken is a less severe state of ~fear~[TAG_FEAR] than ~frightened~[TAG_FRIGHTENED] or ~panicked~[TAG_PANICKED].
TAG_SICKENED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::: The character takes a -2 penalty on all ~attack rolls~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL], weapon damage rolls, ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC], ~skill checks~[TAG_USING_SKILLS], and ability checks.
TAG_SLEEPING:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::: If you are the recipient of a ~Sleep~[TAG_SPELLS_SLEEP] spell, you fall into a magical slumber.  As a sleeping creature, you are ~helpless~[TAG_HELPLESS] and normal noise cannot be used to wake you.
TAG_STAGGERED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS::: A character whose ~nonlethal damage~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_NONLETHAL_DAMAGE] exactly equals his current ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS] is staggered.  A staggered character may take a single ~move action~[TAG_MOVEMENT_ACTION] or ~standard action~[TAG_STANDARD_ACTION] each round (but not both, nor can he take ~full-round actions~[TAG_FULL_ROUND_ACTION]).
TAG_STUNNED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::2: A stunned creature can't take actions, takes a -2 penalty to ~AC~[TAG_ARMOR_CLASS], and loses his ~Dexterity~[TAG_DEXTERITY] bonus to AC (if any).
TAG_TEMPORARY_HIT_POINTS:TAG_CHARACTER_C: Certain effects, such as the ~Aid~[TAG_SPELLS_AID] spell, give a character temporary hit points.  When a character gains temporary hit points, he should take note of his current ~hit point~[TAG_HIT_POINTS] total.  When the temporary hit points go away, such as at the end of the Aid spell's duration, the character's hit points drop to his current hit point total.  If the character's hit points are below his current hit point total at that time, all the temporary hit points have already been lost and the character's hit point total does not drop further.     When temporary hit points are lost, they cannot be restored as real hit points can be, even by magic.
TAG_TURNED:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS:::2: Affected by a ~turn undead~[TAG_TURN] attempt.  Turned undead flee for 10 rounds (1 minute) by the best and fastest means available to them.  If they cannot flee, they ~cower~[TAG_COWERING].
TAG_UNCONSCIOUS:TAG_CHARACTER_CONDITIONS: Knocked out and ~helpless~[TAG_HELPLESS].  Unconsciousness can result from having current ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS] between -1 and -9, or from ~nonlethal damage~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_NONLETHAL_DAMAGE] in excess of current hit points.
TAG_SPECIAL_ABILITIES::::2: A special ability is either extraordinary, spell-like, or supernatural in nature.  - Extraordinary abilities are nonmagical.  A ~monk's~[TAG_MONKS] ability to ~evade~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_MONK_EVASION] attacks and a ~barbarian's~[TAG_BARBARIANS] ~uncanny dodge~[TAG_CLASS_FEATURES_BARBARIAN_UNCANNY_DODGE] are extraordinary abilities.  - Spell-like abilities, as the name implies, are spells and magical abilities that are very much like spells.  Spell-like abilities are subject to spell resistance and ~Dispel Magic~[TAG_SPELLS_DISPEL_MAGIC].  - Supernatural abilities are not subject to spell resistance and do not function in areas where magic is suppressed or negated.[CMD_CHILDREN_SORTED]
TAG_SPECIAL_ABILITIES_ABILITY_SCORE_LOSS: Various attacks cause ~ability score~[TAG_ABILITY_SCORES] loss, either ~ability damage~[TAG_ABILITY_DAMAGED] or ~ability drain~[TAG_ABILITY_DRAINED].  Points lost to ability damage return at the rate of 1 point per day (or double that if the character gets complete bed rest) to each damaged ability, and the spell ~Lesser Restoration~[TAG_SPELLS_RESTORATION_LESSER] offsets ability damage as well.  Ability drain, however, is permanent, though ~Restoration~[TAG_SPELLS_RESTORATION] can restore even those lost ability points.     Having a score of 0 in an ability is different from having no ability score whatsoever.  For example, a wraith has no ~Strength~[TAG_STRENGTH] score, not a Strength score of 0.  The wraith can move, it just can't act physically on other objects.     Some spells or abilities impose an effective ability score reduction, which is different than ability score loss.  Any such reduction disappears at the end of the spell's or ability's duration, and the ability score immediately returns to its former value.     If a character's ~Constitution~[TAG_CONSTITUTION] score drops, then he or she loses 1 ~hit point~[TAG_HIT_POINTS] per Hit Die for every point by which his or her Constitution modifier drops.
TAG_SPECIAL_ABILITIES_DAMAGE_REDUCTION:T: Some magic creatures have the supernatural ability to instantly heal damage from weapons or to ignore blows altogether as though they were invulnerable.     The numerical part of a creature's damage reduction is the amount of ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS] the creature ignores from normal attacks.  Thus, a creature with a damage reduction number of 5 that is struck for 8 points of damage will ignore 5 points and take only 3 points of damage.     Usually, a certain type of weapon can overcome this reduction. This information is separated from the damage reduction by a slash. For example, a ~Salamander's~[TAG_MONSTER_SALAMANDER_AVERAGE] damage reduction is 10/magic, meaning the Salamander ignores the first 10 points of damage from every normal attack unless it is made with a magic weapon. If a dash follows the slash (for example, a ~Large Air Elemental~[TAG_MONSTER_ELEMENTAL_AIR_LARGE] has a DR of 5/-), then the damage reduction is effective against any attack that does not ignore damage reduction.
TAG_SPECIAL_ABILITIES_ENERGY_DRAIN_AND_N: Some horrible creatures, especially undead monsters, possess a fearsome supernatural ability to drain levels from those they strike in combat.  The creature making an energy drain attack draws a portion of its victim's life force from him.     Most energy drain attacks require a successful melee ~attack roll~[TAG_ATTACK_ROLL]--mere physical contact is not enough.  ~Monks~[TAG_MONKS], for instance, can pound such creatures with their fists without risking their life energy.     Each successful energy drain attack bestows one or more negative levels on the opponent.  A creature takes the following penalties for each negative level it has gained:     -1 on all ~skill~[TAG_USING_SKILLS] and ability checks     -1 on attack rolls and ~saving throws~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC]     -5 ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS]     -1 effective level     Negative levels remain for 24 hours or until removed with a spell, such as ~Restoration~[TAG_SPELLS_RESTORATION].  After 24 hours, the afflicted creature must attempt a ~Fortitude~[TAG_FORTITUDE] save.  If the saving throw succeeds, the negative level goes away with no harm to the creature.  The afflicted creature makes a separate saving throw for each negative level it has gained.  If the save fails, the negative level goes away, but the creature's level is also reduced by one.
TAG_SPECIAL_ABILITIES_FAST_HEALING:TAG_S: A creature may have the extraordinary ability to regain ~hit points~[TAG_HIT_POINTS] at an exceptional rate.     At the beginning of each of the creature's turns, it heals a certain number of hit points.     Unlike ~regeneration~[TAG_REGENERATION], fast healing does not allow a creature to regrow or reattach lost body parts.     A creature that has taken both ~nonlethal~[TAG_RADIAL_MENU_NONLETHAL_DAMAGE] and ~lethal~[TAG_NORMAL_DAMAGE] damage heals the nonlethal damage first.
TAG_POISON:TAG_SPECIAL_ABILITIES:::2: When a character comes into contact with poison he must make an initial ~Fortitude~[TAG_FORTITUDE] ~saving throw~[TAG_SAVING_THROW_DESC].  If he fails, he takes the poisons initial damage (usually ~ability damage~[TAG_ABILITY_DAMAGED]).  Even if he succeeds, he typically faces more damage 1 minute later, which he can avoid with a successful Fortitude saving throw.PoisonsArsenic  Type: Ingested DC 13Initial Damage: 1 StrSecondary Damage: 1d6 StrLich dustType: Ingested DC 17Initial Damage: 2d6 StrSecondary Damage: 1d6 StrMalyss root pasteType: Contact DC 16Initial Damage: 1 DexSecondary Damage: 2d4
